story:
Who are we and what is iGEM?

We are a group of students from five countries and study in Linköping, Sweden. 

This summer, we are working on a non-profit project for the international genetically engineered machines (iGEM) competition, the largest synthetic biology research contest with 300 teams from all over the world. The goal is to solve real-world problems by modifying biological organisms.

Besides the obvious laboratory part, our work also includes Human Practice, where we get in contact with experts in the field and in our case Swedish farmers who experience water shortages. We use the input we receive to further improve our project. 

We want to make our project easily understandable for everyone. Therefore, we are also working on the Wiki (our webpage) and the representation of our team on all our social media accounts. Additionally, we create illustrations, videos, and presentations for a better explanation of our project and the problem of water shortage.

What is CyaSalt?

CyaSalt is our solution to the increasing threat of water shortage that all of us are facing. Although our planet provides us with an abundance of water, we can only utilize roughly 1% as fresh water. Many people already suffer from this shortage and with a rapidly growing world population, it is bound to get worse, if nothing changes. Already in 2025, half of us will be living in water-stressed areas. Current desalination technologies are highly energy and resource-consuming, which is why we want to present a more sustainable and environmentally friendly solution.

How do we want to fight the water shortage?

Cyanobacteria are the ideal organisms to create freshwater because they are able to grow in high salt concentrations (like seawater) and the use of the clean energy source sunlight as their primary energy source makes it a more sustainable option. We want to genetically modify the bacteria to achieve a higher salt uptake.

Our project can be described by what we call the CyaSalt cycle. Starting with the cultivation of the modified cyanobacteria, moving on to the actual desalination process, and then the separation of the cyanobacteria from the desalinated water. The cycle ends with part of the bacterial biomass being used for starting a new cycle, and the rest being used for biofuel production.

An in-depth explanation for science-lovers:

Our solution is to utilize the photosynthetic and halophilic properties of the cyanobacteria Synechosystis sp. PCC 6803 so that it can successfully desalinate seawater. We will use plasmids that contain the target genes to genetically modify the bacteria ①. After a successful transformation, the bacteria will express the inward-directed chloride pump Halorhodopsin and the cation channel MscL ②. Halorhodopsin is activated by light and creates a chloride influx which leads to a concentration gradient that accelerates the transport of sodium ions through MscL into the cells ③. Now that the salt ions are trapped within the cyanobacteria ④, we have to separate them from the water. To achieve this, we will genetically modify them to express a fusion protein containing a membrane-anchored protein as well as a cellulose-binding domain (CBD) on the outer membrane ⑤. This will allow for easy separation by filtering the water through a cellulose matrix leading to covalent binding of the bacteria to the cellulose ⑥. Optimally, a large part of the accumulating bacterial waste could be used for the production of biofuel.

 

What happens with your donation? 

Although researching is fun and really important it is very costly. The donations we receive will be used mostly for the lab work. Part of it will cover our costs to participate in the Giant Jamboree where we will finally present our project to the other iGEM teams. The rest will be used to increase public awareness about the water shortage and our project.

Next to our amazing perks, as a thank you, we will add your name as a sponsor on our webpage.

How can you reach us?

Follow us on our social media or contact us via email. 

                  

Give our podcast a try if you are interested in the topic and want to be up to date!

Our website is still under construction but feel free to check it out!

story:
The Cork Forest Conservation Alliance is the only North American nonprofit, whose sole mission is to preserve and protect the Mediterranean cork forests. We are members of the FSC, European Forestry Institute, and the United Nations ECOSOC for NGO's. 

The cork forests are considered one of the most environmentally important forest regions on our planet, yet little is known about them. Many people think the trees are cut down and there is a cork shortage, neither of which is true.

The idea behind the Cork Art Cube is to give people something really beautiful to look at and because we all love our smart phones, a fun way to learn about our forest conservation efforts and their planet.

We didn't spend any money on this video, as you can tell. It was made on an iPhone!  We wanted to tell our story, in a fun way and save our $$$ for the real reason we all work 60 hours a week, to save the cork forests. 

It’s been five years since we started our organization and we realized that we needed to take the education/awareness process to another level. The Cork Art Cube, we believe, will be that vehicle.  It will travel across the US and be set up in public places where thousands of people will pass by and have an opportunity to view it and have fun. When the QR code is scanned a gorgeous, 40 second video will pop up, not a stagnant webpage. This video will engage the viewer and let them know how they can learn more about our efforts. 

 

Our budget is $25,000, 100% of which will go to funding this project. It will cover the cost of building the cube, creating high quality videos, transportation and the fees associated with placing the cube in 15 cities across America.

We've got some great perks:

  • A set of 6 cork coasters,
  • Our 100% organic cotton, Quercus suber t-shirt
  • An eco-friendly cork watch from Sprout.
  • Your name on the video as a Co-Producer
  • Best of all, a guided trip to the cork forests and a cork manufacturing facility in Portugal. Airfare, Transportation and Hotels included. 
  • If you contribute and we come to your city, we'd love to take your picture with the cube and post it on our website. 

 

Your contribution will help advance our forest conservation efforts in a number of ways:

  • Helping to educate the public about the vital environmental importance this forest region has to health of our planet.
  • Building a large network of people commited to our organizations forest conservation efforts.
  • Advancing our public awareness and education campaign
  • Helping us to reforest the most critical areas of the cork forests

Our Cork ReHarvest, natural cork-recycling program is the largest in North America. It has helped to remove millions of used wine corks from our landfills and helped to educate the public about our efforts. With corporate partners like Whole Foods Market, Wente Vineyards, Bobby Flay, Mario Battali, and Caesar’s Palace in Las Vegas we have raised the awareness of the American public regarding the impending danger facing the cork forests. 

 

If you can't contribute, please let your friends know about our efforts, use the Indiegogo share tools and please visit our website to learn more. Thank you and we appreciate your support.

story:
About the Expedition (And me!)

I have been a canoe enthusiast and passionate environmentalist since I was a child. This lust for the outdoors and a sense of urgency to protect our natural resources has guided me through life. Most recently, it has led me to help start up a non-profit, Wild River Academy. Wild River Academy provides canoe expeditions along the Minnesota River. Trips stop along the route to interact with environmental organizations, community members, farmers, and State Park Rangers. This experiential learning opportunity not only enhances outdoor skills, it exposes participants to the social and natural environment in the Minnesota River watershed, encouraging a sense of peace and place. 

The trip down the Mississippi is Wild River Academy's most ambitious trip yet. In the fall of 2013, I, along with eight other people, will embark on and film a three month long canoe journey down the Mississippi River from the headwaters in Lake Itasca, Minnesota, to New Orleans. As we paddle, we will engage communities in an ongoing dialogue about their relationships to and interactions with this watertrail to give voice to the Mississippi River, its inhabitants, and the many perspectives we encounter along the way. Upon completion of the trip, we will produce a documentary of this journey so that these vital conversations can continue with others beyond the flow of the river.

Why Paddle the Mississippi? 

This is a great question. As the climate debate comes to a head in the United States, it’s easy to lose sight of the everyday people whose lives revolve around the health of a natural resource. We think it is vital to not only document what we learn about the river from the perspective of a canoe, but also to listen to and engage with a few of the 18 million people who rely on the Mississippi for drinking water. 

What I Need 

So the breakdown is pretty simple.  First and foremost, I need to eat.  I’m asking $720 for all of my food expenses.

Food for one day:

$9

Food for one week:

$63

Food for one month:

$279

Food for the whole trip:

$720

While it would be nice if there were no other expenses, there are.  Both myself and my canoe need to come back to Minneapolis in one piece.  The breakdown is as such:

Ship a canoe to Minneapolis

$130

Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities

$150

                                                                         Total Trip Cost:         $1,000

What Do You Get If You Help Fund My Campaign?

$25 – A HUGE hug and a postcard from somewhere along the river. My standard hug is pretty big, so just be prepared. Also lots of karma points.

$50 – A shout-out to you or your organization on our Twitter and Facebook with a picture of me featuring your name or company. Plus a HUGE hug and a postcard from somewhere along the river. And a canoe-full of karma points.

$100 – Your name will be featured in the credits of our documentary. This could be your big break! Plus A HUGE hug, a postcard, and a photo shout-out, and a multitude of karma points.

$250 – A Paddle For Change t-shirt. Who doesn't love a good t-shirt?? Plus A GIGANTIC hug, a postcard, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, and a photo shout-out. And feel free to give yourself pats on the back at any time.

$500 - A copy of our finished documentary! Show it to your friends! Plus a Paddle For Change t-shirt, your name in the credits of our documentary, a photo shout-out, a postcard, a hug, and as many karma points as I can summon from the universe.

$1,000 – A copy of the finished documentary, a photo shout-out, a Paddle For Change t-shirt, your name in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, THE BIGGEST hug, and my eternal gratitude. And I will wish happy things for you for all of my birthday wishes from here on out.

The Impact

Without your support, this trip is not possible. Not only will I personally grow from this challenging and unique experience, but I will connect with new people to develop a constructive dialogue about our lives in the United States and the world.

Upon returning, we will have the incredible opportunity to construct a national dialogue about the Mississippi by creating a documentary of our experiences.  This documentary will spark conversations about our national resources, water usage, the meaning of community, and the very nature (pun!) of what it means to be "in nature."  We believe strongly that these are dialogues that our nation must be having more often with one another, and I would be proud to be a part of this legacy.  Besides, everyone likes a good documentary, amiright? 

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to contribute monetarily, but that doesn’t mean you can't help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. Also, if you are a teacher or know of a classroom that would be interested in following us on our journey and tuning in to video chats with us, let us know!!

Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us. Though our group has a great deal of paddling experience, we cannot do this without community support. We welcome your insight. 

https://www.facebook.com/paddleforchange

https://www.facebook.com/WildRiverAcademy

THANK YOU! And happy trails!

story:
Short Summary

We are a family of four in an unhealthy and unsafe envirinment.  A sewage spill happened due to the landlords deferred maintinance (pulled an eight inch ball of roots out of the main drain).  There have been four clean up companies out to give an estimate but the landlord will not hire any of them to clean up propertly.

Since some of the sheetrock was pulled out, there is clearly black mold growing between the walls.  I have contacted city code enforcement, the health department and an attorney, but none of those can do anything to help with the housing situation.

Our landlord will not renew our lease now that we have called City Code enforcement and complained about the lack of sufficient clean up.

We need to have a place to move into when we get back from the funeral next week.

The boys' father just left Colorado to work in California when we got word that his father died unexpectedly on vacation scuba diving, so we are all grienving right now.

Any donations will go directly towards moving expenses, we are already approved for a house, we just need the funds to get out of this unsafe environment.

Please share this campaign with your friends, every little dollar helps!

story:
Who We Are

The Factory Farming Awareness Coalition is an educational non-profit dedicated to empowering people to help the environment, animals, and our own health through our daily food choices.

FFAC educates people about factory farming through presentations and public outreach campaigns. We have given over 200 presentations across the United States and Mexico to classes, community organizations, and businesses.

The Issue

Nearly 10 billion animals are raised for food every year in the United States, 99% of them on factory farms. This system is hugely detrimental for:

  • Environment: Factory farming is one of the leading causes of water pollution, deforestation, soil erosion, and climate change.
  • Animals: The animals raised on factory farms spend their entire lives confined indoors with thousands of other animals, often in spaces so small they cannot even turn around.
  • Workers: Workers on factory farms and in slaughterhouses face some of the most dangerous working conditions in the country with no access to health care or fair wages.
  • Public Health: The overconsumption of animal products plays a major role in the health epidemics facing this country (heart disease, cancer, diabetes, obesity), and the overuse of antibiotics in animals puts us at risk of antibiotic-resistant epidemics.

The Victory

For the second year in a row, we won nearly $50,000 worth of free advertisements on San Francisco's public transit system. We will use this opportunity to educate people about the impacts of factory farming on animals and on the environment.

What We Need

Right now, we're asking for your help to pay for professional graphic design for our ads. High-quality design will give our ads maximum visual punch and allow us to relay our message clearly and effectively. 

Any additional money raised will go towards our educational outreach program, to train more presenters and reach out to new audiences.

The Impact

Over 300,000 people per day will see these ads! This is a tremendous opportunity to raise awareness about factory farming, and to urge people to take easy steps like Meatless Mondays.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign with your friends & family. Every dollar makes a difference!
  • Like us on Facebook & follow us on Twitter @ffacoalition
  • E-mail info@ffacoalition.org to learn about volunteer opportunities or to schedule a presentation in your community

story:
The Project: Plant survey in the South-West of Turkey

“What is it all about?”

The aim of this project it to carry out a botanical survey of the wild plants growing in the Taurus mountains between, Antalya and Ipartas (South-western Turkey).

The scientific assessment of the plant biodiversity will also contribute to a better understanding of the plant distribution and taxonomy of this botanically rich but very understudied region. 

“Why do a survey of the wild flora in the foothills of the Taurus Mountains, in the South West of Turkey?”

Turkey is a place of extraordinary plant biodiversity and remarkably rich habitats and geography, with more than 9000 referenced vascular plant species, 30 % of which are endemic (not existing anywhere else). To put this in perspective, Europe is thirteen times the size of Turkey and has around13000 vascular plant species, only 4000 more than Turkey.  

This unique flora, however is surprisingly understudied compared to European countries. To be able to preserve this wonderful biodiversity, we need to know what it is composed of and as a botanist I really feel I need to use my knowledge and passion to do this.

With your help, I'm sure we could positively contribute to the on going efforts of a better understanding of plant distributions and habitats in Turkey. There is even the possibility of discovering as yet unknown plants.

“What I need, and what you get?”

To carry out the survey I need to scientifically name each plant that I encounter in my study area. To do this a botanist uses an identification flora, which is usually composed of multiple choice keys, based on the morphological characters of the plant that is being identified. These books are the botanist's best friend because they enable the identification of plants that he/she has not yet been seen meaning that new areas can be studied independently without direct transmission of knowledge. In the study of the European flora, we are very lucky to have access to good quality identification keys at accessible prices. This is unfortunately not the case for Turkey's flora: P.H.Davis and his team from the University of Edinburgh have produced a very good identification key, however the 11 volumes of the «Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands » costs 1700 GBP. My budget is too small to support such an investment but it is the only book offering identification keys for the study area, no regional book for the south west of Anatolia yet exists (until I write one) and without out it I will be unable to identify and keep a log of those species that have already been located.

This is why, to bring this project to life, your contribution is essential. By helping me raise a total of 2000Euros/1700GBP you will give me the possibility to carry out this botanical research study and buy the one essential tool I need the «Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands ».

Link :Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands (amazon)


"Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Island"

“What will you get?”

Everyone that contributes 10 euros or more to the realisation of this project will receive an e-mail thanking you for your support and photographic updates of the plants studied. This will be followed by a print of one of my botanical illustrations drawn on the field in Turkey and a signed copy of my dissertation.

“A bit about me”



My name is Jah-Wild Skipper, I am a 23 year old Franco/English botanist. I have been studying this discipline in depth for the last six years and teaching field botany regularly at Lyon’s Medicinal plant school for the last three years. 

I have a technical French diploma in Nature conservation and a diploma in botanical gardening. As part of my studies, I worked for a year in Lyon’s Botanical gardens, renowned for its rich collections and specialist botanists and gardeners. During this period, I located two rare fern hybrids in the Rhône region of France  (Asplenium x amternifolium) as well as the only recorded siting of Oreopteris limbosperma in the Ardeche. 

I consider myself and am seen by others as a true 'field botanist', always studying the plants on the field in their natural habitats.

During the course of my evolution as a botanist, I felt the need to learn some university skills and followed a “University botany diploma” at Picardie University in France. To validate this course I need to write a dissertation. With your help I will be able to carry it out in Turkey where every field botanist counts : )!

“In a nutshell how would you make a difference by funding this project?”

By helping this project come to life, you would:

→ Enable one more person to work towards a better understanding of the little known flora of Turkey and at the same time help to resolve taxonomic, ecological and distribution questions that are essential for any nature conservation plan to be successful.

→ Give wild plants the recognition they deserve as is too often forgotten, they support nearly every ecosystem on this planet.

→ And last but not least help a botanist to carry on learning and therefore be of greater use for the protection of plants and their biotope in the future.

"Other ways you can help"

If every one spreads the word about my project throught their networks, that would be great! 

Thankyou!
story_txt:
The
Project: Plant survey in the South-West of Turkey

“What is it all about?”

 The aim of this project it to carry out a botanical survey of the wild plants growing in the Taurus mountains between, Antalya and Ipartas (South-western Turkey).The scientific assessment of the plant biodiversity will also contribute to a better understanding of the plant distribution and taxonomy of this botanically rich but very understudied region. 

“Why
do a survey of the wild flora in the foothills of the Taurus
Mountains, in the South West of Turkey?”
	Turkey is a place of extraordinary plant biodiversity and remarkably rich habitats and geography, with more than 9000 referenced vascular
plant species, 30 % of which are endemic (not existing anywhere
else). To put this in perspective, Europe is thirteen times the size of Turkey and has around13000 vascular plant species, only 4000 more than Turkey.  This unique flora, however is
surprisingly understudied compared to European countries. To be able
to preserve this wonderful biodiversity, we need to know  what it is
composed of and as a botanist I really feel I need to use my
knowledge and passion to do this.With your help, I'm sure we could
positively contribute to the on going efforts of a better
understanding of plant distributions and habitats in Turkey. There is
even the possibility of discovering as yet unknown plants.  

“What
I need, and what you get?”

	To carry out
the survey I need to scientifically name each plant that I
encounter in my study area. To do this a botanist uses an
identification flora, which is usually composed of multiple choice
keys, based on the morphological characters of the plant that is
being identified. These books are the botanist's best friend because
they enable the identification of plants that he/she has not yet been seen
meaning that new areas can be studied independently without direct
transmission of knowledge. In the study of the European flora, we are
very lucky to have access to good quality identification keys at
accessible prices. This is unfortunately not the case for Turkey's
flora: P.H.Davis and his team from the University of Edinburgh have
produced a very good identification key, however the 11 volumes of
the «Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands » costs 1700 GBP.
My budget is too small to support such an investment but it is the
only book offering identification keys for the study area, no
regional book for the south west of Anatolia yet exists (until I
write one) and without out it I will be unable to identify and keep a
log of those species that have already been located.

	This is why, to
bring this project to life, your contribution is essential. By
helping me raise a total of 2000Euros/1700GBP  you will give me the
possibility to carry out this botanical research study and buy the
one essential tool I need the  «Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean
Islands ».Link :Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean Islands (amazon)"Flora
of Turkey and  the East Aegean Island"“What

that contributes 10 euros or more to the realisation of this project will receive an

copy of my dissertation.

bit about me”My name is Jah-Wild Skipper, I am a 23 year old Franco/English botanist. During this period, I located two rare fern hybrids in the Rhône region of France  (Asplenium x amternifolium) as well as the only recorded siting of Oreopteris limbosperma in the Ardeche. 

I consider
myself and am seen by others as a true 'field botanist', always
studying the plants on the field in their natural habitats.

During the
course of my evolution as a botanist, I felt the need to learn some
university skills and followed a “University botany diploma” at
Picardie University in France. To validate this course I need to
write a dissertation. With your help I will be able to carry it out
in Turkey where every field botanist counts : )!
“In

project come to life, you would:

more person to work towards a better understanding of the little
known flora of Turkey and at the same time help to resolve taxonomic,

nature conservation plan to be successful.→ Give wild
plants the recognition they deserve as is too often forgotten, they
support nearly every ecosystem on this planet.→ And last but
not least help a botanist to carry on learning and therefore be of
greater use for the protection of plants and their biotope in the future.
"Other ways you can help"

story:
I am in line to be the 5th generation owner of our small 30 acre property in rural Arkansas. My Great-Great Grandfather purchased an immense amount of land in the area, which was divided up among his children and eventually sold off. Of his original expansive property, only our 30 acres and the diagonal 30 acre plot still belong to his direct family members.  Over the last few years, images from the USDA Farm Service Agency seem to show that the forest has thinned out over time.

More than 50 years ago, my Great Grandfather set out to expand the existing pine forest on the property. He was able to go out and double the size of the woods by himself, with little more than determination and a solid work ethic. 

Since these trees have grown to maturity, they have provided a natural habitat for a variety of wild animals. All of the adjacent properties have opted to cut down the majority of their trees in favor of grazing fields, which leaves limited options for local wildlife, such as White-tailed deer. These animals are constantly under threat during hunting season, especially when some hunters illegally kill and collect them from our land. 

My plan is to start by planting 1,000 additional trees of multiple varieties. The proposed tree species would include Black Walnut, Pecan, Persimmon, Red Mulberry, and Redbud. These trees were selected for their appeal to wildlife, in hopes of promoting biodiversity and restoring the natural ecosystem. The trees would serve a secondary purpose by providing more cover to our deer from hunters on the road, or on the adjacent properties. 

Our forest area is approximately 15 acres, and of course 1,000 trees may not be enough to completely fill it out. However, I am confident that it will be a good start. I would like to continue maintaining the work my Great Grandfather did for the local environment. I currently live in the suburbs, and planting this many trees on the property is the most significant way that I can think of to make a contribution to nature. By diversifying the tree species, and through man-made contributions such as bird and bat houses, I hope to provide housing for a variety of different animal species.

Cost Breakdown:

1,000 Trees ($300): The Arkansas Forestry Service offers trees at a very reasonable rate in order to promote reforestation in the state. They realize that the benefits of additional trees are seen at every level, from the immediate tree planting area to the carbon sink they provide for the entire ecosystem. 

Four Dibble Bars ($179.80): Dibble Bars are a tool used for planting seedlings in the soil. We would need a minimum of four so I could work together with some people to speed up the process. 

Farm Truck ($800): Nothing fancy, I am just looking for an old used F-150 or something similar, both to transport trees from the pickup location, and also to enhance our ability to move them around the property. This is by far the largest monetary investment, but I would also be able to use it for the next rounds of tree planting, as well as other sustainable projects around the property. 

Refrigeration ($200): In order to keep the seedlings at the proper storage temperature, and to ensure a large yield, I will need to purchase a small refrigeration system. This will be essential for the storage and germination of future trees, and other seeds. 

Wild Flowers ($20): To promote pollination and overall ecological health, I will also be planting a variety of different wildflowers. By choosing different species with staggered growing seasons, I am hoping to attract more local bee and butterfly populations to the area. 

This is just the first of many projects I plan to put into action in order to revitalize the land and promote a healthy environment for Arkansas' native birds, insects, and mammals. I will be sure to document the process and provide plenty of media in the form of photos, videos, and written information about how it turns out. Thank you for your time and support, either moral or financial.

story:
Climate Impact Network

We are an organization dedicated to empowering the public with respect to climate change action, founded by Alice Zhu, an environment student at the University of Toronto.


We are working on a campaign to fight for a national climate change action plan for Canadians. Our campaign kicks off with a video targeted at voters (regardless of their political preferences) to encourage them to send letters to their Members of Parliament (MPs). The letters are pre-written and will ask their MPs to pledge to:

  • end fossil fuel subsidies
  • put a price on corporate carbon and
  • create a renewable energy plan for Canada.

Your contribution will help with the promotion of our campaign video, spreading awareness about the need to take action on Climate Change. We are aiming to have MPs sign the pledge on climatefast.ca to show their support for our environment by having voters express their concern over this issue. With more than 110 MPs having already pledged their commitment, we are hoping to have a majority of MPs in Parliament to support our cause.

The Impact

CIN strives to increase climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts by the public through our educational and action-oriented events. In the past, the Climate Impact Network has the Sustainable Food Conference at the University of Toronto. We are hoping to reach out to more people by starting a Youth Leadership Program in the Greater Toronto Area and holding another Sustainability Conference April 2015.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in drafting the video, filming the video, doing post-production, or promoting the video, please contact Alice Zhu at alicexia.zhu@mail.utoronto.ca to join the campaign team or visit our website at https://home-cinetwork.rhcloud.com/

story:
After much development we are pleased to bring you the market leading desktop system for producing on demand filament for your Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) 3D printer - the FilaFab Extruder and the FilaFab Filament Winder.

NOW SHIPPING WITH 4 WEEK DELIVERY.  ORDER NOW.

The FilaFab system enables you to produce professional quality filament and spool it ready for printing, all within the confines of your desk/workshop.

NEW EXTRUSION & WINDING SYSTEM OPTIONS



WHY EXTRUDE YOUR OWN?

The benefits of producing your own filament are increasingly well known but if you need convincing here are the highlights:

  • Save over 80% on the cost of ready made filament
  • Recycle old prints and other plastics
  • Experiment with new colours and compounds
  • Extrude ABS, PLA, EVA, HDPE, LDPE and more


WHO?

  • 3D printer hobbyists 
  • Professional print hubs
  • Universities, colleges and schools
  • Architects and designers
  • Prototyping services
  • Filament sellers

...anyone who uses a FFF 3D printer! 

We already have many established users in diverse fields such as:

  • Rapid prototyping department of a major multi-national brand
  • Astronomy research department
  • Pharmaceutical research group
  • Polymer and composites laboratories
  • Arts and design institute
  • Major polymer recycling centres

Content

Contribute and share

To receive a free $25 Amazon gift card in addition to your perk (any over $500), simply follow the instructions below.

1) Share our campaign on Facebook (There is a Facebook share button on the left, or otherwise (http://igg.me/at/filafab/), please use this exact link to share.  

2) Follow us on Facebook (Search for FILAFAB on Facebook and follow us)

3) Screen shot both the above and send it to info@filafab.co.uk from your registered Indiegogo account.  

Referral 

How to Enter:

1) Sign up at Indiegogo.com (signing up is super easy with Facebook),  then LOG-IN to your account.

2) Click and COPY the SHARE link at the FilaFab Campaign Page.

3) Share your unique link on Facebook, Twitter, G+, Pinterest, E-Mail, or anywhere else it might get clicks.

Each time someone clicks your unique link to look at our campaign page, it will count as one referral for you.  For each perk over $500 that is pledged through your referral link you will receive a $25 Amazon gift card.

Terms: This contest may be removed at any time.  Gift cards will only be sent after contributors funds have cleared.


THE FILAFAB SYSTEM

We have worked tirelessly to produce a filament extruder which is robust, reliable, compact and easy to use.  The FilaFab system is the market leading filament extrusion and winding system for the following reasons:

  • 3 years of continuous research and development - ready to go!
  • Industrial design miniaturised for your desktop - a real heavyweight!
  • Easily handles a wide variety of materials - in a league of its own in terms of versatility.
  • Many critical safety features built-in.

1 FilaFab Extruders

We have two versions of the FilaFab Extruder available, the EX100 and EX350.  

EX100

EX100 is the standard model with a compact yet powerful motor drive, ideal for extruding both ABS and PLA and where space is at a premium.

EX350

For those who are serious about recycling or are looking to produce custom batches we would recommend the EX350 model which provides significantly more power and speed to the drive system and also features a speed adjuster.  This means that it can more easily handle some of the other polymers other than ABS and PLA.

Both models have common features which make them stand out from the crowd:

All-Metal Powerful Motor Drive - Consistent power is delivered to the auger through careful motor selection and attention to the drive-train design with dedicated electronics to maintain motor torque and velocity.  Unlike some extruders we have not used any plastic parts.

Force Distribution - Managing the high forces created by the extrusion process has been taken care of by our extra robust steel frame system which enables a high power output within a small form factor.

High Speed - Precision engineering and a heavy duty drive-train combine to provide a high speed extrusion output for a range of materials. Extrude up to an astonishing 1kg of filament per hour.

Tolerance of Filament - Careful nozzle selection and winding speed ensures accurate filament with a high throughput and good tolerance, to rival the best mass produced filament on the market.  Each machine is supplied with 1.75mm and 2.85mm nozzles, other sizes are available.

Variety of Materials - Unlike some other extruders which are limited to certain plastics we have designed FilaFab to handle a vast array of different materials and compounds, including: ABS, PLA, EVA, HDPE, LDPE and more.

Colour Choice - Combine readily available colourants to produce any colour of filament you require.  Try producing filament that changes colour by adding different mixtures at various stages of extrusion.

Safety - The robust design includes many safety features, such as: 

  • Emergency stop button 
  • Auto shutdown on mains failure
  • Fully encased power supply 
  • Nozzle and hopper guards
  • Internal over Voltage and Current protection
  • Steel powder coated enclosure
  • Non slip feet

Aesthetics - Available in blue, black or yellow.

2 FilaFab Filament Winder

Note: Since launch we have made some design changes to the winding system to incorporate a more powerful motor and better spool loading mechanism.  The form factor of the winding system has therefore changed with a slightly taller enclosure, the spool is now positioned to one side and the controls have been moved to the side panel. The optical sensor now comes with a 'filament puller' peripheral which uses a motor to pull the filament to the correct diameter. We will update the photographs soon!

The extruders work without the winder by spooling under gravity however the winder allows for automatic spooling in one easy step and is a great accessory to any extruder.  The use of the winder maximizes the quality of the filament and the ease by which you can transfer filament to your printer.

 The FilaFab Winder comes with some great features:

Consistent Spooling - Digital spool motor control and filament positioning slide provide excellent spool layer build up. An adjustable speed stepper motor controls the horizontal position of the filament.

Easy to Setup - Adjustable end stops provide a quick and easy way to set the spool size, simply adjust to match the width of your spool and let the FilaFab Winder do the rest.

Easy to Use - Changing spools is kept ultra simple due to the rolling bar design which also provides compatibility with the majority of available spools.

Open Source - How the filament is managed after extrusion is important in order to achieve a consistent high quality filament.  For this reason we have built in an open source sensor and accessory system which enables a variety of accessories to be attached to best suit your requirements.  Two rails and a power/communications port are located on the front of the extruder for connecting one or more of the following:

  • Various filament sensors
  • Filament tension controllers
  • Cooling devices such as fans
  • Filament guide wheels

Sensors and accessories and designed to be mounted in printed plastic enclosures to give you the versatility to produce your own and also to modify and upgrade if required.  At the end of the campaign enclosure designs will be made available to freely download and print your own. Alternatively we are offering pre-printed enclosures for you, see reward chart.

We already have two sensors available and are working on some accessories to go along side them.  All files will be available to download after the campaign finishes.

Infrared Sensor - The default sensors are used to automatically control the winding speed.  As filament is extruded it passes by two infrared sensors which are fed to the winding control system. If the filament deviates from the specified path the winder will adjust winding speed to compensate. This ensures that despite the spool's effective diameter changing as more filament is wound the speed remains almost constant, this feedback control loop ensures that the filament is not stretched out of shape while being wound.

Optical Micrometer - We are pleased to make available this precision optical micrometer, designed by Filip Mulier at Objects With Intelligence. The sensor was an obvious choice for our open sensor system by providing a real time width measurement of the extruded filament. Connected via the front panel accessory port the winder automatically detects it and self configures for its use.  The winding of the filament is now automatically controlled to maintain the filament at the required width.  The desired width is set either by the controls on the winding machine or by the soon to be released smartphone app.

Development

We have developed FilaFab over the last three years and it has undergone extensive research, development and prototyping.  We have taken on board feedback from customers of previous versions and the FilaFab offered today is a highly developed market ready machine.

We have a large workshop in Somerset setup with prototyping capabilities which means we have been able to design and test all of the bespoke components.

We have suppliers for all components which we have used before and built up relationships with.  We have all the practical resources to meet your pledges.  Our design aims throughout have been:

  • To produce the best desktop filament extrusion and winding system available. 
  • Attention to detail with exceptional performance. 
  • Safe to use in a variety of environments. 
  • Low cost of ownership. 
  • Quick and easy to use. 
  • Easy to service. 
  • Compatible with future concepts. 
  • Compatible with existing devices. 
  • Rapid extrusion. 
  • Extrude and wind a lot of different materials. 
  • Adaptable.

We pride ourselves on the fact that the FilaFab system is robust and fit for purpose and as mentioned above this has already been endorsed by the market.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

We have spent many months completing the design and pre-production stages for our new desktop extruder and winder combination and are now seeking your help to bring them to market. With your backing we can pay for the initial tooling and minimum order quantities required to get the price to a feasible level. We have a number or rewards with savings of up to 50% compared to our anticipated after launch RRP price.

With enough backers we can get the cost low enough to start delivering our machines to business hubs in developing nations. We want to see local businesses created collecting and recycling plastics to use and resell in a safe and sustainable way. Products can be produced using low cost 3D Printers fed from FilaFab machines. Filament can be sold on for profit or used directly. FilaFab can be taken directly to the point of usage which removes the necessity to transport large volumes of plastics to centralised locations. Another major reason we need your help is for us to develop our our exciting range of FilaFab Peripheral devices and expanded range products, see the What's Next section for more details. Note also that as way of thanks for your amazing support we will be offering supporters special offers and discounts and also order priority.

REWARDS



WHAT'S NEXT?  

We have designed FilaFab EX Extruders and FilaFab Winder to be powerful and fit-for-purpose working together or standalone, but we are also working towards our next generation or FilaFab accessories, upgrades and add-ons which you will be able to take advantage of when released. All backers will receive a supporters discount on these future products to add-on to your extruder or winder.



DELIVERY SCHEDULE

Industrial design miniaturised for your desktop - a real heavyweight!
Easily handles a wide variety of materials - in a league of its own in terms of versatility.
Many critical safety features built-in.

1 FilaFab Extruders
We have two versions of the FilaFab Extruder available, the EX100 and EX350.  
EX100

EX100 is the standard model with a compact yet powerful motor drive, ideal for extruding both ABS and PLA and where space is at a premium.
EX350

For those who are serious about recycling or are looking to produce custom batches we would recommend the EX350 model which provides significantly more power and speed to the drive system and also features a speed adjuster.  This means that it can more easily handle some of the other polymers other than ABS and PLA.
Both models have common features which make them stand out from the crowd:
All-Metal Powerful Motor Drive - Consistent power is delivered to the auger through careful motor selection and attention to the drive-train design with dedicated electronics to maintain motor torque and velocity.  Unlike some extruders we have not used any plastic parts.
Force Distribution - Managing the high forces created by the extrusion process has been taken care of by our extra robust steel frame system which enables a high power output within a small form factor.
High Speed - Precision engineering and a heavy duty drive-train combine to provide a high speed extrusion output for a range of materials. Extrude up to an astonishing 1kg of filament per hour.
Tolerance of Filament - Careful nozzle selection and winding speed ensures accurate filament with a high throughput and good tolerance, to rival the best mass produced filament on the market.  Each machine is supplied with 1.75mm and 2.85mm nozzles, other sizes are available.
Variety of Materials - Unlike some other extruders which are limited to certain plastics we have designed FilaFab to handle a vast array of different materials and compounds, including: ABS, PLA, EVA, HDPE, LDPE and more.
Colour Choice - Combine readily available colourants to produce any colour of filament you require.  Try producing filament that changes colour by adding different mixtures at various stages of extrusion.
Safety - The robust design includes many safety features, such as: 

Emergency stop button 
Auto shutdown on mains failure
Fully encased power supply 
Nozzle and hopper guards
Internal over Voltage and Current protection
Steel powder coated enclosure
Non slip feet

Aesthetics - Available in blue, black or yellow.
2 FilaFab Filament Winder
Note: Since launch we have made some design changes to the winding system to incorporate a more powerful motor and better spool loading mechanism.  The form factor of the winding system has therefore changed with a slightly taller enclosure, the spool is now positioned to one side and the controls have been moved to the side panel. The optical sensor now comes with a 'filament puller' peripheral which uses a motor to pull the filament to the correct diameter. We will update the photographs soon!
The extruders work without the winder by spooling under gravity however the winder allows for automatic spooling in one easy step and is a great accessory to any extruder.  The use of the winder maximizes the quality of the filament and the ease by which you can transfer filament to your printer.


 The FilaFab Winder comes with some great features:

Consistent Spooling - Digital spool motor control and filament positioning slide provide excellent spool layer build up. An adjustable speed stepper motor controls the horizontal position of the filament.

Easy to Setup - Adjustable end stops provide a quick and easy way to set the spool size, simply adjust to match the width of your spool and let the FilaFab Winder do the rest.


Easy to Use - Changing spools is kept ultra simple due to the rolling bar design which also provides compatibility with the majority of available spools.


Open Source - How the filament is managed after extrusion is important in order to achieve a consistent high quality filament.  For this reason we have built in an open source sensor and accessory system which enables a variety of accessories to be attached to best suit your requirements.  Two rails and a power/communications port are located on the front of the extruder for connecting one or more of the following:

Various filament sensors
Filament tension controllers
Cooling devices such as fans
Filament guide wheels


Sensors and accessories and designed to be mounted in printed plastic enclosures to give you the versatility to produce your own and also to modify and upgrade if required.  At the end of the campaign enclosure designs will be made available to freely download and print your own. Alternatively we are offering pre-printed enclosures for you, see reward chart.
We already have two sensors available and are working on some accessories to go along side them.  All files will be available to download after the campaign finishes.

Infrared Sensor - The default sensors are used to automatically control the winding speed.  As filament is extruded it passes by two infrared sensors which are fed to the winding control system. If the filament deviates from the specified path the winder will adjust winding speed to compensate. This ensures that despite the spool's effective diameter changing as more filament is wound the speed remains almost constant, this feedback control loop ensures that the filament is not stretched out of shape while being wound.


Optical Micrometer - We are pleased to make available this precision optical micrometer, designed by Filip Mulier at Objects With Intelligence. The sensor was an obvious choice for our open sensor system by providing a real time width measurement of the extruded filament. Connected via the front panel accessory port the winder automatically detects it and self configures for its use.  The winding of the filament is now automatically controlled to maintain the filament at the required width.  The desired width is set either by the controls on the winding machine or by the soon to be released smartphone app.
Development

We have developed FilaFab over the last three years and it has undergone extensive research, development and prototyping.  We have taken on board feedback from customers of previous versions and the FilaFab offered today is a highly developed market ready machine.
We have a large workshop in Somerset setup with prototyping capabilities which means we have been able to design and test all of the bespoke components.
We have suppliers for all components which we have used before and built up relationships with.  We have all the practical resources to meet your pledges.  Our design aims throughout have been:

To produce the best desktop filament extrusion and winding system available. 
Attention to detail with exceptional performance. 
Safe to use in a variety of environments. 
Low cost of ownership. 
Quick and easy to use. 
Easy to service. 
Compatible with future concepts. 
Compatible with existing devices. 
Rapid extrusion. 
Extrude and wind a lot of different materials. 
Adaptable.

We pride ourselves on the fact that the FilaFab system is robust and fit for purpose and as mentioned above this has already been endorsed by the market.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP
We have spent many months completing the design and pre-production stages for our new desktop extruder and winder combination and are now seeking your help to bring them to market. With your backing we can pay for the initial tooling and minimum order quantities required to get the price to a feasible level. We have a number or rewards with savings of up to 50% compared to our anticipated after launch RRP price.
With enough backers we can get the cost low enough to start delivering our machines to business hubs in developing nations. We want to see local businesses created collecting and recycling plastics to use and resell in a safe and sustainable way. Products can be produced using low cost 3D Printers fed from FilaFab machines. Filament can be sold on for profit or used directly. FilaFab can be taken directly to the point of usage which removes the necessity to transport large volumes of plastics to centralised locations. Another major reason we need your help is for us to develop our our exciting range of FilaFab Peripheral devices and expanded range products, see the What's Next section for more details. Note also that as way of thanks for your amazing support we will be offering supporters special offers and discounts and also order priority.
REWARDS








WHAT'S NEXT?  
We have designed FilaFab EX Extruders and FilaFab Winder to be powerful and fit-for-purpose working together or standalone, but we are also working towards our next generation or FilaFab accessories, upgrades and add-ons which you will be able to take advantage of when released. All backers will receive a supporters discount on these future products to add-on to your extruder or winder.






DELIVERY SCHEDULE

story:
What are we doing?

Urban gardens have so much potential!  They reclaim and purify contaminated land, create vibrant beautiful locations for people to come together, and supply healthy affordable food!   We don't have to sell anyone on the idea of a beautiful, food-producing garden in their neighborhood.  

However, throughout the years we've left behind some substances that aren't the best for human health and have no place in our food. That's where sunflowers come in!

(Helianthus Annus - Sunflower has been proven to remove toxins from the soil)

Along with mustard, amaranth, and a whole host of others, researchers are finding that certain plants will actually soak up toxins right out of the soil.  

Image Source

(Brassica Juncea - Indian mustard has been proven to remove toxins from the soil)

So what we'll be doing is planting a beautiful flower garden and testing the soil and plants as they grow to see how well these plants remove toxins and how quickly we can start growing food!

What We Need & Why

All funding will be used for materials only, no one is getting paid with the dollars you contribute.  

Soil and Plant Tissue Testing - $2,500

We want to test the soil before we plant so we can see how many toxins we're dealing with.  Then we'll be testing the plants throughout the season to see how well each kind removes the toxins, and how safe they are to handle.  We'll be testing the roots, the shoots, and the seeds.  If the seeds don't absorb toxins, but the leaves do, then we get a food crop and clean the soil at the same time!  Finally, after all is said and done, we will test the soil again to see how well the plants were able to reduce the overall contamination.

Land - $1,500

We have located a property and contacted the owner.  This property used to have a home on it, which has since been demolished.  It poses all types of challenges, but these are the typical challenges we will have to face to make way for healthy urban agriculture.

Water - $400

We want to make sure we budget enough for water so we don't dry out the plants.  However we will be heavily mulching with wood chips to conserve as much water as possible.  Wood chips have a miraculous ability to absorb and release water in a very regulated way which helps the plants in time of drought, and reduces the amount of storm water runoff into our sewers.  

Seeds - $200

Obviously we'll need seeds to get started.  We will be buying all heirloom, open-pollinated seeds and "organic" or "sustainable" whenever possible.

Tiller Rental - $100

The land has been nothing but weeds and grass for years now.  We'll need to turn all that over to get started and get seeds into the ground.  But once we have soil to plant into and we mulch over with our covering, we will be practicing "no-till" methods.

$300 - To cover the cost of this awesome crowd-funding website and ensure we get the full funds we need.

The Process

  • Till and test the soil.
  • Mulch the lot and make furrows for the seeds; then water.
  • Test plant tissue in early, mid, and late stages of growth; roots, shoots, and seeds.
  • Determine the fate of the plants according to level of contamination.
  • Re-test soil for overall reduction in contamination.

Hold on, Plants? Cleaning Soil?


Image Source

Yes, it's called "phytoremediation." "Phyto-" as in plants, and "-remediation" as in healing. As you can see in this diagram (click to see larger version), there are a number of ways plants can heal the land.  Sometimes the plant will break down the toxin right there in the ground, other times the plant will literally soak up the toxin into itself.  Then when you harvest the plant, you are removing the toxin with it.

The Environmental Protection Agency has been looking into this technology for a while now.

The Long-Term Vision

Today's common methods for cleaning up contaminated soil are expensive and energy-intensive.  If we are going to reclaim urban land for healthy safe food production, we must find more affordable ways.  

Once our tests demonstrate that the soil is safe for food production we will begin the construction of a food forest.  

If you haven't heard of a food forest check out the Beacon Food Forest in Seattle.

Why couldn't a city be landscaped with food? Public lands, private lands, all growing food providing a living for those who raise the food, and a luscious landscape for those who simply live.  

But ours is not a "communal food" or "communal garden" vision.  To be sure, where there is a garden there is always a surplus of food and we make sure this finds its way to those who need it most.  But these gardens can be incredible tools for empowerment.  We can create jobs with these gardens, clean the soil, and provide our neighborhoods with fresh, healthy, affordable food.

Vacant lots are becoming more and more common, help us make a practical step in the direction of our urban food forest.

Who are we, anyway?

Young Urban Homesteaders purchased it's current location on Nov 9, 2012.  Since then they have transformed the property into food production.  2014 will be their second full season growing for the markets, and with your help will mark the beginning of the second phase: Healing Urban Ground. 

It is the mission of the Plentiful Earth Foundation of Indiana (PEF-IN) to support responsible stewardship of both land and community.  PEF-IN is developing an apprentice program to help those who would like to farm sustainably get on their own two feet.

Healing Urban Ground is a project that supports the vision of both Young Urban Homesteaders and the Plentiful Earth Foundation of Indiana and thus presents an ideal partnership.


Accountability: What happens to my money?

In the event that we do not meet our funding goal, we will continue with planting and as much testing as we can afford.

If you like our project so much that we have a surplus, that money will be reserved by the Plentiful Earth Foundation of Indiana to heal the next property in partnership with whomever might be interested in responsible stewardship of that land. 

All of our receipts and bank statements will be available upon request ~ 

Honesty is our Policy :)

Come on out for our planting day and please share with everyone you know!

Check for updates at facebook.com/YoungUrbanHomesteaders

story:
Pour Arbre-Évolution, l’objectif premier est de positionner les milieux communautaires comme des hôtes d’initiatives de compensation-carbone et de reboisement d'aires dévitalisées. De cette façon, nous croyons qu’en plus de réduire réellement la pollution en assurant la croissance à long terme d’arbres, nous instaurons un dialogue direct de sensibilisation avec les citoyens des communautés. C’est ce dialogue qui nous permet d’éveiller en tout un chacun le rôle du citoyen dans la lutte aux changements climatiques.

Notre participation à la COP21 à Paris sera donc une occasion de créer de nouveaux contacts avec les acteurs investis dans la protection du climat et ceux impliqués au niveau des communautés du Québec et d'ailleurs.  Ces rencontres nous permettrons ensuite d'agir encore plus efficacement avec nos différents programmes de reboisement et de lutte aux changements climatiques.

Le financement demandé servira à concrétiser la délégation de trois personnes à cette rencontre internationale sur le climat. Les sommes amassées serviront à défrayer les coûts des billets d'avion, de l'hébergement et des frais d'inscription.

***Un projet de reboisement dans une communauté sera réalisé au printemps 2016 pour souligner notre participation à la COP21 et pour compenser les émissions de GES engendrées lors des transports des participants.***

Merci de participer à nos efforts pour l'environnement et les communautés.

Pour de plus amples informations sur nos différents programmes et projets, visitez www.arbre-evolution.org

story:
WE DID IT!!! £1,500 raised in total to help find pine marten in Yorkshire. 

Thank you to everyone who helped make it happen.

If you missed the campaign but still want to contribute, you can donate to the project here.

Keep up-to-date with the latest from the project on our website.


As seen on:

          

    

     


UPDATE: We've teamed up with Earth and Nature Ltd to offer 10% off their online eco-shop on all donations over £15!

The pine marten is the second-rarest carnivorous mammal in the UK, and has it's only stronghold in Scotland. It's only ever been pictured once in England, in Staffordshire, 2004.

A member of the mustelid family which includes badgers and otters, it has been called 'Scotland's most beautiful mammal'; and its easy to see why. 

The pine marten is sighted fairly regularly across the North York Moors and a dead marten was actually discovered here in 1993. They are strongly believed to be living here but have never been proven to be. We want to find them.

This is a unique opportunity to help inform conservation and discover more about one of the UK's rarest mammals. 

Photo: Chas Moonie

We want to prove conclusively that these incredibly elusive animals are living right under our noses. We have already been monitoring small areas of North York Moors forests using camera traps, with the help and permission of the Forest Commission, for pine marten - but we need to look deeper. To do that, we need more camera traps. 

And it's not just pine marten's that could turn up on the cameras - we've already uncovered a great variety of often unseen wildlife, such as roe deer and their kids, foxes, badgers, squirrels, many birds, rabbits...

See the latest images from the forest on our recent sightings page...

Pine marten photo: Willie Angus

More camera traps means more dedicated eyes in the forest, watching and waiting for pine marten, 24/7. This will greatly increase the chances of successfully picturing and proving that they are living here. 

The NatureSpy team will place, monitor and collect the camera traps periodically.

The full breakdown of funding is:

  • 6 Bushnell Trail Cameras (model 119476) at approximately £204 each = £1224
  • 6 8gb/16gb SD cards at approximately £10 each = £60
  • 6 metre-long lengths of small chain (to secure cameras to trees and act as theft-deterrent) = £6
  • 6 small padlocks = £17
  • AA batteries = £19.68

  • Indiegogo fee (4%) = £53.07
  • Credit card/Paypal fees = £39.80

Total = £1419.55

Photo: Nevispix

Finding pine marten in this part of the UK will be fantastic news. They are thought to be living here, but confirmation will mean:

  • Focused conservation efforts where pine marten are found
  • We can begin to estimate how many are living here
  • Forest management can be adapted to benefit pine marten
  • Raised awareness of the pine marten's plight and status

The launch of the project featured in The Northern Echo.

We have been using camera traps for many years, developed high levels of expertise and have captured thousands of images of British wildlife. Our goal is to bring people closer to wildlife and make a connection, inspiring people to care about and want to protect the wild places the UK has left. This can be through showing people the unseen wildlife on a nature reserve to the hedgehog in the garden. We work with environmental organisations across the UK. We also run workshops on how camera traps work and can be used in conservation. 

To find out more about what we do, please visit www.naturespy.org.

Any contribution, big or small, is joyfully received and we heartily thank you for your support.

But even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help us (and we'll be very grateful!). Share this campaign via your social networks and help us create a buzz about pine marten and this project!

Photo: Les & Liz Pearce

A massive thank you to the many kind people who gave permission for their brilliant pine marten pictures to be used in this campaign. They are, in no particular order:

Chas Moonie, Les & Liz Pearce, Robert Bannister, Nevispix, Matt Jones, Ros King & Ali Rusbridge, Peter G W Jones, Roger Stewart, Sandra Standbridge, Willie Angus, Brian Dunning, Richard Winn, and Frank Greathead.

Also, a huge thank you to Linda Henshaw for providing her voice-over talent!

We also run workshops on how camera traps work and can be used in conservation.

But even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help us (and we'll be very grateful!). Share this campaign via your social networks and help us create a buzz about pine marten and this project!


Photo: Les & Liz Pearce



A massive thank you to the many kind people who gave permission for their brilliant pine marten pictures to be used in this campaign. They are, in no particular order:
Chas Moonie, Les & Liz Pearce, Robert Bannister, Nevispix, Matt Jones, Ros King & Ali Rusbridge, Peter G W Jones, Roger Stewart, Sandra Standbridge, Willie Angus, Brian Dunning, Richard Winn, and Frank Greathead.

Also, a huge thank you to Linda Henshaw for providing her voice-over talent!

story:
Hey, friends!  

I want to learn to build Earthships.

Earthships are these fabulous carbon-zero, off-the-grid dwellings that architect Michael Reynolds has been building in New Mexico (and elsewhere) for 40 years.

They are made largely of recycled and natural materials (automobile tires, aluminum cans, beetle-killed tree trunks, earthen banks), as well as traditional building materials (wood, glass, concrete).  

They generate their own electricity (with solar panels and windmills), collect their own water (from rain run-off, run through a sophisticated filtration unit), and process their own sewage (into a septic system or dry-composting toilet).  They conserve water by using it 4 times before returning it to the earth.  They are heated and cooled naturally (through an ingenious harmony of design with sunlight and the thermal mass of the earth).  They use no fossil fuels.

Part of the house functions as a greenhouse, growing food for the household.

They cost a fraction of what traditional housing costs to build.  They can be part of a revolution in low-cost housing, and in a greening of the U.S.

Houses like these are already going up in West Philly and Bristol, and I want to help.

But I have to learn how first!  So I need your help in getting to Taos, where I will do an internship this January.

story:
Who is KEEN?

The Kittitas Environmental Education Network (or KEEN for short) has been working to connect our community to nature for nearly 15 years. We started the fantastic Nature of Night event (now run by the University); we created and maintain the annual Get Intimate with the Shrub-Steppe event with expert-led field trips into the surrounding habitat; we are partners in the Yakima River Canyon Scenic Byway (YRCSB) effort; we are leading the campaign to establish a YRCSB Interpretive Center at Helen McCabe Park to share our love and knowledge about the region with visitors and locals alike.

The Project

KEENers fell in love with Helen McCabe Park - which is five miles south of Ellensburg - around 10 years ago. Since then we've secured nearly $300,000 in grant funds to begin restoration of the 64-acre park (it was a gravel mining site used to help construct I-82 in the late 60's). We've planted native trees, shrubs and grasses on nearly 10 acres of the Park to date.

Now we are focusing on the trail system and restoring the area surrounding the 8-acre pond. Trembling or Quaking Aspen (Populous tremuloides) is a fast-growing native tree species that is found down Canyon and establishing a grove of aspen at the Park would be an incredible asset to the Park's ecology and 'sense of place'.

Why Grow an Aspen Grove?

Aspens are COOL! Did you know that aspen propagates itself primarily through root sprouts? Extensive and wide-ranging clonal colonies are common. Each colony is its own clone, and all trees in the clone have identical characteristics and share a single root structure. All trees in a given clonal colony are considered part of the same organism. How cool is that?! We need to plant a lot of trees to ensure a colony can become established.

Aspen groves are very special places...as the name implies when the wind blows (and it blows a lot in Ellensburg!) the leaves 'tremble' and 'quake' with a sound like waves upon the ocean. The colors are magical in the fall and the trees looks mysterious and striking in the fogs of winter. Birds are happy and protected in groves, deer can hide in them, and walking through them in any season is a truly otherworldly experience. 

The Impact

KEENers are good at planting trees, we're good at keeping them alive, we're good at restoring ecosystems, and we're especially great at sharing all that good stuff with our community. And we love Helen McCabe Park and want everyone to fall in love with it as well. The Aspen Grove will be an incredible asset to the Park, to the Community and to our Region. Every tree counts - literally! - so won't you help us create a special place and Grow the Grove?

story:
Short Summary

Fifty years from now, every American home will be using biogas. It is the simplest form of truly renewable energy of all to produce and one of the biggest no-brainers since fire and the wheel. There are no technical reason every home in the world is not already using biogas other than most people simply do not know about it. Education is the key. 

We are seeking to raise funds to place home biogas units Made in the USA using recycled materials by Hestia Home Biogas at select non-profit educational sites  where they may be visited by the public and utilized by educators to provide students with hands-on experience operating small scale biodigesters and using biogas.  

We can add installations for every $3,000 we raise, beginning with the Greenburgh Nature Center in Scarsdale, New York. The first five proposed sites are...

  • Greenburgh Nature Center, Scarsdale, New York
  • Mud Creek Farm permaculture demonstration site, Hudson, NY
  • Rooftop garden of national magazine, Washington DC.
  • Global Vertical Farms, Philadelphia area, Pennsylvania




The thought-provoking renewable natural gas symbol was developed for the Biogas Education Network crowdfunding campaign, and we hope it becomes adopted as the international symbol for renewable natural gas. For perks, we are offering bumper stickers, coffee mugs and t-shirts with this original logo.

For the ladies, we are offering the fun sweatpants with 'Got Biogas?' on the back at the $75 level. The perfect Christmas present! 


The Impact


At this time few people recognize the game changing impact biogas will have in the future, making grant funding and other contributions difficult to raise and support from government or established non-profit organizations is non-existent. We hope these high--profile installations will generate enough interest in home scale biogas for public officials and those in decision-making positions within their organizations take notice.

Contributing to this campaign, you really can help change the world for the better!

If you can't contribute to the campaign, please use the social media share buttons on this page to spread the word throughout your network and be sure to follow our progress!

story:
Understanding Climate, Wildlife and Ourselves

Do you care about our future?  Are you frustrated with politics that overwhelm data?  Do you feel like you just can't get the inside scoop on science?  Yeah.  We get that.  And that is what our trip is all about.  My name is Todd Levine and I am working with a small group of students to help them to see the world and to get involved in something bigger than any of us. 

Climate change is an all-encompassing topic in our world, in science and in politics.  It can be really hard to see.  Does a warm summer mean that the climate is warming?  Or does a cool one mean that the global warming is a scam?  A common claim is that changes that can be seen, measured and recorded are happening at the poles; that changes in our climate might be easier to see there.  Let's go.  We're going to meet with the scientists that make these claims, learn the details of how they put together predictions from observations and data.  And we will speak to the people watching the poles, Inuit, scientists and other inhabitants of this stark and beautiful place.  Maybe we'll even ask the bears.

We all need to understand science.  None of us can be a responsible citizen without at least a basic understanding of science.  No science, no data can tell us what we should do.  But, science can tell us what we must do to achieve certain outcomes.  We have to decide whether the data are convincing.  We have to decide what it is worth to ensure particular futures.  That's what students will learn on this trip.  I will challenge those who believe in climate change to examine why and will challenge students who don't believe in climate change to explain why not.  We will move beyond politics and beliefs; we will see what all the fuss is about and shape our own opinions.

I have been working in science for over a decade, struggling to push forward, to create new knowledge and to help people understand science. I have taught to many audiences, formal and informal, from kindergarten to retired adults.  I earned my PhD at Miami University in Ohio and am currently teaching for the University of Wisconsin system.  I maintain strong ties with Hancock Biological Station in western Kentucky, which is part of Murray State University.  Much of my own research is not about climate change, but is framed by it.  So, I have a responsibility to not believe in climate change, but to critically examine the data and understand the whys and wherefores too. 

Support a student; make this trip possible - live vicariously or come with us.

Just like me, when I took a similar, life-altering trip to Churchill, many of the students participating have limited access to financial support.  There are many reasons for this; some come from families without much money, some are supporting families of their own, some have had bad luck...everyone deserves a chance to do something epic at least once in their lives.  This is more than epic, it means something.  It gives students direct access to the information that scientists use to learn about climate.  It also gives them a chance to see animals that barely fit into zoos and that they might never be able to see in captivity or otherwise. 

When I went to Churchill, I was helped by the organization with which I traveled, the Great Bear Foundation.  But I was also helped by my fellow students.  To this day, I don't know where they came up with the money, but they collected it through what we might call...primitive crowdsourcing...and helped me cover the difference between what I could afford and what I needed.  I want to do for my students as my peers did for me.  In some ways, that is very literal.  Similar trip, same location...I hope that it makes the impression on them that it did on me!

Why does this matter?  Students will emerge from this experience better prepared to participate in and change our world.  Where ever they come from, whatever age, regardless of political background or preference, students will know more.  They will be equipped with data.  They will have read the original sources.  They will be ready to help others make responsible decisions, based on evidence and to separate data from opinion.  They will be ready to separate goals from information and will be ready to move in our world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't give today.  Maybe you struggle to make enough to cover bills too, just like my students and just like me.  Help us reach out.  Help us tell the world about this.  Pass this project along.  Help someone see this who wouldn't otherwise.  And help make sure that this class runs, join it or recommend it to friends.
