story:
Our Story

SCRAP-Denton is a sponsored project of SCRAP.  SCRAP is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit arts and environmental organization with a mission to inspire creative reuse and environmentally sustainable behavior by providing educational programs and affordable materials to the community.

We are starting a SCRAP Denton and we NEED YOUR HELP!!!

Denton is an ideal city for a creative reuse center. We are a community of artists, students, educators, and idealists alike. Our families and friends have a vision of a sustainable and progressive way of life.

SCRAP Denton retail center will be located just off the square, (215 W. Oak St. Denton, TX) and will sell all kinds of reuse materials for arts and crafts, plus school, office, and party supplies. We will accept donations of creative materials during regular store hours, so our inventory will change constantly and you will never know what you’re going to find! What do you think you will find? What will you make of it?


The Impact

Everybody benefits from SCRAP, local community, state, nation, world and future by filling minds rather than landfills! With the materials we collect we will be providing supplies at affordable prices and educating through outreach programs and workshops all while reducing waste. SCRAP Denton will also be offering a common place for artists, students, educators and other local non-profits to have studio, gallery and work space  for low cost rent!

In 2010 SCRAP in Portland, Oregon was able to divert over 103 tons of reusable arts, crafts and educational materials from their local landfills! We plan to do the same in Denton.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $12,000 to get started, this money will allow us to open our doors and provide educational opportunities in our classroom space, offer the opportunities for reuse artists to have a venue to show and share their art, and for community members to have a place to both donate and purchase the wonderful materials and supplies we will have available. The Creative Reuse Center will host many downtown and community wide events that promote and further our mission of reuse for both adults and children. As a startup donor we have a few perks for different levels of donation.


You Can Help!

We Can NOT open this community store without start up funding!!! 

Spread our message to all your contacts, we have just 60 days to raise funds.

Like us on Facebook!

We are also in need of volunteers during the week and on weekends. 

THANK YOU!!!
story_txt:
Our Story

SCRAP-Denton is a sponsored project of SCRAP.  SCRAP is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit arts and environmental organization with a mission to inspire creative reuse and environmentally sustainable behavior by providing educational programs and affordable materials to the community.

We are starting a SCRAP Denton and we NEED YOUR HELP!!!Denton is an ideal city for a creative reuse center. We are a community of artists, students, educators, and idealists alike. Our families and friends have a vision of a sustainable and progressive way of life.SCRAP Denton retail center will be located just off the square, (215 W. Oak St. Denton, TX) and will sell all kinds of reuse materials for arts and crafts, plus school, office, and party supplies. We will accept donations of creative materials during regular store hours, so our inventory will change constantly and you will never know what you’re going to find! What do you think you will find? What will you make of it?




The Impact

Everybody benefits from SCRAP, local community, state, nation, world and future by filling minds rather than landfills! With the materials we collect we will be providing supplies at affordable prices and educating through outreach programs and workshops all while reducing waste. SCRAP Denton will also be offering a common place for artists, students, educators and other local non-profits to have studio, gallery and work space  for low cost rent!In 2010 SCRAP in Portland, Oregon was able to divert over 103 tons of reusable arts, crafts and educational materials from their local landfills! We plan to do the same in Denton. 




What We Need & What You Get


We need $12,000 to get started, this money will allow us to open our doors and provide educational opportunities in our classroom space, offer the opportunities for reuse artists to have a venue to show and share their art, and for community members to have a place to both donate and purchase the wonderful materials and supplies we will have available. The Creative Reuse Center will host many downtown and community wide events that promote and further our mission of reuse for both adults and children. As a startup donor we have a few perks for different levels of donation. 





You Can Help!
We Can NOT open this community store without start up funding!!! 

Spread our message to all your contacts, we have just 60 days to raise funds.

Like us on Facebook!

We are also in need of volunteers during the week and on weekends. 
THANK YOU!!!

story:
From April 4th to 6th, 300 students from over 75 colleges and universities from across the United States and Canada will gather at San Francisco State University for the 2nd annual student-led Fossil Fuel Divestment Convergence.

At the first divestment convergence at Swathmore College in 2013, students began to discuss and strategize about the role of the campus fossil fuel divestment campaign in moving forward for climate justice. The Fossil Fuel Divestment Student Network was created, and numerous regional networks were created or strengthened out of the gathering.

Divest Dal seeks the value in being part of strengthening the power of the continent-wide student movement, and becoming more connected to more regional networks, while also seeing the network grow in geographic reach.

While 9 campuses have committed to full or partial fossil fuel divestment, administrative resistance remains at many institutions. In the event that our own institution resists divestment, we want to be prepared to escalate our campaign. The first way to do this is by coalition-building and direct action, gaining attention nationwide with sit-ins, petitions, rallies, public art displays, referenda, and growing alumni and faculty support.

This convergence is designed to be the spark that carries the momentum of 2013 into 2014. In order to confront the overwhelming crisis of climate change, we must not only build our organizing skills and leadership, but also build relationships and coalitions with others fighting the same forces; all of which is part of the founding principles of the convergence. Fossil fuel divestment is just one piece of taking on the fossil fuel industry, and will ground our conversations in the role of the divestment campaign in the larger Climate Justice movement.

If you can, please help to support the Divest Dal Delegation. Insodoing, you will be helping to help the campaign here in Halifax, and also contribute to the widespread movement of divestment from the fossil fuel industry!

story:
Why should you care?

Rusinga Island is a poignant example of unsustainable resource usage and its devastating effects. This small island ecosystem in Lake Victoria, Kenya, has failed to manage its natural resources in light of an exploding human population.

Rusinga Island was once a bird watchers paradise, called the ‘Green Island’. Covered in tall indigenous trees, it was a haven for unique bird species and nurtured wild leopards and hyenas. Today, the forest lays destitute.  Large parts of the hills have eroded as a fast growing human population has tried to eke out a living on the already scarce resources.

Rusinga is home to the Kenyan Luo tribe, who are traditionally fishermen. A decline in fisheries has prompted tribesmen to explore other ways of producing an income, such as tree cutting for firewood or charcoal making. Many also try their hand at farming. However, with no knowledge base of sustainable farming methods and unpredictable rainfall due to climate change, the results are poor harvests, hunger and degradation of livelihoods. The result is more poverty.

Catalyzing Change

We work with Rusinga Island Organic Farmers Association (RIOFA), a group of small-holder farmers and graduates of our permaculture course. RIOFA encompasses 21 farmers who are, in turn, representatives of eight self-help, women’s and youth groups with a total of 194 members.

ROIFA’s tenet: Grow sustainable livelihoods whilst regenerating the degraded environment on Rusinga. RIOFA wants to become model farmers and peer educators for their community. Its members want to demonstrate that a prolific permaculture farm can generate a good income and simultaneously an abundant life and environment.  

We have supported RIOFA with basic permaculture training and with administrative set-up. Now, ROIFA needs YOUR help to meet next year’s aims:

  • Establish sustainable water harvesting and irrigation systems for each farm

  • Expand permaculture knowledge base on soils, water, intercropping and pest management

  • Train in organic certification

  • Learn about market access, record keeping and financial management

  • Identify and trial crops for international organic and health products market


With YOUR help, RIOFA and PRI-Kenya will be able to spread permaculture knowledge with the aim to establish food security and stable livelihoods throughout the island’s 35,000 inhabitants and beyond!


Help Us Support RIOFA “GO BOOM!”

Our Goal: Raise USD 15,000 to support RIOFA’s 2014 aims outlined above. Funds secured through this campaign will be used to:

  1. Offer workshops in permaculture, group development, organic certification and market access;

  2. Create a farmer-/community- lead strategy to address uncontrolled grazing;

  3. Offer one-on-one farmer support through farm visits by one of our permaculture trainers to help them develop their farm into a model farm; and

  4. Support each farm with rainwater harvesting systems and agriculture tools.

Rusinga Island is PRI-Kenya’s first long-term community project. We are immensely proud of what our partnership has achieved despite limited funds. YOUR SUPPORT will help RIOFA members take the next step towards their goal of becoming self-sufficient, organic-certified farmers, while helping their community to do the same!


Julie’s Story

Julie is a member of RIOFA. In the last seven months since her training commenced, Julie has implemented a kitchen garden that is a testament to what can be achieved with permaculture methods.

Julie’s husband died in 2002, leaving her with a shell of a house. With no money or support from her family, Julie was unable to finish constructing her house. To this day her house has no roof or windows. She has only managed to cover one room with some odd bits of tin roof weighed down by some stones, within which currently lives and cooks.

We would like to dedicate extra funds raised above our target to a fund a roof and some windows for Julie’s house. With a roof over her head, we would significantly uplift her living standard AND provide Julie with a source of rental income by hiring her extra rooms as accommodation for trainers and volunteers working on projects in the area.


Who is PRI-Kenya?

PRI-Kenya (Permaculture Research Institute of Kenya) was established in 2011 as a response to a growing interest in permaculture as an effective tool to address the chronic issues of food and nutritional insecurity, climate change and environmental degradation in East Africa. We are a small, dynamic and endlessly enthusiastic team with joint expertise in the practice and implementation of permaculture and sustainable community development projects within Kenya and internationally.


Why Permaculture?

Imagine a world where humans are harmoniously integrated with their environment. In this world there are sustainable systems to provide for human needs of food, shelter and energy, whilst producing an abundance of food and protecting biodiversity and wildlife. Permaculture is a tool that helps create such systems. It does so by carefully observing the environment, using low-cost, low-input techniques that mimic natural ecosystem processes. It is a tool that emphasizes a bottom-up approach to knowledge and innovation. Farmers are encouraged to use creative thinking to create their own solutions, suitable to their context. This makes permaculture not only a tool for efficient land-use management but also a tool for empowerment.


“It's the little things citizens do.
That's what will make the difference.
My little thing is planting trees.”
~Wangari Maathai

story:
H.O.O.P.ing it up: Help Our Organic Production! 
Together we can build a new HOOP house to extend the growing season at EarthDance!

Who are we?
EarthDance is a non-profit organization operating an Organic Farm School in St. Louis, Missouri. Founder Molly Rockamann, sometimes known as the hula hooping farmer. created EarthDance in 2008 on Missouri's oldest organic farm. Established in 1883 by the Mueller family. Molly saw a need to preserve this peri-urban farm and so she formed EarthDance’s Organic Farm School, using the Mueller Farm as a vibrant hub for agricultural education, collaboration, and celebration. Until last year, EarthDance had been on a one year lease, unable to make significant changes or upgrades to the farm. But in 2012, EarthDance reached its goal of saving the farm by purchasing the land with the help of partners and is placing a conservation easement upon the property to ensure that it will stay farmland into perpetuity. EarthDance's mission is to sustainably grow food, farmers, and community, one small farm at a time, through hands-on education and delicious experiences.

 

About the project:
A major component of what EarthDance does is our nationally-recognized Organic Farming Apprenticeship Program, which educates beginning farmers in the skills of sustainable agriculture from seed to market. By putting up a hoop house here at EarthDance we will not only be able to grow food year-round, but also train 25 other farmers every year on how to extend the growing season. Imagine the impact this could have on our local food economy!

So, what is a hoop house? A hoop house is a structure similar to a greenhouse that allows for extending the growing season by providing an environment crops can grow in during the winter months. It gets its name from the half-round “hoop” shape that covers the garden beds. For EarthDance, having a hoop house will allow us to use it as a learning tool for our farmers-in-training.

EarthDance will also host a workshop on how to build the hoop house, create a video, and then post it for all to use. This education becomes invaluable not only to farmers, but to everyone who wants to eat local, even when it’s cold outside!

What We Need & What You Get

The funding will cover:

  • Hoop house structure 30’x 48’ high tunnel frame kit
  • Plastic sheathing
  • Drip irrigation
  • Endwalls
  • Basic ventilation package including manual roll-up sidewall ventilation & manual butterfly peak vents
  • Additional bracing kits for a moveable structure
  • Repair tape
  • Experienced construction crew leader
  • Costs of hosting a weekend-long workshop
  • Creation of instructional video

We've already received financial support through EQIP (Environmental Quality Incentives Program) from Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS), but we need your help to bridge the gap! Even if we don’t reach our goal, we will still use what money we do get to purchase a smaller version of the hoop house, or one that is stationary.   

The Impact
New farmers, growing skills, appreciation for gardening and farm equipment, friendships, flowers, herbs, young people’s understanding of where food comes from, compost, an awareness of nature, confidence, a sense of belonging, food, community…these are things EarthDance is growing… with your support!

Other Ways You Can Help
We at EarthDance love all of our supporters! Even if you're not able to make a financial contribution, you can help us spread the word through word of mouth, Facebook, Youtube, and Twitter. You can also volunteer on the farm or at an event, or donate an item on our wish list.  Share the links and the love below and that will make a huge difference.

story:
Down to the Wire

You have $5, $10, $20, $50 to spend today. Coffee? A movie? dinner out? A concert? Tomorrow all you will have left of that money is a memory. You could do something radical instead. You could help change the world. 
You could encourage innovation and development of sustainable farming techniques to deal with a changing climate. You could make sure that hundreds more people of all ages and interests have the opportunity to learn gardening, farming, and sustainable life skills. Together with similar donations from others, and the huge discount the seller has offered, your money can do a lot of good for a long time.
How do I know this? Because it's already working. This campaign has already succeeded, in many ways. In addition to the money raised by here, there have been several independent contributions, and generous private lenders have come forward to put up the balance of the $25,000. People from across the US and Canada have joined local friends to make sure Pinwheel continues. And the seller has given us additional time to finalize the pay-off arrangements.
 So donate more. Donate anyway. Because it says you value the farm, about healthy food, and about the environment. The smaller the loan we need, the better off the farm will be going forward. But most important, your support of this campaign...even a $5 donation...is a tangible reminder that I am not alone in this effort to preserve precious farmland. And that is priceless.
So please...for this last weekend...donate to the campaign...share it far and wide...and keep PInwheel in your thoughts and prayers. 

Short Summary

The seller will cancel over $30,000 of the farm's debt if I put $25,000 in his hands by December 8 October 8. The entire farm (except for the separate, adjacent rental Farmhouse) will have a clear title, and the 3 separate parcels can be joined as one. This will free me and the farm to make even greater contributions to our community. Pinwheel isn't just about producing sheep and veggies, it's also about teaching skills, preserving the ecosystem, sharing nature, and fostering spiritual growth to benefit everyone.

Not-So-Short Summary

18 years ago, I bought a barren 10-acre cornfield behind my house to save it from becoming a warehouse. Since then I've worked relentlessly to create a sustainable sheep and vegetable farm right on the city limits of Lawrence, KS, with some of the best soil in the  world and the Kansas River flowing close beneath it (learn more at Pinwheel's website and blog). About 6 years ago, I entered into a contract to buy an adjacent acre (comprising 3 parcels) that will complete the farm with essential street frontage, a well-built metal barn for the sheep, a lovely grove of trees that the seller's sons planted in the 1960s, and a small house that I've been renovating for 3 years on a shoestring budget.

Now I'm facing one of my biggest challenges yet, and you can help. A series of misfortunes (see * in "HISTORY, THE SHORT VERSION" at the end of this article if you want more details on "how things came to be this way") has put me in dire financial straits. However, the seller of the acre has made the generous offer to discount the contract by more than half--IF I pay him $25,000 by December 8 October 8. 

(Find "Pinwheel Farm" on FaceBook if you want to message me with questions.) 

Your immediate generous contribution will help pay this final "ransom" so that the farm will be free to be a farm forever. And it will forever be, in part, YOUR farm, and our descendents' farm. Every contributor will be honored on our "Helping Hands" display (see Perks). When my stewardship is over, the farm will pass to others who will carry on my work to build and protect it. It will never be sold.

MORE ABOUT ME: As well a farmer, I'm a writer, artist, song-writer, inventor, mender-and-fixer, penny-pincher, volunteer coordinator, sustainable liver, researcher, teacher, spiritual pilgrim, grandmother, generous human being, good listener, and a whole lot more. I have a BS in Human Resource Management from Friends University, but that's nothing compared to the hands-on learning that life has brought me through voluntary service, friends, family, mentors, and other "classrooms" too numerous to mention. The farm is my way of passing on to others the skills and knowledge that so many have generously shared with me over the years.

What We Need

You're wondering--The seller wants $25,000; I'm asking for $35,000. What's up with that? The extra $10,000 ensures that the fees and taxes for this fundraising effort can be paid, in addition the contract buy-out. 

Any funds left after I pay the $25,000 and all fees and taxes will go first towards 2013 property taxes on all the farm's land. 

Additional funds (we'd love to get more than $35,000!) will go towards basic farm infrastructure improvements such as finishing the new veggie washhouse, cold storage for our veggies, sheep barn improvements (including small-scale milking facilities),  completing the new water well and well house for the farm, ADA accessible toilet facilities, and off-grid energy projects (not necessarily in that order). All funds will go towards debt retirement or lasting improvements on the farm, not operating or personal expenses.

If this campaign doesn't reach its goal, every penny left after the Indiegogo fee is paid will go towards the $25,000 contract buyout. Meanwhile, I'm working hard to find other sources of loans and donations to bridge any gap. We can do this! We WILL do this!

I want to assure you that I do not own land to profit from its resale. It's my "retirement plan", but not because I'll cash it in and move to a retirement home. It will be my pantry and my place to live for the rest of my life. Although I'll have title to the land, it will continue to own me--I am its steward, not its master. I will do everything I can to ensure that it will never be sold again, so that it will be available to future generations to continue farming without going through the years of debt and overwork that I've endured. It will be free to be a farm.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can make a short-term low/no-interest loan, please contact me immediately!

I know (because I'm there myself) that sometimes there just isn't a dollar to spare, no matter how important the cause. You can still help in so many ways, and still be a "Helping Hand"!

  • First and foremost, make this campaign viral! Share this campaign with everyone you can think of, via FaceBook, Twitter, email, or any way you can. Use the Indiegogo "share tools". Ask your friends and family to share it with their friends and family. Reach out to groups and strangers that you think share our values and long-term goals.
  • Keep me, the farm, the Embers family, our donors and other benefactors, and this campaign in your thoughts and prayers. 
  • Send me encouraging words via FaceBook, email, a postcard (if you know what those are), or the phone.
  • Contribute in-kind to the farm so that I can use all cash resources for the Big Payment. Groceries, gasoline, other basic necessities are all appreciated.
  • Volunteer at the farm if you are local and have time/energy. This campaign takes time away from the farm, and the farm still needs a lot of work to recover from this spring's upheaval.

What You Get

You'll become a member of Pinwheel Farm's Community of Life, forever! No matter how small your donation, you'll be honored on the Helping Hands wall of the Brown Barn. We'll list you as a donor on Pinwheel's website (unless you want to remain anonymous, or make a donation in honor of someone else). You'll be a Pinwheel VIP! Hopefully you'll be able to visit the farm in person and enjoy its quiet beauty, yummy veggies, entertaining animals, fascinating wildlife, and interesting people.

Moderate (by my pinch-penny standards) donations will get you great Pinwheel Farm products, discounts, and promotional items...there's something for everyone.

Larger donations will get you even more wonderful perks. By sponsoring a sheep or a tree, you'll feel a very special, unique connection with the farm for years to come. Participating in special events at the farm will bring you and your friends even closer to the farm's Community of Life.

Want to donate, don't see a perk that appeals to you, and have an idea for something else I could offer? Contact me!

The Impact

Paying off this contract will have far-reaching benefits beyond me and the farm. 

The farm will be able to support itself, me, and others as well. I'll be free to increase my mission to teach farming and sustainable living skills to people of all ages; continue developing special low-input gardening methods to ensure future food production "no matter what"; breed low-maintenance sheep that provide meat, wool and milk with just pasture and hay; enrich others' lives with opportunities to experience the natural ecosystem that's replaced the once-barren cornfield; welcome visitors to explore and relax in this rural haven that's just 3 blocks from a city transit route; navigate the challenges of an increasingly unstable climate; write about and photograph the wonders and lessons of the farm and share them through blogs and booklets.

The farm and its vast, complex Community of Life will be safe from nearly all risk of development. As of 2000, we had identified nearly 500 naturally-occuring species of living things here; I know there are hundreds more by now. We see new ones every year. The trees will continue to benefit our entire community through shade, screening of industrial areas, air purification, oxygen production, and more. Myriad bird species will sing, forage, raise their families, migrate through. The rich diversity of insects will thrive in a healthier balance each year. Frogs, turtles, snakes, foxes, and many other animals will delight us with their presence.

We live in a world in crisis, with increasing CO2 levels, unstable global weather patterns, GMOs, bee die-offs, Fukushima radiation headed this way, water shortages, worsening economy, etc. Pinwheel has been designed since its very beginning to make a positive difference in our environment, both ecological and social.

Pinwheel provides:

Food security, in so many ways--With the help of so many mentors and volunteers, I grow healthy, nutritious food with a minimum of off-farm inputs, using a minimum of fossil fuels. We sell it directly to eaters whenever possible. We make generous donations to local food banks (Just Foods). We grow more and more of our own seed. We provide perennial plant starts to others. We teach farming and gardening skills and knowledge, and even food storage and preparation ideas. We answer questions, we coach, we mentor. Relentlessly, whenever we are called to do so.

An ark for many creatures--It's been amazing to watch the ecology of the farm become more diverse every year as the formerly plowed land recovers a natural balance. We try to be attentive to the needs of our precious pollinator friends by managing crops, pasture, and fallow areas especially for bees, butterflies, and other beneficials. This means the farm isn't always as tidy as it could be...but we are well compensated by the beauty of our non-human residents and visitors.

Sustainable farming research and development--My farming methods have been developed through on-farm experiments and observations as well as continuing education opportunities and extensive reading. I continue to refine these techniques and systems to reduce the environmental impact of food production at Pinwheel, while improving yields. My methods are guided by this particular microclimate and soil, but also influenced by permaculture principles and farming/gardening greats such as Joel Salatin, Helen and Scott Nearing, Ruth Stout, Gene Logsdon, Masanobu Fukuoka, Wes Jackson, and many others.  Key areas of ongoing experimentation include use of natural plant-based mulches to manage soil moisture, temperature and fertility; techniques for producing vegetables in an extreme climate without irrigation; and use of Mulberry trees as a drought-tolerant sheep forage to replace soon-to-be-GMO alfalfa.

Freedom of information--We don't charge for sharing what we've learned, because so many people have been so generous in sharing their knowledge with me throughout the years. Workshops and seminars are presented on a donation basis. The farm would not exist today without the tireless help of many mentors and consultants who asked only that I share what they gave me. I ask only that those who come to the farm to learn will teach others in the same way. By spreading knowledge freely, we all benefit.

Sustainable life training--So many basic daily skills that I learned as a child or even later in life are all but lost to today's younger generations. Yet some of these skills may be essential to coping with today's changing climate and economy. I'm committed to passing on the things I've learned over the years, like efficient clothesline use, making homemade soap, sweeping a rug, using human powered tools, and keeping house without toxic chemicals.

Opportunities--I try to meet each person where they're at, and help them towards their spiritual and sustainable living goals. If someone is drawn to the farm, I try to find a way for them to make a positive difference. Both on and off the farm, I've worked for many years with people with diverse lifestyles, identities, beliefs, and abilities. I learn and grow from everyone who chooses to participate in the farm, even if it's just a quick visit; it's always a two-way street.

"Farmercise"--Volunteering at the farm is a great affordable alternative to going to the gym, and has many additional social and physical benefits. Volunteers enjoy the serenity of the farm, fresh air, sunshine, and activities to fit a wide range of abilities and interests. The sense of community gained from working together with others to complete a task contributes to a sense of well-being and self-esteem. 

Spiritual retreat--Pinwheel is a place to put the rat race at arm's length for an hour or a day, and heal our spirits through connecting with nature. There are special places around the farm set aside especially for meditation, or people can find their own special spot. All faiths are welcome here. 

Local regulatory and policy development--My consulting background (DPRA Incorporated, 1987 - 1992) prepared me well for this particular farm and community. I was involved in the development of Lawrence's Natural Landscaping Ordinance and regulations allowing backyard poultry, as well as Douglas County's Agritourism regulations, and the City/County Northeast Sector Plan. In 2009, I was honored at the Pioneers of Local Foods event for helping open the way for locally grown meat to be sold at the DowntownLawrence Farmer's Market (blog article on Pioneers of Local Foods). 

Carbon sequestration--We maintain a very small carbon footprint through energy conservation. We also incorporate many practices that maximize carbon sequestration at the farm, including permanent pasture and tree plantings, use of wood chips instead of gravel for lanes and paths, and natural decomposition of brush piles instead of burning.

I could go on, but you get the idea. Pinwheel is pretty amazing, and pretty complex.

History, the Short Version

My current situation didn't just happen out of nowhere, either the blessings or the challenges. Like the scarab in the video, I've been hard at it for a long time, learning and working:

1960 (age 3): First accurate bird ID ("Mommy, mommy, there really IS a Tufted Titmouse in that tree down the path!") marks the beginning of my lifetime love affair with "God and Mother Nature". 1975: I have a vision of a small farm, simple lifestyle, sheep. 1978-1995: Don't think I'd ever be able to achieve that dream, but keep finding little pieces of the puzzle along my life journey. 

1992: Design the imaginary "Pinwheel Farm" as a paper for a Vegetable Crop Production class in college. 1994: Move to Lawrence and marry; buy what is now the Pinwheel Farmhouse along with another house that we rented out. 1995: Neighbor offers to sell us the 10 acres behind us. We cash in everything we have to buy it (I now own it free and clear). 1996: A series of serendipitous connections brings me sheep, then a Border Collie, then a guardian llama. I realize God has commissioned me to build a modern-day "Noah's Ark"--a place of refuge for the natural Community of Life displaced by surrounding urban development. 

*Misfortunes begin: 1997: Devastating fire at our tenant's house. 1998: Divorce. 2001-2003: "Friend" leaves me with significant credit card debt. 

*Misfortunes continue: 2004-6: Tenants renting the farm/farmhouse during my sabbatical trash the house and cause over $23,000 damages to farm infrastructure, putting me deeper in debt. Meanwhile, the voluntary service agency I'm working through suffers an internal upheaval and "fires" me, leaving me homeless and jobless in Canada (I had a great time anyhow!). More debt accrues. 2006: Back at the farm, I drive a transit bus full-time while rebuilding the farm and paying off debts. 2007: Another neighbor offers to sell me, on contract, the acre next door--a great opportunity, but more debt. 2007-2010: Keep driving the bus (great Lawrence Journal World article and video about my double life as a farmer/bus driver), pay down debts, build the farm, operate the farm. 2010- 2012: Farm is back on track; suddenly it's time to start renovating the little house--including structural work and a whole new plumbing system that I design and build myself. 

*Big season of misfortunes: April 2012: When we should be doing spring planting, the farmhouse well which supplies the whole farm fails, and my apprentices and I spend a month dealing with extremely limited water while rebuilding the entire well/pump system ourselves. Early May 2012: Worst lambing season ever, with deformed lambs and lots of bottle babies requiring round the clock care. Veterinary mystery--possible new virus due to climate change? Late May 2012: Fired for making a split-second decision to not risk lives; denied unemployment. I decide to keep my commitments to apprentices who are living at the farm rent-free in exchange for learning and working; no rent to help pay the bills = more debt. Summer 2012: Record high temperatures and extreme drought reduced farm income; hay prices sky rocket. Fall 2012: Both apprentices drop out before the end of the season, leaving me unexpectedly short handed.

*Even bigger misfortune: November 2012: New tenant/co-farmer makes a commitment to jointly operate the farm with me for the rest of my life. Winter 2013: We plan the partnership, start rearranging the farm as a two-person enterprise, and jump through a bunch of regulatory hurdles to get permits for new infrastructure. May 2013: Co-farmer gives 24 hours notice for ceasing all farm involvement and breaks lease on farmhouse right in the middle of spring planting, before rebuilding infrastructure we've taken down, and takes most of the seeds and seed potatoes we were about to plant. Summer 2013: Full-blown financial crisis results when I can't find new tenant for the Farmhouse. 

Moving forward: The Pinwheel Farmhouse suddenly has wonderful new tenants as of Sept. 1, significantly stabilizing the farm's financial situation. This incredibly energetic family of 4 plans to be a long-term part of Pinwheel. Unexpectedly, the Embers family offered to generously discount the remaining debt on the acre (the woods, the small house, and the brown barn) if I can pay them $25,000 by October 8, 2013. 

Now: Here's where you come into the picture. It can be your farm, too. You can be part of the Pinwheel story. Just make a donation and pick a perk!

Thanks for Reading This!

Thanks for thinking about Pinwheel Farm for these few minutes. I hope you'll continue thinking about us, visit us, be part of us. Find us on Facebook or at the Farmer's Market. Because this campaign really isn't about my debt and your money. It's about our farm and our community!

Blessings,

Natalya and Pinwheel
story_txt:
Down to the Wire
You have $5, $10, $20, $50 to spend today. Coffee? A movie? dinner out? A concert? Tomorrow all you will have left of that money is a memory. You could do something radical instead. You could help change the world. 
You could encourage innovation and development of sustainable farming techniques to deal with a changing climate. You could make sure that hundreds more people of all ages and interests have the opportunity to learn gardening, farming, and sustainable life skills. Together with similar donations from others, and the huge discount the seller has offered, your money can do a lot of good for a long time.
How do I know this? Because it's already working. This campaign has already succeeded, in many ways. In addition to the money raised by here, there have been several independent contributions, and generous private lenders have come forward to put up the balance of the $25,000. People from across the US and Canada have joined local friends to make sure Pinwheel continues. And the seller has given us additional time to finalize the pay-off arrangements.
 So donate more. Donate anyway. Because it says you value the farm, about healthy food, and about the environment. The smaller the loan we need, the better off the farm will be going forward. But most important, your support of this campaign...even a $5 donation...is a tangible reminder that I am not alone in this effort to preserve precious farmland. And that is priceless.
So please...for this last weekend...donate to the campaign...share it far and wide...and keep PInwheel in your thoughts and prayers. 
Short SummaryThe seller will cancel over $30,000 of the farm's debt if I put $25,000 in his hands by December 8 October 8. The entire farm (except for the separate, adjacent rental Farmhouse) will have a clear title, and the 3 separate parcels can be joined as one. This will free me and the farm to make even greater contributions to our community. Pinwheel isn't just about producing sheep and veggies, it's also about teaching skills, preserving the ecosystem, sharing nature, and fostering spiritual growth to benefit everyone.

Not-So-Short Summary

18 years ago, I bought a barren 10-acre cornfield behind my house to save it from becoming a warehouse. Since then I've worked relentlessly to create a sustainable sheep and vegetable farm right on the city limits of Lawrence, KS, with some of the best soil in the  world and the Kansas River flowing close beneath it (learn more at Pinwheel's website and blog). About 6 years ago, I entered into a contract to buy an adjacent acre (comprising 3 parcels) that will complete the farm with essential street frontage, a well-built metal barn for the sheep, a lovely grove of trees that the seller's sons planted in the 1960s, and a small house that I've been renovating for 3 years on a shoestring budget.
Now I'm facing one of my biggest challenges yet, and you can help. A series of misfortunes (see * in "HISTORY, THE SHORT VERSION" at the end of this article if you want more details on "how things came to be this way") has put me in dire financial straits. However, the seller of the acre has made the generous offer to discount the contract by more than half--IF I pay him $25,000 by December 8 October 8. 
(Find "Pinwheel Farm" on FaceBook if you want to message me with questions.) 
Your immediate generous contribution will help pay this final "ransom" so that the farm will be free to be a farm forever. And it will forever be, in part, YOUR farm, and our descendents' farm. Every contributor will be honored on our "Helping Hands" display (see Perks). When my stewardship is over, the farm will pass to others who will carry on my work to build and protect it. It will never be sold.


MORE ABOUT ME: As well a farmer, I'm a writer, artist, song-writer, inventor, mender-and-fixer, penny-pincher, volunteer coordinator, sustainable liver, researcher, teacher, spiritual pilgrim, grandmother, generous human being, good listener, and a whole lot more. I have a BS in Human Resource Management from Friends University, but that's nothing compared to the hands-on learning that life has brought me through voluntary service, friends, family, mentors, and other "classrooms" too numerous to mention. The farm is my way of passing on to others the skills and knowledge that so many have generously shared with me over the years.
What We Need
You're wondering--The seller wants $25,000; I'm asking for $35,000. What's up with that? The extra $10,000 ensures that the fees and taxes for this fundraising effort can be paid, in addition the contract buy-out. 
Any funds left after I pay the $25,000 and all fees and taxes will go first towards 2013 property taxes on all the farm's land. 
Additional funds (we'd love to get more than $35,000!) will go towards basic farm infrastructure improvements such as finishing the new veggie washhouse, cold storage for our veggies, sheep barn improvements (including small-scale milking facilities),  completing the new water well and well house for the farm, ADA accessible toilet facilities, and off-grid energy projects (not necessarily in that order). All funds will go towards debt retirement or lasting improvements on the farm, not operating or personal expenses.
If this campaign doesn't reach its goal, every penny left after the Indiegogo fee is paid will go towards the $25,000 contract buyout. Meanwhile, I'm working hard to find other sources of loans and donations to bridge any gap. We can do this! We WILL do this!
I want to assure you that I do not own land to profit from its resale. It's my "retirement plan", but not because I'll cash it in and move to a retirement home. It will be my pantry and my place to live for the rest of my life. Although I'll have title to the land, it will continue to own me--I am its steward, not its master. I will do everything I can to ensure that it will never be sold again, so that it will be available to future generations to continue farming without going through the years of debt and overwork that I've endured. It will be free to be a farm.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can make a short-term low/no-interest loan, please contact me immediately!
I know (because I'm there myself) that sometimes there just isn't a dollar to spare, no matter how important the cause. You can still help in so many ways, and still be a "Helping Hand"!


First and foremost, make this campaign viral! Share this campaign with everyone you can think of, via FaceBook, Twitter, email, or any way you can. Use the Indiegogo "share tools". Ask your friends and family to share it with their friends and family. Reach out to groups and strangers that you think share our values and long-term goals.

Keep me, the farm, the Embers family, our donors and other benefactors, and this campaign in your thoughts and prayers. 

Send me encouraging words via FaceBook, email, a postcard (if you know what those are), or the phone.
Contribute in-kind to the farm so that I can use all cash resources for the Big Payment. Groceries, gasoline, other basic necessities are all appreciated.

Volunteer at the farm if you are local and have time/energy. This campaign takes time away from the farm, and the farm still needs a lot of work to recover from this spring's upheaval.






What You Get

You'll become a member of Pinwheel Farm's Community of Life, forever! No matter how small your donation, you'll be honored on the Helping Hands wall of the Brown Barn. We'll list you as a donor on Pinwheel's website (unless you want to remain anonymous, or make a donation in honor of someone else). You'll be a Pinwheel VIP! Hopefully you'll be able to visit the farm in person and enjoy its quiet beauty, yummy veggies, entertaining animals, fascinating wildlife, and interesting people.
Moderate (by my pinch-penny standards) donations will get you great Pinwheel Farm products, discounts, and promotional items...there's something for everyone.
Larger donations will get you even more wonderful perks. By sponsoring a sheep or a tree, you'll feel a very special, unique connection with the farm for years to come. Participating in special events at the farm will bring you and your friends even closer to the farm's Community of Life.
Want to donate, don't see a perk that appeals to you, and have an idea for something else I could offer? Contact me!
The Impact


Paying off this contract will have far-reaching benefits beyond me and the farm. 

The farm will be able to support itself, me, and others as well. I'll be free to increase my mission to teach farming and sustainable living skills to people of all ages; continue developing special low-input gardening methods to ensure future food production "no matter what"; breed low-maintenance sheep that provide meat, wool and milk with just pasture and hay; enrich others' lives with opportunities to experience the natural ecosystem that's replaced the once-barren cornfield; welcome visitors to explore and relax in this rural haven that's just 3 blocks from a city transit route; navigate the challenges of an increasingly unstable climate; write about and photograph the wonders and lessons of the farm and share them through blogs and booklets.
The farm and its vast, complex Community of Life will be safe from nearly all risk of development. As of 2000, we had identified nearly 500 naturally-occuring species of living things here; I know there are hundreds more by now. We see new ones every year. The trees will continue to benefit our entire community through shade, screening of industrial areas, air purification, oxygen production, and more. Myriad bird species will sing, forage, raise their families, migrate through. The rich diversity of insects will thrive in a healthier balance each year. Frogs, turtles, snakes, foxes, and many other animals will delight us with their presence.

We live in a world in crisis, with increasing CO2 levels, unstable global weather patterns, GMOs, bee die-offs, Fukushima radiation headed this way, water shortages, worsening economy, etc. Pinwheel has been designed since its very beginning to make a positive difference in our environment, both ecological and social.

story:
Short Summary

Rose Tasker is a scientist, humanitarian, explorer, writer, musician, and artist from Tasmania, Australia. With a reputation for generating endless ideas and getting overly passionate about her work. Rose is one of those crazy people who believes we can make the world a better place and preserve what is already wonderful.

Rose has been selected as part of the 2041 International Antarctic Expedition and Antarctic Youth Ambassadors Program.

In 2014 Rose will join explorer Robert Swan and other young people from around the globe and venture to the Antarctic continent to explore the fragility of this important wilderness.

The expedition costs in excess of $22000 and Rose is seeking your help to raise the funds. 

What We Need & What You Get

Antarctica isn't cheap. To make the expedition a reality a fundraising goal has been set at $22000. 

There are some pretty cool things available if you donate certain amounts, have a look at some of the donation options. You can of course donate as little or as much as you like, even if it is not a listed amount.

The Impact

In its second year, the Antarctic Youth Ambassador Programme consists of young people selected from across the globe, AYAP Ambassadors will participate in the AYAP skills and capacity programme. Beginning the expedition with a goal in mind, Amabassadors will focus on developing an on-ground environmental project with youth-based curriculum. Using a combination of the Antarctic’s inspiration and newfound skills, Ambassadors will return home to implement a personalized yearlong project within their region; ultimately, inspiring positive ongoing change.

IAE 2014 Team Members will be sharing their adventures via the 2041 expedition website, updated daily from the field using the latest in satellite technology and digital media. Through photos and blog posts, the team will share their physical and emotional impressions of the Antarctic in real-time. The team’s global audience will vicariously experience the adventure with cutting-edge immediacy.

Rose on the Expedition
Camera, notebook, sketchbook, pencils, and remote technology in hand Rose has several goals during the expedition. These include, but are not limited to:

  • Collection of natural history illustrations from the Antarctic continent
  • Video 'architecture' projection on the polar landscape (first ever on the Antarctic continent, will be filmed for exhibition purposes)
  • Collection of photographs depiction the continents uniqueness and importance, but also evidence of anthropogenic impacts and challenges
  • Collecting scientific observational data on anthropogenic impacts on the continent, including dark snow, marine debris, climate change, and wildlife impacts
  • Documentary and landscape filming of Antarctica, to be screened publicly post-exhibition
  • The development of education programs to be implemented in Australian/Tasmanian schools
  • Collection of writings - poetry, prose, articles, essays, and thoughts
  • The development of an interactive website and/or computer game/app


There will be a number of post-expedition events to engage the wider public with the Antarctic continent and today's sustainability and environmental challenges. These may include workshops, lectures, festivals and events. Rose will also be engaging with young people on her return to assist in training and enhancing the capacity of young leaders.

Rose is particularly interested in working with Australian organisations in developing related projects. Projects may include curation of exhibitions, lectures, workshops, educations programs, or digital media projects. Please contact her blog (www.rosesouth.weebly.com) if you or your organisation are interested in collaborating.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and get your friends to donate. Follow me on my blog: 

www.rosesouth.weebly.com

Using a combination of the Antarctic’s inspiration and newfound skills, Ambassadors will return home to implement a personalized yearlong project within their region; ultimately, inspiring positive ongoing change.IAE 2014 Team Members will be sharing their adventures via the 2041 expedition website, updated daily from the field using the latest in satellite technology and digital media. Through photos and blog posts, the team will share their physical and emotional impressions of the Antarctic in real-time. The team’s global audience will vicariously experience the adventure with cutting-edge immediacy.Rose on the ExpeditionCamera, notebook, sketchbook, pencils, and remote technology in hand Rose has several goals during the expedition. These include, but are not limited to:

Collection of natural history illustrations from the Antarctic continent
Video 'architecture' projection on the polar landscape (first ever on the Antarctic continent, will be filmed for exhibition purposes)
Collection of photographs depiction the continents uniqueness and importance, but also evidence of anthropogenic impacts and challenges
Collecting scientific observational data on anthropogenic impacts on the continent, including dark snow, marine debris, climate change, and wildlife impacts
Documentary and landscape filming of Antarctica, to be screened publicly post-exhibition
The development of education programs to be implemented in Australian/Tasmanian schools
Collection of writings - poetry, prose, articles, essays, and thoughts
The development of an interactive website and/or computer game/app

There will be a number of post-expedition events to engage the wider public with the Antarctic continent and today's sustainability and environmental challenges. These may include workshops, lectures, festivals and events. Rose will also be engaging with young people on her return to assist in training and enhancing the capacity of young leaders.Rose is particularly interested in working with Australian organisations in developing related projects. Projects may include curation of exhibitions, lectures, workshops, educations programs, or digital media projects. Please contact her blog (www.rosesouth.weebly.com) if you or your organisation are interested in collaborating.  


Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out and get your friends to donate. Follow me on my blog: 
www.rosesouth.weebly.com

story:
One Earth Film Festival is a program developed by Green Community Connections. Green Community Connections is a not-for-profit organization currently operating under the fiscal sponsorship of the Institute of Cultural Affairs (ICA). Your contribution will be received/processed by ICA on our behalf.


FOR THE NEXT TWO WEEKENDS - 1/30 - 2/1 and 2/6-2/8 - those who contribute $100+ to our fund will be entered to win a $20 giftcard for The Chicago Diner!



This season share the gift of sustainability!

One Earth Film Festival is the Midwest’s premier environmental film festival, creating opportunities for understanding climate change, sustainability and the power of people. We showcase top-issue, thought-provoking environmental films leading audiences through interactive post-film discussions focused on solutions and actions.

We need your help! Through this IndieGoGo campaign, One Earth Film Festival is launching its first-ever online giving opportunity, where YOU can create social and environmental impact with your support of our event.

Your support is tax deductible and will be received by the Institute of Cultural Affairs, Green Community Connection's fiscal sponsor.

Take Action. Make a difference.

If you believe in a sustainable future, support our festival's growth and impact.

  • We believe in the power of people. Our goal for individual contributions is $5,000. It takes $50,000+ to produce a festival of this caliber. We're looking to source 10% of that goal through individuals who are equally committed to sustainability.
  • "Many hands make for light work."  To reach our goal, we must expand our reach. Share this opportunity with you friends.
  • Every dollar counts. Each contribution made during this impact campaign significantly enhances our ability to present high-quality film and discussion.
  • Your investment will create measurable impact. One Earth Film Festival will track commitments made by attendees to take some level of environmental action; we will send you and other investors an “Actions Report,” describing the impact made by your investment.
  • Enjoy the benefits of your investment.  As an agent of change, your impact will award you with unique opportunities at a variety of levels. Everyone contribution is meaningful and will be recognized.

Together, we can make this year's festival is our most inspiring fest, yet. Your financial support is a commitment we deeply appreciate and recognize as a meaningful contribution towards the protection of our One Earth.


Your Investment Increases Proven Outcomes

Last year’s 2,400 attendees viewed 38 screenings of 30 films in over 24 locations in Oak Park, River Forest, Berwyn and Chicago. This year’s festival promises to expand its reach, attendance and impact region-wide. We are aiming to reach 4,000 festival goers Here's why ...

  • We're the only one! One Earth Film Festival is the only festival of its kind in the region that focuses solely on environmental issues.
  • We're growing. Festival attendance has grown exponentially since our first year. As we grow, we know interest in these topics continues to build. 
  • We transform inspiration into action. Our festival was founded by a neighborhood of volunteers at Green Community Connections committed to sustainability. This group offers continued education and opportunities for action all year round. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't invest financially, we still need your help spreading the word!

  • Follow and interact with us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter
  • Share this campaign with your friends!
