story:
Our campaign in a few words

#GROWTHEFUTURE

Hi! We’re Compost Montreal, a small business run by a dedicated team of environmental entrepreneurs for the past 7 years. We are the only access that many Montrealers have to composting, but we were recently told that our local compost site will soon be turned into a storage area for city equipment. There are no other compost sites anywhere near the city of Montreal, so the closure of this site would put our project in serious jeopardy.

The goal of our fundraising campaign is to raise $200,000 to develop a new compost site in order to keep providing Montrealers with the ability to compost, preventing the release of huge amounts of greenhouse gas and creating rich new soil to grow new food, no matter what may come…

This is a flexible funding campaign, so we will receive any contributions that are made. Thanks for your support!

(To read more please see below... and if you have any questions please write to us at info@compostmontreal.com or visit us at www.compostmontreal.com)


Notre campagne en quelques mots

#CULTIVONSLAVENIR

Bonjour! Nous sommes Compost Montréal, une petite entreprise gérée par des entrepreneurs environnementaux depuis maintenant 7 ans. Nous sommes le seul accès qu’ont beaucoup de Montréalais au compostage mais nous avons été avertis récemment que notre site local de compostage sera transformé en aire d'entreposage d'équipement. Il n'y en a aucun autre site de compostage dans la grande région de Montréal, alors la fermeture du site mettrait notre projet en grand danger.

Le but de cette campagne est de récolter $200,000, ce qui nous donnera la possibilité de développer un nouveau site de compostage afin de pouvoir continuer d'offrir aux Montréalais la possibilité de composter, peu importe ce qui arrive... 

Ceci est une campagne de financement flexible, alors nous reçevrons toute contribution que vous faites. Merci de votre soutien!

(POUR VOIR LA SUITE EN FRANÇAIS, CLIQUEZ ICI)

(Vous avez une question? Veuillez nous contacter à info@compostmontreal.com ou venez nous visiter à www.compostmontreal.com)

English


About us

Compost Montreal has blossomed from a bicycle and trailer collection into a dedicated team of 15 people. We serve nearly 750 residents and 100 businesses and institutions, such as schools, restaurants, and offices. Many of our clients are as passionate as we are about reducing the environmental impact of the waste they produce. Together, we divert around 700 tonnes of organic waste from landfills every year, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by about 1,750,000 tonnes of CO2 equivalent annually. That’s about the same impact as taking 900 cars off the road!

We are a social entreprise, one with strong environmental and social purpose to everything we do. We believe that a very powerful way to create real positive change to the way our economy impacts the world is to build a viable business while doing something that is good. There is a strong market of people out there who are voting with their dollar and supporting businesses that are making the world a better place.

We are currently pursuing a certification as a 'B' Corp, a model that is much more common in the U.S. and has a pretty strict protocol for balancing 'people, planet, and profits', to always be trying to satisfy a 'triple bottom line'. We have been working to reach these goals for the past 7 years, and so far have always made just enough to pay ourselves and keep our pickup trucks in working order.

We are the only access that many Montrealers have to composting, as the official plan for a city-wide residential collection is not expected to take effect before 2019.

Our Challenge

Our local compost site, run by the South-West borough, is the only site that makes agricultural-grade compost within an hour of Montreal. However, a nearby major roadwork project from the Ministry of Transportation has pressured the South-West borough to transform the compost site into a storage area for its equipment. Thanks to the support of thousands of citizens, and the goodwill of the South-West borough, the closure has been postponed by several months.

While attempts are still being made to keep the site open, the possibility of its closure is still very real, and the site could now close at any moment.

Here is a video of the site in action:

There are no other compost sites near the city of Montreal, so the closure of this compost site would put our project in serious jeopardy. Setting up a new compost site will take some time, considering the work required and the process of obtaining the necessary permits. That's why we've launched this campaign now: To help raise some money in order to develop a new site and keep composting, no matter what may come. This will allow us to continue to make our social and environmental contribution through the work that we do.


What we need

Since being told that our local compost site was going to close, and looking around only to find a lack of real alternatives, we have realized that the only real solution to the situation is to open our own compost site. The next-closest compost site that makes agricultural-grade compost is over an hour away from Montreal, and charges a great deal for the food waste it receives. We want to continue to compost as locally as possible, as economically and as ecologically as possible, and we want to keep providing the community with great quality finished compost for growing food in the city.

We have met with a number of groups - like the folks at the Valhalla Movement - who recognize the value of compost and have been helping us in our quest to set up a new site. A number of great options are available for locations to set up a site, but of course it will take a significant amount of money to pay for plans, development, and equipment.

We need your help to raise $200,000 to develop a new site. We will use this money to:

- Continue the research and development for our site, including engineer consulting, planning, and permitting.

- Upgrade to cost-effective higher-capacity trucks and convert them to run on used vegetable oil, which we’ve already begun collecting, filtering, and testing. This is a great way to cut pollution and cost while doing our collection runs and transporting the food waste for treatment while we set up our new site. Once our new site is ready these trucks will still be perfect for the job!

- Purchase the essential equipment we will need to get started, most importantly a tractor.

- If the South-West borough needs funding help that we can provide to keep their compost site open, we will gladly contribute what we can to their site's success and survival.


What's next?

We are working on partnerships with groups that would like us to create and operate a compost site on land that is already available, and doesn’t need to be purchased. This will help keep the cost of our project reasonable, as land is obviously a significant expense. And yet there is so much food waste produced in the City of Montreal - and such a need for finished compost to grow new food - that we will eventually be looking to buy land in order to meet this demand. Once our crowdfunding campaign is done, we will begin preparing for environmental-impact investment in order to raise more funds that will allow us to further develop our model for sustainable composting and help Montrealers compost more of their waste. 

What is an impact investment? "Impact investments are investments made into companies, organizations, and funds with the intention to generate social and environmental impact alongside a financial return." (www.thegiin.org)

Only about 10-15% of organic waste generated in Montreal is presently being composted, and the rest is still going to landfill. While the city of Montreal does have plans for city-wide residential organic waste collection by 2019, it will not include collection for commercial and institutional clients such as restaurants and schools, so there will always be a vast amount of food waste available for us to make our own high-quality compost.

Help Montreal compost by helping Compost Montreal! We appreciate your support and we hope to see you at our new compost site sometime soon!


Ready to see details about the perks? Click here! Interested in learning more? Read on!


------------------

How Compost Montreal Began

Compost Montreal was started in July of 2007 with just a bike and a trailer. Stephen McLeod knew that when food waste goes in the garbage, it ends up in landfills, which creates greenhouse gases that contribute enormously to global warming and climate change. He also knew that compost is nature’s way of enriching the soil to grow new food, and that the chemical fertilizers we use are slowly destroying our soil and polluting the environment.



Montreal had no municipal organic waste collection service, so Stephen decided to do something about it. He began picking up food waste from his neighbours, using a trailer attached to the back of his bike, and taking it to a nearby small-scale composter run by the environmental group Éco-Quartier. Stephen soon discovered that the South-West borough of Montreal, (where he still lives and where our office is still based) was running a medium-scale compost site just down the road. He approached them about adding the nutrient-rich food waste he was picking up, and they agreed! With that, Compost Montreal was born. 


About the South-West compost site

We have been incredibly fortunate to have had access to this site for the past 7 years. It is located just 5 minutes from our office and only 6 kilometres from downtown Montreal, which is truly an amazing resource for a city to have and something you just don’t find anywhere else. 

Due to space concerns related to the demolition of the Turcot Interchange, a major piece of downtown highway infrastructure, the South-West borough recently announced a plan to shut down the compost operations at this site in order to use the space as storage for roadwork equipment.

Thanks to the support of thousands of petition signers, and the reluctance of the South-West borough to actually close their site, (a source of pride for the borough, and the only one of its kind anywhere near Montreal, in operation now for over 20 years) the closure has been delayed by a few months. We have been working with the borough to try to keep the site open and operating in some capacity, something they would like to be able to do.

However, the borough is in a tough position, and while there is still hope, the situation is complicated and there is a real possibility that the site will have to close in the very near future. While it would break our hearts, and there is no replacing such an incredible resource - both to the city itself and of course to our own operations - we are determined to keep composting, and believe that with your help, we can turn this crisis into an opportunity.

We certainly hope that the South-West compost site never shuts down. But we now know that in order to guarantee the future of our project, and to keep helping Montrealers to compost, we need to open another site.

About food waste and compost

When food waste is sent to landfill it is layered with all kinds of garbage, and breaks down without oxygen. This causes it to release large amounts of methane (a greenhouse gas 25 times more potent than CO2), leach out toxic liquids, and sometimes take decades to break down completely. Keeping food waste separate from garbage and letting it compost properly with oxygen allows it to transform into nutrient-rich compost in a year or less!

Compost is a fantastic soil amendment that repairs and enriches soil, eliminating the need for environmentally-damaging petroleum-based synthetic products to grow food. So, not only does composting your food waste avoid greenhouse gas emissions, it also creates rich soil that can be used to grow new food!

Only about 10-15% of the food waste produced in Montreal is presently being composted, and the other 90% is still going to landfill. We want to help keep more and more of it out of landfills and turn it into high quality compost.  


What is Responsible Solutions?

After a few years collecting compost, we created a parent company called Responsible Solutions that could launch new socially and environmentally responsible projects. So far we have created BioMobile, an online grocery store with delivery that focuses on organic, local, fair-trade, and other sustainable products. We've just recently switched to a new website, but the whole project is presently on hold (though you can still order Green Pasture cod liver oil) while we address the present situation at Compost Montreal. You can always visit the site and send us a message to let us know if this service would be of interest to you.

We have also developed a used vegetable oil collection service for our restaurant clients at Compost Montreal. The oil we collect is used to create biodiesel, fuel our trucks, and help to reduce fossil-fuel consumption.

There are lots of other social and environmental projects that we want to develop and support. But the most important way to guarantee the future of these projects is to make sure that Compost Montreal - our most important project, and the one that started it all - can survive and thrive, even through this turbulent time. 

And for that, we need your help...


Thanks so much for your support! Click here to see more details about our perks!


----------------------------------------


Français


À propos de nous

Compost Montréal est devenu - d'une simple collecte à vélo avec une remorque - une équipe dédiée de 15 personnes. Nous servons près de 750 clients résidentiels, et une centaine de commerces et institutions (écoles, restaurants, et bureaux). Beaucoup de nos clients sont aussi passionnés que nous par la réduction de l’impact environnemental des déchets qu’ils produisent. Ensemble chaque année, nous détournons environ 700 tonnes de matière organique des sites d’enfouissement, ce qui équivaut à réduire annuellement les émissions de gaz à effet de serre de 1,750,000 tonnes de CO2 . C’est le même impact que retirer 900 voitures de la route!

Nous sommes une entreprise sociale, avec de solides engagements sociaux et environnementaux que nous appliquons à tout ce que nous faisons. Nous croyons qu'un moyen efficace de faire évoluer la façon dont l’économie actuelle fonctionne est de montrer aux gens qu’il est possible de construire un projet d’entreprise viable en faisant quelque chose de bien. Il y a un vaste marché de gens qui sont prêts à voter avec leur argent, en soutenant les entreprises qui travaillent à créer un monde meilleur.

Nous sommes actuellement en train de poursuivre la certification ‘B corp’, un modèle plus commun aux États Unis, avec un protocole assez strict afin d'arriver au bon équilibre entre “les gens, la planète et les profits”, toujours dans le but d’atteindre une durabilité à triple résultats (triple bottom-line). Depuis 7 ans maintenant, nous travaillons à atteindre ces buts, et nous avons toujours fait juste assez d'argent pour nous payer et pour garder nos camions pickup en bon état. Nous sommes le seul accès qu’ont beaucoup de Montréalais au compostage, puisque le plan officiel pour une collecte globale pour la ville de Montréal ne prendra normalement effet qu'en 2019.


Notre défi

Le site de compostage de l'arrondissement Sud-Ouest, qui reçoit depuis 7 ans la matière organique que nous collectons, est le seul site qui produit du compost de qualité agricole dans un rayon d'une heure autour de Montréal. Cependant, un projet de travaux routiers majeur, initié par le Ministère des Transports, fait pression sur l'arrondissement pour transformer le site de compostage en une aire d'entreposage d'équipement. Grâce au soutien de milliers de citoyens, et à la bonne volonté de l'arrondissement, la fermeture a été reportée de plusieurs mois.

Malgré les tentatives mises en place pour garder le site ouvert, la possibilité de fermeture demeure réelle, et le site pourrait fermer à tout moment. 

Ci-dessous une vidéo du site en action:


Il n'y en a aucun autre site de compostage dans la région du Grand Montréal, donc la fermeture du site mettrait notre projet en grand danger. Démarrer un nouveau site de compostage prendra du temps, considérant le travail nécessaire ainsi que le processus d'obtention des permis requis. C'est pour cette raison que nous avons lancé cette campagne maintenant: Pour nous aider à récolter des fonds afin de développer un nouveau site de compostage et continuer à composter, peu importe ce qui arrivera. Ceci nous permettra de continuer à faire notre part sociale et environnementale à travers le travail que nous effectuons. 


Ce dont nous avons besoin 

Depuis l'annonce initiale de la fermeture de notre site de compostage local, nous avons cherché des alternatives et, avons alors réalisé que la seule véritable solution serait de développer un nouveau site de compostage. Après le site du sud-ouest, le prochain site qui produit du compost de qualité agricole le plus proche est situé à plus d’une heure de route de Montréal, et applique des frais importants pour les résidus alimentaires qu’il reçoit. Nous voulons continuer à composter aussi localement, économiquement et écologiquement que possible, et nous voulons continuer à fournir à la population un compost d’excellente qualité qui permettra de cultiver dans la ville. 

Nous avons rencontré de nombreux groupes, comme les gens du Mouvement Valhalla, qui reconnaissent la valeur du compost et nous aident dans notre quête; celle de développer un nouveau site de compostage. Un bon nombre d’options intéressantes est disponible quant aux lieux où nous pourrions établir notre site mais ceci demande, bien sur, des sommes importantes afin de pouvoir financer les plans d'aménagement, le développement, et l'équipement. 
Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour récolter $200,000 afin de développer notre nouveau site. Nous utiliserons cet argent pour : 

- Continuer la recherche et le développement du nouveau site, ce qui comprend des ingénieurs-conseils, plans et permis.

- Améliorer la rentabilité de nos camions, en augmentant leur capacité, et en les convertissant à l’huile végétale usée/biodiésel, que nous avons déjà commencé à collecter, filtrer et tester. C’est un excellent moyen pour réduire nos émissions de polluants et nos coûts, tout en continuant à collecter et à transporter les résidus alimentaires pour le traitement, pendant que nous développons un nouveau site. Une fois que notre site sera prêt, ces camions seront toujours parfaitement adaptés!

- Acheter l’équipement qui nous est essentiel pour commencer les opérations sur le nouveau site, le plus important étant d’acheter un tracteur.

- Si l'arrondissement du sud-ouest a besoin de soutien financièr afin de garder ouvert leur site de compostage, nous ferons notre possible pour contribuer de cette façon à la survie et succès de leur site.

Qu'arrive t-il après?

Nous travaillons actuellement sur un partenariat avec des groupes qui souhaitent que nous créerions un site de compostage sur des terrains qui sont d’ores et déjà disponibles et qui n’ont pas besoin d’être achetés. Cela aidera à maintenir les coûts de notre projet à un niveau minimum, puisque que le terrain représente, bien sur, une dépense considérable. Et pourtant, il y a tellement de résidus alimentaires produits par la ville de Montréal, et un tel besoin en compost fini pour pouvoir cultiver des aliments sains, que nous chercherons éventuellement à procurer un autre terrain pour pouvoir véritablement répondre à la demande. Une fois que cette campagne de levée de fonds sera terminée, nous commençerons à se préparer pour de investissement d’impact environnemental, dans le but de récolter davantage de fonds afin de continuer à développer notre modèle de compostage durable.

Qu'est-ce que c'est l'investissement d'impact? "Les investissements d'impact sont des montants placés dans des sociétés, des organismes et des fonds dans le but de produire un impact social et environnemental mesurable parallèlement à leur rendement financier."
(www.thegiin.org, http://www.mcconnellfoundation.ca/fr/)

Seulement 10-15% de la matière organique générée par les citoyens de la Ville de Montréal est présentement compostée, et le reste se retrouve toujours dans les dépotoirs. La Ville ne planifie pas d’offrir de collecte résidentielle de la matière organique à travers toute la ville avant 2019, et même à ce moment là, il n’y aura pas de collecte organisée pour les commerces, entreprises, écoles et institutions. Il y aura donc toujours un approvisionnement abondant de matière organique à composter sur notre site.

Aidez Montréal à composter en aidant Compost Montréal! Nous apprécions votre soutien et nous espérons vous voir à notre nouveau site bientôt!


Prêt pour les récompenses? Cliquez ici! Vous souhaitez en apprendre davantage? Continuez! 

                                                                  
 ------------------

Comment nous avons commencé


Compost Montréal est né en juillet 2007 avec un vélo et une remorque. Stephen McLeod savait que lorsque les résidus alimentaires vont à la poubelle, ils finissent dans des sites d’enfouissement, causant la création de gaz à effet de serre connus pour leurs rôles dans le réchauffement et les changements climatiques. Il savait aussi que le compost est un moyen naturel d’enrichir le sol afin de cultiver de la nouvelle nourriture, et que les engrais chimiques que nous utilisons sont doucement en train de détruire notre sol et de polluer notre environnement.



Montréal n’avait pas de service municipal de collecte de résidus alimentaires, donc Stephen décida d’agir. Il commença par récupérer les résidus alimentaires de ses voisins, en utilisant une remorque attachée à l’arrière de son vélo, puis il les déposait dans une compostière à petite échelle, mise en place par le groupe environnemental Éco-Quartier. Stephen découvrit assez vite que l’arrondissement du sud-ouest de Montréal (où il vit toujours et où nos bureaux sont situés) exploitait un site de compostage à moyenne échelle dans le même secteur. Il leur proposa d’ajouter les résidus alimentaires riches en nutriments qu’il récoltait, et ils ont accepté! C’est comme cela que Compost Montréal est né.

À propos du site de compostage du sud-ouest

Nous avons été incroyablement chanceux d’avoir eu accès à ce site pendant les 7 dernières années. Il est situé à 5 minutes de nos bureaux et seulement 6 kilomètres du centre ville de Montréal, ce qui en fait une extraordinaire ressource pour la ville, quelque chose qui ne peut être trouvé nulle part ailleurs.

Faisant face à des problèmes d’espace liés à la démolition de l’échangeur Turcot (une partie importante de l’infrastructure de l’autoroute du centre-ville), l’arrondissement Sud-ouest a récemment annoncé l'arrêt de ses activités de compostage, afin de transformer l'espace utilisé en aire d'entreposage pour les équipements de la voirie.

Grâce au soutien de milliers de citoyens, et à la réticence de l’arrondissement du Sud-ouest de fermer leur site, (une grande fierté pour l'arrondissment et le seul dans son genre, ouvert depuis plus de 20 ans) la fermeture a été reportée de quelques mois. Nous travaillons avec l’administration de l'arrondissement pour garder le site ouvert à une certaine capacité, mais l'arrondissement se trouve dans une position difficile et, même s'il reste de l'espoir, il y'a toujours possibilité que le site soit forcé de fermer dans un avenir très proche. Même si cela nous briserait le cœur, et qu’une telle ressource ne pourra jamais être remplacée, pour la ville ou pour nos opérations, nous sommes déterminés à continuer de composter, et nous pensons qu’avec votre aide, nous pouvons transformer cette situation en une opportunité. 

Nous espérons que le site du sud-ouest reste ouvert pour toujours. Mais nous savons maintenant que pour garantir le futur de Compost Montréal et pour continuer à aider les Montréalais à composter, il faut ouvrir un nouveau site de compostage.

À propos des résidus alimentaires et du compost

Lorsque les résidus alimentaires sont envoyés à l’enfouissement, ils sont mélangés à différentes autres sortes de déchets, et se décomposent sans oxygène. Cela provoque des émanations de méthane (un gaz à effet de serre 25 fois plus puissant que le CO2), l’écoulement de liquide toxique, et des fois cela peut mettre des décennies à se décomposer complètement. Séparer les résidus alimentaires des autres déchets, et les laisser se composter correctement avec de l’oxygène permet de les transformer en un compost riche en nutriments en seulement une année ou moins. 

Le compost est un fantastique amendement du sol qui répare et enrichie la terre, et élimine le besoin d’utiliser des produits synthétiques à base chimique, néfastes pour l’environnement et pour notre santé. Par conséquent, composter vos restes n’évite pas seulement l’émission de gaz à effet de serre, cela crée aussi un sol plus riche, qui peut être utilisé pour à nouveau faire pousser de la nourriture saine!

Seulement de 10-15% des résidus alimentaires produits à Montréal sont actuellement compostés et le reste est toujours envoyé à l’enfouissement. Nous voulons aider à détourner de plus en plus de matière hors des sites d’enfouissement et à les transformer plutôt en un compost d’excellente qualité. 

À propos de Solutions Responsables

Après quelques années de collecte de compost, nous avons créé une société mère, appelée Solutions Responsables, pour lancer de nouveaux projets socialement et environnementalement responsables. Pour l’instant, nous avons créé BioMobile, une épicerie en ligne avec service de livraison, axée sur des produits biologiques, locaux, et certifiés commerce équitable, et qui encourage un monde plus durable. Apart du fait que vous pouvez toujours comander de l'huile de foie de morue Green Pasture, le projet est autrement en pause pour que nous puissions nous consacrer entièrement à Compost Montréal. Vous pouvez toujours aller sur notre site web si vous le voulez et laisser vos coordonnées si l’idée d’un tel service vous intéresse.

Nous avons aussi développé un programme de recyclage des huiles usées pour les clients restaurateurs de Compost Montréal. L’huile que nous récoltons est utilisée pour fabriquer du biodiésel, alimenter nos camions, et réduire la dépendance sur les produits pétroliers. 

Il y a une multitude d’autres projets sociaux et environnementaux que nous souhaiterions développer et soutenir mais le moyen le plus sûr pour garantir le futur de ces projets, c’est de s’assurer que Compost Montréal, notre projet le plus important et celui grâce auquel nous avons tout commencé, peut survivre et continuer à se développer, même durant cette période tumultueuse.

Et pour faire cela, nous avons besoin de vous!

Our trucks have always had names, usually based on the stories told to us by the previous owners, and usually having to do with animals: The Moose, Big Red, The Bull, Snow Dog… and with this level of contribution, we'd like to give you the opportunity to name one of our next trucks! story_txt:
Our campaign in a few words
#GROWTHEFUTUREHi! We’re Compost Montreal, a small business run by a dedicated team of environmental entrepreneurs for the past 7 years. We are the only access that many Montrealers have to composting, but we were recently told that our local compost site will soon be turned into a storage area for city equipment. There are no other compost sites anywhere near the city of Montreal, so the closure of this site would put our project in serious jeopardy. The goal of our fundraising campaign is to raise $200,000 to develop a new compost site in order to keep providing Montrealers with the ability to compost, preventing the release of huge amounts of greenhouse gas and creating rich new soil to grow new food, no matter what may come…This is a flexible funding campaign, so we will receive any contributions that are made. Thanks for your support! (To read more please see below... and if you have any questions please write to us at info@compostmontreal.com or visit us at www.compostmontreal.com)
Notre campagne en quelques mots
#CULTIVONSLAVENIRBonjour! Nous sommes Compost Montréal, une petite entreprise gérée par des entrepreneurs environnementaux depuis maintenant 7 ans. Nous sommes le seul accès qu’ont beaucoup de Montréalais au compostage mais nous avons été avertis récemment que notre site local de compostage sera transformé en aire d'entreposage d'équipement. Il n'y en a aucun autre site de compostage dans la grande région de Montréal, alors la fermeture du site mettrait notre projet en grand danger. 
Le but de cette campagne est de récolter $200,000, ce qui nous donnera la possibilité de développer un nouveau site de compostage afin de pouvoir continuer d'offrir aux Montréalais la possibilité de composter, peu importe ce qui arrive... 
Ceci est une campagne de financement flexible, alors nous reçevrons toute contribution que vous faites. Merci de votre soutien!
(POUR VOIR LA SUITE EN FRANÇAIS, CLIQUEZ ICI)
(Vous avez une question? Veuillez nous contacter à info@compostmontreal.com ou venez nous visiter à www.compostmontreal.com)
English

About usCompost Montreal has blossomed from a bicycle and trailer collection into a dedicated team of 15 people. We serve nearly 750 residents and 100 businesses and institutions, such as schools, restaurants, and offices. Many of our clients are as passionate as we are about reducing the environmental impact of the waste they produce. Together, we divert around 700 tonnes of organic waste from landfills every year, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by about 1,750,000 tonnes of CO2 equivalent annually. That’s about the same 
impact as taking 900 cars off the road!We are a social 
entreprise, one with strong environmental and social purpose to 
everything we do. We believe that a very powerful way to create real positive change to the way our economy impacts the world is to build a
 viable business while doing something that is good. There is a strong market of people out there who are voting with their dollar and supporting businesses that are making the world a better place.We are currently pursuing a certification as a 'B' Corp,  a model that is much more common in the U.S. and has a pretty strict protocol for balancing 'people, planet, and profits', to always be trying to satisfy a 'triple bottom line'. We have been working to reach these goals for the past 7 years, and so far have always made just enough to pay ourselves and keep our pickup trucks in working order. We are the only access that many Montrealers have to composting, as the official plan for a city-wide residential collection is not expected to take effect before 2019. Our Challenge
Our local compost site, run by the South-West borough, is the only site that makes agricultural-grade compost within an hour of Montreal. However, a nearby major roadwork project from the Ministry of Transportation has pressured the South-West borough to transform the compost site into a storage area for its equipment. Thanks to the support of thousands of citizens, and the goodwill of the South-West borough, the closure has been postponed by several months.While attempts are still being made to keep the site open, the possibility of its closure is still very real, and the site could now close at any moment. Here is a video of the site in action: 



There are no other compost sites near the city of Montreal, so the closure of this compost site would put our project in serious jeopardy. Setting up a new compost site will take some time, considering the work required and the process of obtaining the necessary permits. That's why we've launched this campaign now: To help raise some money in order to develop a 
new site and keep composting, no matter what may come. This will allow us to continue to make our social and environmental contribution through the work that we do.
What we needSince being told that our local compost site was going to close, and looking around only to find a lack of real alternatives, we have realized that the only real solution to the situation is to open our own compost site. The next-closest compost site that makes agricultural-grade compost is over an hour away from Montreal, and charges a great deal for the food waste it receives. We want to continue to compost as locally as possible,  as economically and as ecologically as possible, and we want to keep providing the community with great quality finished compost for growing food in the city.We have met with a number of groups - like the 
folks at the Valhalla Movement - who recognize the value of 
compost and have been helping us in our quest to set up a new site. A 
number of great options are available for locations to set up a site, 
but of course it will take a significant amount of money to pay for plans, development, and equipment.We need your help to raise $200,000 to develop a new site. We will use this money to:
- Continue the research and development for our site, including engineer consulting, planning, and permitting.

- Upgrade to cost-effective higher-capacity trucks and convert them
 to run on used vegetable oil, which we’ve already begun collecting, 
filtering, and testing. This is a great way to cut pollution and cost 
while doing our collection runs and transporting the food waste for treatment while we set up our new site. Once our new site is 
ready these trucks will still be perfect for the job!

- Purchase the essential equipment we will need to get started, most importantly a tractor. 
- If the South-West borough needs funding help that we can provide to keep their compost site open, we will gladly contribute what we can to their site's success and survival. 

What's next?

We are working on partnerships with groups that would like us to create and operate a compost site on land that is already available,
 and doesn’t need to be purchased. This will help keep the cost of our 
project reasonable, as land is obviously a significant expense. And 
yet there is so much food waste produced in the City of Montreal - and 
such a need for finished compost to grow new food - that we will eventually be
 looking to buy land in order to meet this demand. Once our crowdfunding
 campaign is done, we will begin preparing for environmental-impact investment in order to raise more funds that will allow us to further develop our model for sustainable composting and help Montrealers compost more of their waste.  
What is an impact investment? "Impact investments are investments made into companies, organizations, and funds with the intention to generate social and 
environmental impact alongside a financial return." (www.thegiin.org)
Only about 10-15% of organic waste generated in Montreal is presently being composted, and the rest is still going to landfill. While the city of Montreal does have plans for city-wide residential 
organic waste collection by 2019, it will not include collection for 
commercial and institutional clients such as restaurants and schools, so
 there will always be a vast amount of food waste available for us to make our own high-quality compost.
Help Montreal compost by helping Compost Montreal! We appreciate your support and we hope to see you at our new compost site sometime soon!

Ready to see details about the perks? Click here! Interested in learning more? Read on!

------------------

How Compost Montreal Began
Compost Montreal was started in July of 2007 with just a bike and
 a trailer. Stephen McLeod knew that when food waste goes in the 
garbage, it ends up in landfills, which creates greenhouse gases that 
contribute enormously to global warming and climate change. He also knew
 that compost is nature’s way of enriching the soil to grow new food, 
and that the chemical fertilizers we use are slowly destroying our soil 
and polluting the environment.



Montreal had no municipal organic 
waste collection service, so Stephen decided to do something about it. 
He began picking up food waste from his neighbours, using a trailer 
attached to the back of his bike, and taking it to a nearby small-scale 
composter run by the environmental group Éco-Quartier. Stephen soon 
discovered that the South-West borough of Montreal, (where he still 
lives and where our office is still based) was running a medium-scale 
compost site just down the road. He approached them about adding the 
nutrient-rich food waste he was picking up, and they agreed! With that, 
Compost Montreal was born.  

About the South-West compost site
We have been incredibly fortunate to have had access to this site for the past 7 years. It is located just 5 minutes from our office and only 6 kilometres from downtown Montreal, which is truly an amazing resource for a city to have and something you just don’t find anywhere else. 
Due to space concerns related to the demolition of the Turcot Interchange, a major piece of downtown highway infrastructure, the South-West borough recently announced a plan to shut down the compost operations at this site in order to use the space as storage for roadwork equipment.
Thanks to the support of thousands of petition signers, and the reluctance of the South-West borough to actually close their site, (a source of pride for the borough, and the only one of its kind anywhere near Montreal, in operation now for over 20 years) the closure has been delayed by a few months. We have been working with the borough to try to keep the site open and operating in some capacity, something they would like to be able to do. 
However, the borough is in a tough position, and while there is still hope, the situation is complicated and there is a real possibility that the site will have to close in the very near future. While it would break our hearts, and there is no replacing such an incredible resource - both to the city itself and of course to our own operations - we are determined to keep composting, and believe that with your help, we can turn this crisis into an opportunity.
We certainly hope that the South-West compost site never shuts down. But we now know that in order to guarantee the future of our project, and to keep helping Montrealers to compost, we need to open another site.
About food waste and compost
When food waste is sent to landfill it is layered with all kinds of garbage, and breaks down without oxygen. This causes it to release large amounts of methane (a greenhouse gas 25 times more potent than CO2), leach out toxic liquids, and sometimes take decades to break down completely. Keeping food waste separate from garbage and letting it compost properly with oxygen allows it to transform into nutrient-rich compost in a year or less!
Compost is a fantastic soil amendment that repairs and enriches soil, eliminating the need for environmentally-damaging petroleum-based synthetic products to grow food. So, not only does composting your food waste avoid greenhouse gas emissions, it also creates rich soil that can be used to grow new food!
Only about 10-15% of the food waste produced in Montreal is presently being composted, and the other 90% is still going to landfill. We want to help keep more and more of it out of landfills and turn it into high quality compost.  

What is Responsible Solutions?
After a few years collecting compost, we created a parent company called Responsible Solutions that could launch new socially and environmentally responsible projects. So far we have created BioMobile, an online grocery store with delivery that focuses on organic, local, fair-trade, and other sustainable products. We've just recently switched to a new website, but the whole project is presently on hold (though you can still order Green Pasture cod liver oil) while we address the present situation at Compost Montreal. You can always visit the site and send us a message to let us know if this service would be of interest to you.
We have also developed a used vegetable oil collection service for our restaurant clients at Compost Montreal. The oil we collect is used to create biodiesel, fuel our trucks, and help to reduce fossil-fuel consumption.
There are lots of other social and environmental projects that we want to develop and support. But the most important way to guarantee the future of these projects is to make sure that Compost Montreal - our most important project, and the one that started it all - can survive and thrive, even through this turbulent time. 
And for that, we need your help...


Thanks so much for your support! Click here to see more details about our perks!


----------------------------------------


Français

À propos de nousCompost Montréal est devenu - d'une simple collecte à vélo avec une remorque - une équipe dédiée de 15 personnes. Nous servons près de 750 clients résidentiels, et une centaine de commerces et institutions (écoles, restaurants, et bureaux). Beaucoup de nos clients sont aussi passionnés que nous par la réduction de l’impact environnemental des déchets qu’ils produisent. Ensemble chaque année, nous détournons environ 700 tonnes de matière organique des sites d’enfouissement, ce qui équivaut à réduire annuellement les émissions de gaz à effet de serre de 1,750,000 tonnes de CO2 . C’est le même impact que retirer 900 voitures de la route!



Nous sommes une entreprise sociale, avec de solides engagements sociaux et environnementaux que nous appliquons à tout ce que nous faisons. Nous croyons qu'un moyen efficace de faire évoluer la façon dont l’économie actuelle fonctionne est de montrer aux gens qu’il est possible de construire un projet d’entreprise viable en faisant quelque chose de bien. Il y a un vaste marché de gens qui sont prêts à voter avec leur argent, en soutenant les entreprises qui travaillent à créer un monde meilleur.Nous sommes actuellement en train de poursuivre la certification ‘B corp’, un modèle plus commun aux États Unis, avec un protocole assez strict afin d'arriver au bon équilibre entre “les gens, la planète et les profits”, toujours dans le but d’atteindre une durabilité à triple résultats (triple bottom-line). Depuis 7 ans maintenant, nous travaillons à atteindre ces buts, et nous avons toujours fait juste assez d'argent pour nous payer et pour garder nos camions pickup en bon état. Nous sommes le seul accès qu’ont beaucoup de Montréalais au compostage, puisque le plan officiel pour une collecte globale pour la ville de Montréal ne prendra normalement effet qu'en 2019.

Notre défi
Le site de compostage de l'arrondissement Sud-Ouest, qui reçoit depuis 7 ans la matière organique que nous collectons, est le seul site qui produit du compost de qualité agricole dans un rayon d'une heure autour de Montréal. Cependant, un projet de travaux routiers majeur, initié par le Ministère des Transports, fait pression sur l'arrondissement pour transformer le site de compostage en une aire d'entreposage d'équipement. Grâce au soutien de milliers de citoyens, et à la bonne volonté de l'arrondissement, la fermeture a été reportée de plusieurs mois.
Malgré les tentatives mises en place pour garder le site ouvert, la possibilité de fermeture demeure réelle, et le site pourrait fermer à tout moment. 

Ci-dessous une vidéo du site en action: 

Il n'y en a aucun autre site de compostage dans la région du Grand Montréal, donc la fermeture du site mettrait notre projet en grand danger. Démarrer un nouveau site de compostage prendra du temps, considérant le travail nécessaire ainsi que le processus d'obtention des permis requis. C'est pour cette raison que nous avons lancé cette campagne maintenant: Pour nous aider à récolter des fonds afin de développer un nouveau site de compostage et continuer à composter, peu importe ce qui arrivera. Ceci nous permettra de continuer à faire notre part sociale et environnementale à travers le travail que nous effectuons. 



Ce dont nous avons besoin Depuis l'annonce initiale de la fermeture de notre site de compostage local, nous avons cherché des alternatives et, avons alors réalisé que la seule véritable solution serait de développer un nouveau site de compostage. Après le site du sud-ouest, le prochain site qui produit du compost de qualité agricole le plus proche est situé à plus d’une heure de route de Montréal, et applique des frais importants pour les résidus alimentaires qu’il reçoit. Nous voulons continuer à composter aussi localement, économiquement et écologiquement que possible, et nous voulons continuer à fournir à la population un compost d’excellente qualité qui permettra de cultiver dans la ville. Nous avons rencontré de nombreux groupes, comme les gens du Mouvement Valhalla, qui reconnaissent la valeur du compost et nous aident dans notre quête; celle de développer un nouveau site de compostage. Un bon nombre d’options intéressantes est disponible quant aux lieux où nous pourrions établir notre site mais ceci demande, bien sur, des sommes importantes afin de pouvoir financer les plans d'aménagement, le développement, et l'équipement. 
Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour récolter $200,000 afin de développer notre nouveau site. Nous utiliserons cet argent pour : - Continuer la recherche et le développement du nouveau site, ce qui comprend des ingénieurs-conseils, plans et permis.- Améliorer la rentabilité de nos camions, en augmentant leur capacité, et en les convertissant à l’huile végétale usée/biodiésel, que nous avons déjà commencé à collecter, filtrer et tester. C’est un excellent moyen pour réduire nos émissions de polluants et nos coûts, tout en continuant à collecter et à transporter les résidus alimentaires pour le traitement, pendant que nous développons un nouveau site. Une fois que notre site sera prêt, ces camions seront toujours parfaitement adaptés!- Acheter l’équipement qui nous est essentiel pour commencer les opérations sur le nouveau site, le plus important étant d’acheter un tracteur.- Si l'arrondissement du sud-ouest a besoin de soutien financièr afin de garder ouvert leur site de compostage, nous ferons notre possible pour contribuer de cette façon à la survie et succès de leur site.


Qu'arrive t-il après?


Nous travaillons actuellement sur un partenariat avec des groupes qui souhaitent que nous créerions un site de compostage sur des terrains qui sont d’ores et déjà disponibles et qui n’ont pas besoin d’être achetés. Cela aidera à maintenir les coûts de notre projet à un niveau minimum, puisque que le terrain représente, bien sur, une dépense considérable. Et pourtant, il y a tellement de résidus alimentaires produits par la ville de Montréal, et un tel besoin en compost fini pour pouvoir cultiver des aliments sains, que nous chercherons éventuellement à procurer un autre terrain pour pouvoir véritablement répondre à la demande. Une fois que cette campagne de levée de fonds sera terminée, nous commençerons à se préparer pour de investissement d’impact environnemental, dans le but de récolter davantage de fonds afin de continuer à développer notre modèle de compostage durable.


Qu'est-ce que c'est l'investissement d'impact? "Les investissements d'impact sont des montants placés dans des sociétés, des organismes et des fonds dans le but de produire un impact social et environnemental mesurable parallèlement à leur rendement financier." (www.thegiin.org, http://www.mcconnellfoundation.ca/fr/)
Seulement 10-15% de la matière organique générée par les citoyens de la Ville de Montréal est présentement compostée, et le reste se retrouve toujours dans les dépotoirs. La Ville ne planifie pas d’offrir de collecte résidentielle de la matière organique à travers toute la ville avant 2019, et même à ce moment là, il n’y aura pas de collecte organisée pour les commerces, entreprises, écoles et institutions. Il y aura donc toujours un approvisionnement abondant de matière organique à composter sur notre site.
Aidez Montréal à composter en aidant Compost Montréal! Nous apprécions votre soutien et nous espérons vous voir à notre nouveau site bientôt!



Prêt pour les récompenses? Cliquez ici! Vous souhaitez en apprendre davantage? Continuez! 
                                                                    ------------------

Comment nous avons commencé

Compost Montréal est né en juillet 2007 avec un vélo et une remorque.
 Stephen McLeod savait que lorsque les résidus alimentaires vont à la 
poubelle, ils finissent dans des sites d’enfouissement, causant la 
création de gaz à effet de serre connus pour leurs rôles dans le 
réchauffement et les changements climatiques. Il savait aussi que le compost est un moyen naturel d’enrichir le sol afin
 de cultiver de la nouvelle nourriture, et que les engrais chimiques que nous utilisons 
sont doucement en train de détruire notre sol et de polluer notre 
environnement.



Montréal n’avait pas de service municipal de collecte 
de résidus alimentaires, donc Stephen décida d’agir. Il commença par 
récupérer les résidus alimentaires de ses voisins, en utilisant une 
remorque attachée à l’arrière de son vélo, puis il les déposait dans une
 compostière à petite échelle, mise en place par le groupe 
environnemental Éco-Quartier. Stephen découvrit assez vite que l’arrondissement du sud-ouest de Montréal (où il vit toujours et où nos bureaux sont situés) exploitait un site de compostage à moyenne échelle dans
 le même secteur. Il leur proposa d’ajouter les résidus alimentaires 
riches en nutriments qu’il récoltait, et ils ont accepté! C’est comme 
cela que Compost Montréal est né.

À propos du site de compostage du sud-ouest

Nous avons été incroyablement chanceux d’avoir eu accès à ce site pendant les 7 dernières années. Il est situé à 5 minutes de nos bureaux et seulement 6 kilomètres du centre ville de Montréal, ce qui en fait une extraordinaire ressource pour la ville, quelque chose qui ne peut être trouvé nulle part ailleurs.
Faisant face à des problèmes d’espace liés à la démolition de l’échangeur Turcot (une partie importante de l’infrastructure de l’autoroute du centre-ville), l’arrondissement Sud-ouest a récemment annoncé l'arrêt de ses activités de compostage, afin de transformer l'espace utilisé en aire d'entreposage pour les équipements de la voirie.Grâce au soutien de milliers de citoyens, et à la réticence de l’arrondissement du Sud-ouest de fermer leur site, (une grande fierté pour l'arrondissment et le seul dans son genre, ouvert depuis plus de 20 ans) la fermeture a été reportée de quelques mois. Nous travaillons avec l’administration de l'arrondissement pour garder le site ouvert à une certaine capacité, mais l'arrondissement se trouve dans une position difficile et, même s'il reste de l'espoir, il y'a toujours possibilité que le site soit forcé de fermer dans un avenir très proche. Même si cela nous briserait le cœur, et qu’une telle ressource ne pourra jamais être remplacée, pour la ville ou pour nos opérations, nous sommes déterminés à continuer de composter, et nous pensons qu’avec votre aide, nous pouvons transformer cette situation en une opportunité. 
Nous espérons que le site du sud-ouest reste ouvert pour toujours. Mais nous savons maintenant que pour garantir le futur de Compost Montréal et pour continuer à aider les Montréalais à composter, il faut ouvrir un nouveau site de compostage. 
À propos des résidus alimentaires et du compost
Lorsque les résidus alimentaires sont envoyés à l’enfouissement, ils sont mélangés à différentes autres sortes de déchets, et se décomposent sans oxygène. Cela provoque des émanations de méthane (un gaz à effet de serre 25 fois plus puissant que le CO2), l’écoulement de liquide toxique, et des fois cela peut mettre des décennies à se décomposer complètement. Séparer les résidus alimentaires des autres déchets, et les laisser se composter correctement avec de l’oxygène permet de les transformer en un compost riche en nutriments en seulement une année ou moins. Le compost est un fantastique amendement du sol qui répare et enrichie la terre, et élimine le besoin d’utiliser des produits synthétiques à base chimique, néfastes pour l’environnement et pour notre santé. Par conséquent, composter vos restes n’évite pas seulement l’émission de gaz à effet de serre, cela crée aussi un sol plus riche, qui peut être utilisé pour à nouveau faire pousser de la nourriture saine!Seulement de 10-15% des résidus alimentaires produits à Montréal sont actuellement compostés et le reste est toujours envoyé à l’enfouissement. Nous voulons aider à détourner de plus en plus de matière hors des sites d’enfouissement et à les transformer plutôt en un compost d’excellente qualité. 

À propos de Solutions ResponsablesAprès quelques années de collecte de compost, nous avons créé une société mère, appelée Solutions Responsables, pour lancer de nouveaux projets socialement et environnementalement responsables. Pour l’instant, nous avons créé BioMobile, une épicerie en ligne avec service de livraison, axée sur des produits biologiques, locaux, et certifiés commerce équitable, et qui encourage un monde plus durable. Apart du fait que vous pouvez toujours comander de l'huile de foie de morue Green Pasture, le projet est autrement en pause pour que nous puissions nous consacrer entièrement à Compost Montréal. Vous pouvez toujours aller sur notre site web si vous le voulez et laisser vos coordonnées si l’idée d’un tel service vous intéresse.Nous avons aussi développé un programme de recyclage des huiles usées pour les clients restaurateurs de Compost Montréal. L’huile que nous récoltons est utilisée pour fabriquer du biodiésel, alimenter nos camions, et réduire la dépendance sur les produits pétroliers. Il y a une multitude d’autres projets sociaux et environnementaux que nous souhaiterions développer et soutenir mais le moyen le plus sûr pour garantir le futur de ces projets, c’est de s’assurer que Compost Montréal, notre projet le plus important et celui grâce auquel nous avons tout commencé, peut survivre et continuer à se développer, même durant cette période tumultueuse.Et pour faire cela, nous avons besoin de vous!

Our trucks have always had names, usually based on the stories told 
to us by the previous owners, and usually having to do with animals: The
 Moose, Big Red, The Bull, Snow Dog… and with this level of 
contribution, we'd like to give you the opportunity to name one of our 
next trucks! We will display the name you choose on the truck itself,
 and the story we will tell about this truck will be all about you and 
the help that you've given us at this critical stage of our growth. Nos camions ont toujours eu des noms, souvent trouvés grâce aux histoires que nous racontent leur précédents propriétaires, et souvent en rapport avec des aminaux: l'Orignal, Big Red, le Buffle, le Chien de traineau ... Et à ce niveau de participation, nous aimerions vous donner l'opportunité de nommer un de nos prochains camions! Nous afficherons le nom que vous avez choisi directement sur le camion, et l'histoire que nous raconterons sur ce camion vous concernera entièrement, et expliquera comment vous nous avez aidés à ce moment clef de notre croissance.

story:
We manufacture "Earth Friendly" chemical free pet safe bed frames and products that creates an efficient way of reclaiming and re-purposing unique woods.

The weathered cedar and pine fencing we use stood strong and sturdy for over thirty years and now is the time to replace it.  Our highly skilled craftsman are reclaiming and re-purposing this beautiful material to create unique and environmentally-friendly furniture for your best friends.

Reclaiming Cedar and Pine fencing that has come from the heart of the American pioneer is creating an industrial wave in the field of sustainability and reshaping America.  Decades of exposure to the natural elements and increment weather have created stellar beauty in the grain, and natural coloring.  The durability of these woods tells a story of our history and heritage of days gone by.  The aged wood, germinated and grown in the very depths of American soil, has no equal to any wood produced today. 

Cedar wood has many advantages.  Using Cedar is wise because it’s naturally insect and rot resistant. Since it is naturally water-resistant, it doesn't require any treatment before being used outside and when allowed to weather naturally, cedar will develop a unique grayish-color. No harsh chemical treatment is necessary.  These properties make it a perfect choice to reclaim and re purpose.  Most varieties of cedar are vividly grained, with a variety of colors.

The Pine fencing also has its very own and unique beauty from age and the increments of nature.  Because it has never been treated or had harsh chemicals applied, it too becomes part of our environmentally friendly projects.



What We Need & What You Get

  We need funds to develop the wood shop with more efficient tools and equipment and the same for the seamstress division.

  Web Master Services to develop a top-notch website which is currently under construction.

  Promotional funds to market products and educate people about our "Earth Friendly" products. 

  If we do not reach our goal, funds we get will be used for shop tools, and pay contractors to continue building the bed frames.

  Many perks are available to you for your contribution from $15 to $1000.

  You will get recognition on our website and through our associations as helping us create an "Earth Friendly" product.

The Impact your contribution will make!!

These beautiful frames have an eclectic upscale feel.  The luxurious old cedar and pine wood frames take your best friends back to nature and dreams of sleeping and running free through forests of green in wild flower filled meadows.

  Your contribution will benefit the earth by helping us rescue the beautiful old fencing from a landfill or being burned. 

  Your contribution also benefits pets for they have a safe "chemical free" peaceful place to rest.

  This is one of the most exciting and rewarding projects any of us have taken on and the up side is we are helping the environment and your "best friends".  We are all expert business owners in the field of fine craftsmanship in wood, sewing and business ownership.  Combined experience of 94 years.       

Other Ways You Can Help

  • For all you folks who cannot contribute please be our voice!!
  • Here is a call to all you folks who like the idea of recycling and re-purposing      useable items that would have otherwise ended up in a landfill or burned.  You are also helping the pet industry by offering them a "chemical free" safe place to rest.
  • All our products are Made in Montana with USA organic products .  Please get the word out about our project and let your friends and associates know about our campaign.
  • Indiegogo has very useful share tools!! Please Share!

story:
What is this about?

‘An Inconvenient Truth’ made the issue of global warming a recognized problem worldwide. Scientific communities’ alarm about the melting polar ice caps and rising seawater levels initially seemed unreal but hurricane Sandy, cyclone Phailin, recent typhoon in Philippines, and many other natural disasters are a living proof of this grim reality. We now know that climate change is “REAL”, environmental impact is “SEVERE”, and the need of action is “URGENT”.

In this situation, one often asks – “What can I do to make a difference?” I have my question answered in form of an incredible opportunity to travel to Antarctica to experience the last great wilderness on earth and to learn how climate change is affecting it. I am accepted as one of thirty young people from around the world into the 2014 Antarctica Youth Ambassadors Program (AYAP) with Robert Swan and his company 2041.

Antarctica is the last great-untouched wilderness on earth, and I cannot wait to go and experience it for myself. Yet Antarctica is currently facing some of the worst effects of climate change, and by attending this expedition I am going to learn the skills to be able to bring back my knowledge and share it with my community. 

Who am I?

My name is Ashish Saxena and I am a 32-year-old nature enthusiast from India. I am currently staying in Phoenix, Arizona, USA for the past 5 years. I graduated with a Bachelors degree in Technology in 2004, majoring in Electronics Communication & Renewable Energy. Currently I am pursuing further studies in the field of Climate Change, Renewable Energy, and Sustainability. 

In 2012, I was selected for NREL’s Energy Leadership Institute Program which saw me study and learn about renewable energy and energy efficiency from experts.This was a life-changing experience and I returned back determined to make a difference. 

I care deeply about the environment and volunteer my time in learning about Climate Change and sharing my knowledge to help make a difference. Through my past experiences in raising awareness about climate change, I understand that communicating to people about the environment can be hard, as you need to tell an engaging story to people to want them keep reading, and I believe that going to Antarctica and seeing climate change and environmental damage on the front line will help me to become a better communicator.

About The Expedition: 

Polar explorer, environmental leader and public speaker Robert Swan, OBE, the first person in history to walk to both the North and South poles founded 2041.

Swan has dedicated his life to the preservation of Antarctica by the promotion of recycling, renewable energy and sustainability to combat the effects of climate change.

Each year since 2003 Swan has led expeditions down to Antarctica, taking with him an international team of young people, teachers, scientists, environmentalists and corporate leaders as part of his ‘Leadership on the Edge’ program and this year the expedition will run from March 8th – March 21st 2014.

In the year 2041 the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty could potentially be modified or amended. This treaty currently forbids mining and drilling in the Antarctic, but come 2041 this could all change and Antarctica and the waters surrounding the continent may no longer be protected.

Robert Swan and 2041’s aim is to work towards the continuing protection of the Antarctic Treaty so that the last great wilderness on earth is never exploited through education and implementation of renewable energy.

Post Antarctica: The Mission I-M-POSSIBLE

As part of my application to attend the expedition, I had to create a project plan that I would implement upon my return from Antarctica to further spread the word on renewable energy and the threat facing Antarctica.

As an avid traveler, writer, and communicator I am passionate to spread awareness about the environment in effective and engaging ways. The project that I am committing to post expedition is to communicate about Antarctica and renewable energy projects around the world. You see all around the world there are young people, such as those attending the 2014 AYAP, who are creating change in their communities about the way others see climate change. For example, past participants from India helped setting up a renewable e-Base in Ladakh, India and a young Swedish girl helped to put solar cookers on the roofs of the favelas in Brazil.

These stories of young people making a difference are what I am going to travel and write about, including the great stories that are here in our local communities in USA and/or India.

I am going to publish these stories to get the word out about young people making positive change in their local communities, and also film these stories and make them into a documentary. A mission which is difficult but surely not impossible.

The Impact

The environment belongs to everyone, but this is especially true for Antarctica. Antarctica has no claim on it by any country or indigenous people. Antarctica belongs to all of us, and therefore it is all of our jobs to protect it. If we don’t work to protect Antarctica then we are going to be faced with a monumental crisis.

Antarctica holds 70% of the world’s fresh water, and if this melts……well let’s not even think about it.

In 2041 the Antarctic Treaty is going to expire, and if it is not renewed 100% then Antarctica might become open to mining and drilling by companies looking to exploit the natural reserves.

This might lead to the catastrophe that we are currently seeing in the Arctic currently.

We need to make sure that renewable energy is so common, that by the year 2041, no one wants to go to Antarctica and spoil the pristine wilderness by mining.

Why you should sponsor me?

Everyone wants to help the environment, but not everyone can actually go to Antarctica to do so.

Well I want to act as an ambassador for my country/community to go and get firsthand knowledge. I will bring back the skills that I will acquire so that everyone can benefit.

Through my project, continuous learning  and writing I will be able to pass on everything I have learnt to even more people outside of my local community, so that everyone has a chance to learn and feel inspired from my journey.

I think as young people we are really powerful to create change because we are passionate and believe that anything is possible.

So if you too believe that this expedition is possible, and that this is an incredible opportunity, be sure to help me reach it!

How you can help?

Getting to Antarctica is quite expensive as you can imagine, and I need all of the help that I can get to make my dream come true.

The total cost of the expedition is $25,000.00 (including expedition fees, flight tickets, and other essentials for the trip)

BUT if you are able to help me raise at least 1/5th of my goal, $5,000.00, then I will be able to secure my place on the trip 100%.

I am hoping to get help from sponsors to fund the remaining part of the expedition costs.

There are great incentives to donate to my campaign, so I hope you do and are able to come along on this journey with me!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask your friends and family to get the word out and share this campaign through email, Facebook and Twitter.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Become active in your local community and make the change to live as sustain-ably as possible.
  • Think about investing in renewable energy for your house?

Want to learn more?

Connect with me:

Website: http://toantarcticaandbeyond.wordpress.com/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/toAntarcticaAndBeyond

Twitter:@AntarcticaDream
story_txt:
What is this about?
‘An Inconvenient Truth’
made the issue of global warming a recognized problem worldwide. Scientific
communities’ alarm about the melting polar ice caps and rising seawater levels initially
seemed unreal but hurricane Sandy, cyclone Phailin, recent typhoon in
Philippines, and many other natural disasters are a living proof of this grim
reality. We now know that climate change is “REAL”, environmental impact is “SEVERE”,
and the need of action is “URGENT”.
In this situation, one often asks – “What can I do to make a
difference?” I have my question answered in form of an incredible opportunity to travel to Antarctica to experience the last
great wilderness on earth and to learn how climate change is affecting it. I am
accepted as one of thirty young people from around the world into the 2014
Antarctica Youth Ambassadors Program (AYAP) with Robert Swan and his company
2041.
Antarctica is the last great-untouched
wilderness on earth, and I cannot wait to go and experience it for myself. Yet
Antarctica is currently facing some of the worst effects of climate change, and
by attending this expedition I am going to learn the skills to be able to bring
back my knowledge and share it with my community. 
Who am I?
My name is Ashish Saxena and I am a
32-year-old nature enthusiast from India. I am currently staying in Phoenix, Arizona,
USA for the past 5 years. I graduated with a Bachelors degree in Technology in
2004, majoring in Electronics Communication & Renewable Energy. Currently I
am pursuing further studies in the field of Climate Change, Renewable Energy,
and Sustainability. 
In 2012, I was selected for NREL’s Energy
Leadership Institute Program which saw me study and learn about renewable
energy and energy efficiency from experts.This was a life-changing experience and I
returned back determined to make a difference. 
I care deeply about the environment and
volunteer my time in learning about Climate Change and sharing my knowledge to
help make a difference. Through my past experiences in raising awareness about
climate change, I understand that communicating to people about the environment
can be hard, as you need to tell an engaging story to people to want them keep
reading, and I believe that going to Antarctica and seeing climate change and
environmental damage on the front line will help me to become a better
communicator.

the first person in history to walk to both the North and South poles founded

story:
Continuing

Hello and Thank you for looking to support our campaign! The campaign has ended on Indiegogo but we are continuing our campaign on our website, please click the link below to continue to our website.

https://www.ibafriends.org/ibafriends64

 

 

Short Summary

Friends of the IBA (FIBA) is the only nonprofit acquiring and permanently protecting critical habitat for New York’s endangered and at-risk grassland birds.  FIBA owns 14 acres of critical habitat and has a conservation agreement on an adjacent 50 acres. Our Alfred Z. Solomon Grassland Bird Viewing Area (AZS) provides the only universally accessible bird viewing area in the region.

We’re asking you to help us raise $60,000 so we can purchase and permanently protect another 64 acres of critical habitat!  State biologists say the Washington County Grasslands Important Bird Area (IBA) is critical to the survival of Short-eared owls in New York State. It provides important habitat for 10 of 11 of NY’s most imperiled grassland birds, including state endangered Short-eared owls, Eastern meadowlarks, Upland sandpipers, Northern harriers, American kestrels, Grasshopper sparrows and Bobolinks. It supports over 100 other bird and animal species, including the state bird, the Eastern bluebird.

The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) has listed the Washington County Grasslands as a conservation priority in the state’s Open Space Plan.  Yet less than 300 acres of this 2,000-acre grassland have been protected.  Hundreds of acres have already been lost to development, which is why FIBA’s work is so vital!

What We Need & What You Get

FIBA needs to raise $60,000 to close on this project. These funds will allow us to purchase 64 acres of critical habitat in the Washington County Grasslands IBA. Total acquisition cost is $125,000; we’ve raised $65,000 and are trying to raise the final $60,000 in 60 days so we can permanently protect this critical land for Short-eared owls and other arctic visitors this winter!

Benefits you will receive when you contribute to this campaign: 1) knowing you helped ensure Short-eared owls will not disappear from New York State; 2) protecting and preserving this vital resource and NY’s biodiversity; 3) FIBA Membership – benefits include free guided bird walks and tours, discounted Winter Raptor Fest admission and more!  You will also receive the benefits listed under each giving level as a special thank-you for your generous contribution.

If we do not make the campaign goal we will: 1) escrow funds raised and continue fundraising for this project through 2018; 2) Apply to the landowner for additional time if we do not reach our goal by December 2018; 3) Failure is NOT an option.

The Impact

Grassland birds provide FREE ecological services. They control insects and rodents that damage and destroy crops. Crop yields will decrease if we lose our grassland birds. This will encourage growers to apply MORE toxic chemicals to crops, putting MORE toxic chemicals in our food supply and environment. Finally, food costs will increase as the cost of production increases.

Grassland birds share their habitat with hundreds of other species. Bees and butterflies pollinate crops such as fruits and vegetables. Deer, turkey, fox, rabbits, and dozens of other animals depend on grasslands for food and cover. Preserving NY’s biodiversity will benefit everyone, not just the kids and adults who will come to see and experience Short-eared owls and other grassland birds in their natural habitat.  

FIBA has a proven track record of successful land conservation projects. We’ve acquired and permanently protected 14 acres of critical habitat and conserved another 50 acres through a conservation agreement. We’re already seeing increased numbers of at-risk grassland bird species on conserved lands. We’re also assisting DEC with the conservation of 180 acres nearby. This project, combined with our 64-acre purchase, will almost double the acres of conserved land in the Washington County Grasslands!

FIBA has received and successfully implemented grants up to $75,000 from the New York State Conservation Partnership Program*, Alfred Z. Solomon Charitable Trust, Norcross Wildlife Foundation and private corporations. We’ve been recognized by the New York State Ornithological Association for our work to conserve grassland birds and have strong support from NYSDEC, Land Trust Alliance, landowners, residents, government agencies, other nonprofits and elected officials. 

*funded through NY’s Environmental Protection Fund (EPF) and administered by the Land Trust Alliance and DEC

Risks & Challenges

FIBA's major challenge for this project is to raise $60,000 in 60 days.  We believe we can do it if we can reach enough people. That’s why we’re asking you to post and pass along the link to this campaign to your friends! 

Our greatest challenge overall is our need to fundraise for every land purchase. Development pressure in this economically depressed rural is high. Many small farmers would like to see their lands conserved but they do not have the financial resources to give the land away. We’ve seen hundreds of acres lost to development because we did not have the capacity to make those purchases. Time is not on our side. 

The fact that only 15% of the land in the 2,000 acre target area is protected is both a threat and an opportunity.  We have opportunities to conserve another 300 acres of critical habitat in the Washington County Grasslands from willing landowners. We will continue to fundraise for additional land purchases and an endowment for stewardship and future land acquisitions.  Please MAKE A DONATION today!

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to support this project but can’t contribute right now?

  1. Help spread the word about our campaign to save critical habitat for NY’s endangered Short-eared owls and other at-risk grassland birds. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to pass the word on. 
  2. We’re always looking for volunteers who share our passion for the birds and our mission and want to help.  We need people to help with stewardship, fundraising, publicity and a variety of other tasks. Call us at: 518-499-0012

story:
Short Summary

Are you passionate about making a difference in our environment? I am!

My name is Carol Hosley.
I'm the owner of Consignment CAT.
I've created a unique upscale store to encourage women to shop resale.
Resale is a growing trend that helps the environment by reducing landfill waste and reducing the manufacturing burdens on the earth's resources.
I've been doing this successfully for 10 years and have focused on being an environmental influence in my community. I also encourage shoppers to bring their own shopping bag or carry their purchase to their car without a bag to reduce plastic pollution.
Contributing to the sign campaign will allow us to replace the eyesore ("messin' up the scenery") of the empty rusty pylon sign in front of our building AND it will further the store's success and the consignor's success by capitalizing on the traffic that drives by the store and never notices it.

We've partnered with Signs Etcetera, Inc. in Dothan to create and install this beautiful sign for us. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need $2800 to replace the roadside signage on Rucker Boulevard. The reason the cost is so high is because there is a city ordinance to reclad the existing sign poles ("do this, don't do that") There is no way around it.  Simply painting it is not an option. Almost $1000 of this cost is exclusively for the cladding which I was not expecting.

  • I'd like to raise the extra funds by offering some fun perks for my customers, consignors, and special friends who would like to help!
  • Should the campaign exceed the total needed, the extra funds will be applied to add graphics for the front windows that face Rucker Boulevard.
  • We'll have a big celebration party when the sign is complete. We might even christen it with a bottle of bubbly!
     

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some of you won't be able to contribute to this campain and that is totally okay! I appreciate your interest. There are other ways to help.

1. Please come in and shop. If you haven't been to the store, you'll be pleasantly surprised.
2. Ladies, if your closet is too crowded, clean it out and let us sell your gently used clothes for you. Go to www.theconsignmentcat.com for more information on how to consign.
2. Expand our social media presence by following us on Facebook and Instagram. Interacting with us on Social Media platforms is a HUGE boost for us and places our posts in more people's feeds.
3. Please share this with others if you can!

Thanks!
