Ronn holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree and a Master of Science degree. He worked for many years as a partner with Deloitte, Canada’s largest professional services firm.  Ronn serves as the Treasurer of the Saskatchewan Environmental Society.  


Joe Schmutz, PhD has just retired after many years of serving as a faculty member in the School of Environment and Sustainability at the University of Saskatchewan. His primary expertise is in the area of ecology and biodiversity. He owns a small consulting business, Prairie Ecodesign Ltd. Joe also serves on the Saskatchewan Environmental Society board of directors. 


Bill Wardell is a partner in the Saskatoon law firm of Wardell Gillis and farms near Floral, Saskatchewan, just south of Saskatoon. He helped to establish the legal aid system in Saskatchewan and taught law at the College of Law for many years. He has served on the boards of SaskTel and the Saskatoon Co-op. Bill also serves on the Saskatchewan Environmental Society board of directors. 


In addition to their widespread experience, Ronn, Joe and Bill all have solar installations on their own properties. Ronn meets the entire electrical needs of his home using solar energy, and Bill meets the entire electrical needs of his home and farm with solar power. Joe meets his domestic hot water needs with solar energy. All three have significant experience with the challenges that comes with solar installations, and with the maintenance of solar systems, as well as with the tremendous benefits of solar energy.
Thank you for supporting solar in Saskatchewan!

story:
This campaign has finished. Visit our Campaign for 2016!



What is Project SNOWstorm

Created in the winter of 2013-14 to study the largest invasion of snowy owls in the East in nearly a century, Project SNOWstorm is a unique collaboration of more than 40 scientists, bird-banders and wildlife health professionals, all working as volunteers. This winter, with a second major irruption taking shape (especially in the Midwest), our team is expanding its research into this beautiful and mysterious raptor, using state-of-the-art telemetry, banding, DNA and isotope analysis, toxicology screening and more -- all funded by the public.

There's a lot more about this project and its goals at projectsnowstorm.org.

What We Do, and How You Can Help

Last winter, the Indiegogo community gave us the opportunity to launch SNOWstorm in record time -- and with breathtaking results. We tagged 22 snowy owls, from Minnesota to Massachusetts, using GPS/GSM transmitters. Through interactive, near-real-time maps, donors were able to track the wanderings of these birds along with us, in unprecedented, 3D detail -- as they hunted sea ducks at night over the open Atlantic Ocean, or traveled far out into the frozen expanses of the Great Lakes.

In spring, the tagged owls moved back to the Arctic -- and some of them are now returning south, downloading a treasure-trove of stored data detailing their travels through the remote Canadian North.

Because irruptions are usually sporadic, we expected a quite winter this year. Instead, thousands of snowy owls have again invaded the Great Lakes, northern prairies and Northeast -- and we need your help to continue this ground-breaking study. We hope to tag an additional 15-20 snowy owls this winter, and expand the other research we've begun.


What Your Contribution Does

Every penny of your contribution goes straight into the research -- no one associated with SNOWstorm is taking any kind of stipend or salary.

The transmitters are the most expensive element. Even with an extremely generous discount from the manufacturer, Cellular Tracking Technologies, they still cost $3,000 each. But unlike satellite transmitters, which rack up thousands of dollars annually in additional satellite fees, these transmitters work through the cell phone network for basically nothing. And being solar-powered, they last for years.

We must also pay for lab work and testing fees. We're exploring the genetics of snowy owls by examining their DNA, and analyzing the stable chemical isotopes in their feathers, blood and tissues, which tell us about their place of origin and diet over time.

Our team of wildlife pathologists and veterinarians conduct necropsies on owls that are killed in accidents or found dead, and while they're donating their time, there are also lab costs for toxicology, parasitology and histology tests. Your donation helps cover all of this.

What Do You Get for Helping

Besides knowing you're participating directly in ground-breaking research, we have some cool perks, from bumper stickers, to original photographs, to signed copies of a new (not-yet-released!) book on owls.

And if you can't contribute directly, we'd still love to have your support and enthusiasm. Tell your friends about Project SNOWstorm, and use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread to word.


Frequently Asked Questions, Answered!

Does this hurt the owls?

The last thing we want to do is put snowy owls at risk. The capture process is quick and harmless, and backpack harnesses and lightweight transmitters similar to what we're using have been shown to have no effect on either the survival rate or breeding success of these owls. (see reference 1)

A lot of people worry that snowy owls in these irruptions are forced down here by hunger, are must be slowly starving to death. So this must stress them, right? In fact, our research has found that most of the irrupting snowy owls are healthy, with normal weight and fat reserves. If we catch an owl that's underweight or shows signs of illness, we obviously won't tag it.

Some of the thousands of snowy owls in this irruption will certainly perish, but most of those will succumb to vehicle collisions (including with planes, since many hang out at airports), rodenticide poisoning, electrocution on power lines and other unnatural hazards. In fact, our project will help us better understand what threatens snowy owls on the wintering grounds, because we're working with wildlife health specialists to test them for toxins, and to perform necropsies on those that are found dead.

1. Therrien, J-F., G. Gauthier and J. Bêty. 2012. Survival and reproduction of adult snowy owls tracked by satellite. Journal of Wildlife Management 76(8):1562-1567.

Since these are GPS-GSM transmitters, what happens when the bird is out of cellular coverage?

The transmitters use signals from the orbiting GPS satellite system to regularly collect precise information about the bird's location, at preset intervals around the clock, then transmits it once or twice a day via the cellular network. If the bird is outside cell range, the transmitters can store up to 100,000 locations - potentially years' worth, since we can reprogram the units remotely once the owls are ready to head back to the Arctic. They will continue to transmit as they head through southern Canada - and if they come anywhere within cell range in future winters, in places like Newfoundland, southern Labrador or the Canadian prairies, we'll get an enormous trove of data, collected via GPS during their time in the Arctic.

What does the “high resolution” data look like?
The degree of accuracy of this data is beyond anything available with older satellite transmitters. When the transmitter is triangulating its position from several GPS satellites, it can provide a location accurate to a fraction of a meter. Viewing the data through Google Earth, we've been able to tell (and confirm with ground observers) that an owl was perched on a particular piling in a dock, or the south side (rather than the north side) of the roof of a beachfront house.

Read more about the transmitters we are using.


How can this data tell us anything about foraging behavior?
As we test the capabilities of these transmitters, and especially the overnight life of the solar-charged battery, we're steadily reducing the interval at which we program the units to take GPS locations. This ever-finer-grained data is giving us our first look at the nocturnal life of snowy owls, especially where and when they're hunting. One of the surprises already has been how much time coastal birds spend hunting offshore, presumably preying on sleeping ducks. Similarly, we've been able to see how inland birds are using irrigation ditches, roadsides and other habitat for their hunting. Because these transmitters communicate by cell phone, we can reprogram them on the fly - literally - with instructions to increase or decrease the number of fixes we want them to take.

How will this translate into real conservation activities?
Up to now, no one has really known much at all about the winter behavior of snowy owls, especially after dark. Questions we hope to answer include where these irruptive birds are coming from; how far and how fast they move across the landscape during the winter; what kinds of habitats they're using, and how that differs from daytime to darkness; and what threats they face while here in the south, including what their fate may be following a big irruption.  These transmitters provide the first look at the behavior of individual wintering snowy owls in a way that will shed light on many aspects of their ecology, which will ultimately better inform conservation efforts. And this tracking program is just part of a larger study to look at multiple aspects of their ecology and physiology.

How are these transmitters mounted to the birds, and would they impair their wing movements?
The transmitters are held in place with a kind of backpack harness, made of low-friction Teflon® tape, that is a design that's been used for decades on many birds of prey, including large owls. Similar harnesses have been used with satellite transmitters on snowy owls, with no effect on the owls' survival or breeding success. They certainly do not restrict their flight - the first owl we tagged flew nearly 200 miles in a couple of weeks.

Will you be banding any owls in Florida, the Carolinas and Georgia (if they show up that far south)?

The farthest-south snowies present a couple of issues. One is simply that these birds are enormous birding celebrities, attracting a tremendous amount of attention from the birding community, media and general public. But more significantly, there seems to be evidence that the snowies that move far, far out of range are also going to be the most physiologically stretched, and may be at greater risk from ailments like aspergillosis that are less of a hazard in more northerly climes, and in birds that haven't been pushed as far.

We are actually torn about what to do about these owls. There's the assumption that their survival rate isn't good, but then, that used to be the assumption about snowies in places like the Northeast, where (thanks to banding and telemetry by Norman Smith and Tom McDonald) we now know they have a very high survival and return rate. Tagging one of the southern birds might help answer that question. But if we tagged one of those birds and something happened to it - even if it wasn't associated with the tagging - it's likely there would be a lot of recrimination and anger from people who would reflexively blame the research. At the moment the point is moot, because we don't have any collaborating researchers or agencies in those southern locations interested in tagging snowies.

Who are we?

Partners

  • Project Owlnet
  • Ned Smith Center for Nature and Art
  • Cellular Tracking Technologies
  • Pennsylvania Game Commission
  • Maryland Department of Natural Resources
  • Hawk Mountain Sanctuary
  • Massachusetts Audubon
  • The Maryland Zoo in Baltimore
  • Black Swamp Bird Observatory, Oak Harbor, OH
  • New Jersey Audubon's Cape May Bird Observatory, Cape May, NJ

Major donors

  • RJM Foundation
  • Wendy McLean
  • Kathy Lambrow, Michael Reilly
  • Several anonymous donors

Sponsors

  • Cellular Tracking Technologies (in-kind donations)
  • Delmarva Ornithological Society
  • Wisconsin Society for Ornithology
  • Natural resources Foundation of Wisconsin
  • Kirtland Bird Club and Toledo Naturalists' Association
  • Pennsylvania Society for Ornithology
  • Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources
  • Alma College, MI
  • Madison Audubon Society, WI
  • Braddock Bay Raptor Research, Honeoye Falls, NY
  • David Allen Sibley
  • Maryland Ornithological Society
  • American Birding Association
  • Bird Watcher’s Digest
  • Hummer/Bird Study Group
  • Paul Riss, PRBY Apparel, Ontario, Canada
  • Tom Johnson, Hummelstown, PA

Team members include:

  • David F. Brinker, Maryland Department of Natural Resources
  • Scott Weidensaul, Ned Smith Center for Nature and Art, Millersburg, PA
  • Steve Huy, Project Owlnet, Frederick, MD
  • Michael Lanzone and Andrew McGann, Cellular Tracking Technologies, Somerset, PA
  • Don Crockett, Great Blue Media Works, New Britain, CT
  • Trish Miller, West Virginia University
  • Norman Smith, Massachusetts Audubon
  • Jean-François Therrien, Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, Kempton, PA
  • Drew Weber, BirdsEye Project and Nemesis Bird, Syracuse, NY
  • Dan Brauning and Doug Gross, Pennsylvania Game Commission
  • Cindy Driscoll, DVM, Fish and Wildlife Health Program, MD DNR
  • Erica Miller, DVM, Tri-State Bird Rescue, Wilmington, DE
  • Sherrill Davison, University of Pennsylvania New Bolton Center, Kennett Square, PA
  • Glenn Proudfoot, Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY
  • Gene Jacobs, University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point
  • David LaPuma, NJ Audubon and Cape May Bird Observatory, WI
  • Tom McDonald, Rochester, NY
  • Frank Nicoletti, Hawk Ridge Bird Observatory, Duluth, MN
  • Eugene Potapov, Bryn Aythn College, PA
  • Mark Shieldcastle, Black Swamp Bird Observatory, Oak Harbor, OH
  • Nova McKentley and Chris Neri, Whitefish Point Bird Observatory, MI
  • Brian Washburn, USDA APHIS, Sandusky, OH
  • Allen Chartier, Inkster, MI
  • Tom Johnson, Hummelstown, PA
  • Alexis Dow Campbell, Ned Smith Center for Nature and Art

Looking for more?

There's a lot more information about snowy owls, this irruption and what we're doing through Project SNOWstorm at www.projectsnowstorm.org.

story:
For The Bees

Denton Apiaries seeks to help save the dwindling honey bee population by building a small scale, environmentally beneficial apiary (bee farm). Our goal is to approach bee keeping from a natural bee friendly, or apicentric, fashion in order to provide a healthy environment for honey bees. With a local, bee friendly keeping method, we hope to be a small yet effective part of protecting honey bees.

Our methods include:

  • Using Top Bar Hives to help facilitate a more natural environment for the bees.
  • Refraining from using chemicals, miticides or other unnatural methods often employed in commercial bee keeping.
  • Harvesting honey in a bee friendly manner. Seeing ourselves as stewards of the bees rather than "owners."
  • Packaging our honey and honey products in raw and natural ways, without commercial processing.
  • Being resourceful with all of our bee products and honey products. Recycling honey comb and wax into usable products such as soaps and candles.
  • Using our bees to help pollinate local crops.
  • Educating the community on the importance of honey bees.

With your contribution, you will help is in building a facility that will work to protect honey bees while producing natural and environmentally friendly products for all to enjoy. With our methods, we will be able to offer natural, raw honey, beeswax, beeswax soap, candles, etc. Part of the proceeds from the products we sell will be put towards the global effort to protect the honey bee.

What We Need & What You Get

We really don't need much! Here's a brief summary of what we need to make this project a reality:

  • New Top Bar Hives for the apiary. Each Top Bar Hive is approximately $100. We hope to purchase a total of 6 new hives.
  • A website from which to sell our products, including an option to subscribe to regular honey and honey product deliveries (lower 48 US states only).
  • An observational hive in order to facilitate educating people on the habits of bees.
  • For each level of financial contribution, we offer unique perks ranging from thank you cards, jars of honey, to an opportunity to participate in a honey harvest.
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal, every dollar that is contributed goes towards the purchase of hives and other equipment.

The Impact

By helping us build our apiary, you'll be helping the local environment:

  • One third of the food we eat is pollinated by bees. Without them, those foods couldn't grow. Our apiary would bring thousands of bees to our area, helping local farms.
  • The honey produced by our bees will not be commercially processed. It will be all natural and raw, maintaining the health benefits that are inherent to honey.
  • The honey bee population is dwindling globally. Even small gestures to help reverse that are invaluable.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you aren't able to contribute financially, you can still help:

  • Get the word out about our campaign!
  • You can share our campaign with your friends on social media!

story:
Short Summary

Irish Seed Savers Association was set up in 1991 to save Ireland's heritage and heirloom vegetable seeds, potatoes, grains and fruit trees from extinction.

Since then we have grown and grown and now have over 800 varieties of organic, open pollinated heritage seeds in our purpose built Seed Bank, together with the country's key orchards which hold the native Apple Tree Collection together with the country's only self-rooting orchard  here at Irish Seed Savers in County Clare. We also have over 50 varieties of potatoes, which is extremely important given Ireland's history of the Potato Famine, which occurred due to the devastation caused by potato blight; a virus which continues to devastate potato crops today. Then, almost everyone in Ireland grew only one variety, the Lumper potato, and that variety was destroyed by the blight which led to the Great famine. The Bute variety (grown in County Kerry) survived and saved countless souls. We now know that diversification of varieties prevents famines, but yet the world still suffers from famines and we still don't learn.

Unfortunately Irish Seed Savers, like many others have experienced a number of severe cuts over the past number of years and this together with the economic downturn  means that despite our best efforts the continued operations and very survival of Irish Seed Savers is in jeopardy. We have achieved a lot over the past number of years. We have created 20 beautiful acres of Organic Heritage Orchards, Seed Gardens and Woodlands for visitors. We have built Ireland's first National Seed Bank, open to the public, and making seed available to all. It is a living gene-bank,  where 800 varieties of heirloom seeds together with their stories have been collected and carefully grown out to bulk up the numbers. We share our skills and knowledge on seed saving and other sustainable living skills to thousands of children and adults through workshops, courses, camps and outreach programmes. This knowledge and seed base means that Ireland continues to have some control over its future food security in times of continued industrialisation of food and diminishing resources worldwide. Unless we all have the right and the opportunity to grow our own seed, save our own seed and share our seed we don't have food security. Empowering people to do that and save the heritage and heirloom varieties which grow best in Ireland, is what Irish Seed Savers does best. 

Please hep us continue. This appeal is to YOU, our friends and supporters and through you to all those interested in securing a sustainable future for Irish Seed Savers and the important work it undertakes on behalf of the people of Ireland.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of €250,000 ($333,000)  to ensure our survival and we need to raise €100,000 ($133,000) of this on Indiegogo. The money will be used as follows

  • €50,000 ($67,000) will be used to buy raw materials like rootstocks, pots, compost, tools, shop supplies so that we can grow our own sales and improve our future sustainability by making our seeds and trees available to YOU.
  • €50,000 ($67,000) will be used to finish our Seed Bank and ensure we make full use of this wonderful new building, the only one of its kind in Ireland 
  • €100,000 ($133,000) will be used to buy our land outright so that we are not at the mercy of higher interest charges
  • €50,000 will be held as a cash reserve so that we can manage our cashflow during the year to allow for the seasonality of our sales.
  • Whatever we raise we will spend in the order outlined above so that if for example we only raise €100,000 of our goal we will first secure our raw material for future years and complete our Seed Bank.

The Impact

It has been reported that since the 1950's, Europe has lost 80% of its food varieties. That means that we have managed to save 20% from extinction. Despite history, we continue to suffer from famine and the devastation of mono culture. Our food source, the simple seed, is not yet secure. It would be devastating if Irish Seed Savers were to close after so much hard work by so many people, staff, volunteers and supporters. We really need to keep Irish Seed Savers alive so that we can preserve all of our open pollinated seeds, fruit trees and potatoes for future generations. We also need to preserve the knowledge of seed saving and other vital sustainable living skills.

We have grown from very small beginnings to the saving of up to 800 varieties of open pollinated vegetable seeds 140 cultivars of apples trees and 50 varieties of potatoes as well as sharing our knowledge with thousands of children and adults .

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute, we thank you for taking the time to read our appeal and ask you to please share it and let your friends and family know about us and our campaign.

    We really appreciate any help we can get. Anything at all. Please use all the wonderful tools from Indiegogo to share our story and our appeal to help us. 

    Thank you from all at Irish Seed Savers
story_txt:
Short Summary
Irish Seed Savers Association was set up in 1991 to save Ireland's heritage and heirloom vegetable seeds, potatoes, grains and fruit trees from extinction.
Since then we have grown and grown and now have over 800 varieties of organic, open pollinated heritage seeds in our purpose built Seed Bank, together with the country's key orchards which hold the native Apple Tree Collection together with the country's only self-rooting orchard  here at Irish Seed Savers in County Clare. We also have over 50 varieties of potatoes, which is extremely important given Ireland's history of the Potato Famine, which occurred due to the devastation caused by potato blight; a virus which continues to devastate potato crops today. Then, almost everyone in Ireland grew only one variety, the Lumper potato, and that variety was destroyed by the blight which led to the Great famine. The Bute variety (grown in County Kerry) survived and saved countless souls. We now know that diversification of varieties prevents famines, but yet the world still suffers from famines and we still don't learn.
Unfortunately Irish Seed Savers, like many others have experienced a number of severe cuts over the past number of years and this together with the economic downturn  means that despite our best efforts the continued operations and very survival of Irish Seed Savers is in jeopardy. We have achieved a lot over the past number of years. We have created 20 beautiful acres of Organic Heritage Orchards, Seed Gardens and Woodlands for visitors. We have built Ireland's first National Seed Bank, open to the public, and making seed available to all. It is a living gene-bank,  where 800 varieties of heirloom seeds together with their stories have been collected and carefully grown out to bulk up the numbers. We share our skills and knowledge on seed saving and other sustainable living skills to thousands of children and adults through workshops, courses, camps and outreach programmes. This knowledge and seed base means that Ireland continues to have some control over its future food security in times of continued industrialisation of food and diminishing resources worldwide. Unless we all have the right and the opportunity to grow our own seed, save our own seed and share our seed we don't have food security. Empowering people to do that and save the heritage and heirloom varieties which grow best in Ireland, is what Irish Seed Savers does best. 
Please hep us continue. This appeal is to YOU, our friends and supporters and through you to all those interested in securing a sustainable future for Irish Seed Savers and the important work it undertakes on behalf of the people of Ireland. 

What We Need & What You Get
We need a total of €250,000 ($333,000)  to ensure our survival and we need to raise €100,000 ($133,000) of this on Indiegogo. The money will be used as follows 

€50,000 ($67,000) will be used to buy raw materials like rootstocks, pots, compost, tools, shop supplies so that we can grow our own sales and improve our future sustainability by making our seeds and trees available to YOU.

€50,000 ($67,000) will be used to finish our Seed Bank and ensure we make full use of this wonderful new building, the only one of its kind in Ireland 
€100,000 ($133,000) will be used to buy our land outright so that we are not at the mercy of higher interest charges

€50,000 will be held as a cash reserve so that we can manage our cashflow during the year to allow for the seasonality of our sales.
Whatever we raise we will spend in the order outlined above so that if for example we only raise €100,000 of our goal we will first secure our raw material for future years and complete our Seed Bank.



The Impact
It has been reported that since the 1950's, Europe has lost 80% of its food varieties. That means that we have managed to save 20% from extinction. Despite history, we continue to suffer from famine and the devastation of mono culture. Our food source, the simple seed, is not yet secure. It would be devastating if Irish Seed Savers were to close after so much hard work by so many people, staff, volunteers and supporters. We really need to keep Irish Seed Savers alive so that we can preserve all of our open pollinated seeds, fruit trees and potatoes for future generations. We also need to preserve the knowledge of seed saving and other vital sustainable living skills.
We have grown from very small beginnings to the saving of up to 800 varieties of open pollinated vegetable seeds 140 cultivars of apples trees and 50 varieties of potatoes as well as sharing our knowledge with thousands of children and adults . 



Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute, we thank you for taking the time to read our appeal and ask you to please share it and let your friends and family know about us and our campaign.
We really appreciate any help we can get. Anything at all. Please use all the wonderful tools from Indiegogo to share our story and our appeal to help us. 
Thank you from all at Irish Seed Savers

story:
My Story

My name is Christena Wilcox and I am a senior at Central Michigan University, majoring in Outdoor and Environmental Recreation. My desire to volunteer and travel has become possible when I was accepted to the International Student Volunteer program. However, traveling abroad is costly, and I'm asking for your sponsorship to make this opportunity possible. I wish to travel to South Africa where I will embark on a two week volunteer project helping out with the conservation of endangered species and habitats, protecting fragile ecosystems, and much more. Following the volunteer project is a 2 week adventure tour where I will dive into the rich culture of South Africa.

 

The Impact

The personal impact of this volunteer opportunity would be great, knowing the feeling of true contribution and making a difference. But most importantly is the positive impact made on the environment and endangered species in need of help. I feel that this is a truly remarkable opportunity that would stick with me for life. Along with the environmental aspect of this all, I will also be aiding in community development and working with local families and children. From aiding with health and education programs and and protecting fragile ecosystems, to creating a community garden so there is means of sustainable food production, the impact will be tremendous. 

 

What I Need & What You Get

The cost of the four week volunteer program is $3,695.00, not including airfare. Through your generous donations, bottle drives, hard work and persistence, I hope to reach this goal so I am able to pursue this opportunity in the summer of 2012. If all of the money is not raised in time, I will continue to work towards my goal so I can go during the summer of 2013. The program cost includes all accommodations, most meals, park entrance fees, and ground transportation while in the host country. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please know that any support offered will help out. You are not only helping me, but changing the lives of others that I will be able to help through this program. Spread the word! You can share this on facebook, twitter, email...Please help me get the word out!

story:
Nachhaltig denken heißt weiterverschenken

 
Lifecycler.de ist eine intuitive Plattform, um gebrauchte, aber noch wertige Artikel zu verschenken. In einer Welt mit wachsendem Konsum aber endlichen Resourcen, hilft dies, den Lebenszyklus von Produkten zu verlängern. Darüber hinaus leistet Lifecycler bei jeder Transaktion einen aktiven Beitrag zu nachhaltigem Leben in Form von Carbon Credits - eine zertifizierte Absenkung des Kohlenstoffdioxids (CO2) in der Atmosphäre. 

Neue Sachen bekommen, aber wohin mit den alten?

 
Jeder hat Dinge rumliegen, die nicht mehr gebraucht oder benutzt werden. Faustformel: was man 12 Monate nicht benutzt hat, braucht man wahrscheinlich auch in Zukunft nicht mehr und kann sie verschenken. Wegwerfen wäre ja Verschwendung, verkaufen zu aufwändig und risikoreich. Aber es gibt viele, die sich über den Artikel richtig freuen würden. Und für die Umwelt wäre es ohnehin besser, den Lebenszyklus des Artikels zu verlängern, statt ihn am Ende doch nur wegzuwerfen.
 

Lieber verschenken statt teuer entsorgen

 
Sachen zu verschenken, ist auf Lifecycler nicht nur kostenlos und sehr einfach, sondern man erhält für jeden verschenkten Artikel auch noch 50 kg CO2 gutgeschrieben, die über Carbon Credits neutralisiert werden. 50 kg CO2 entsprechen dem Carbon Footprint von etwa 2 Tagen eines Durchschnittsdeutschen. Wer also viel zu verschenken hat, kann seinen ökologischen Fußabdruck damit aktiv reduzieren! Per Smartphone-App oder Homepage sind die Artikel im Handumdrehen hochgeladen. 
 

Damit hilfst Du anderen und der Umwelt!

 
Wer sich einen angebotenen Artikel schnappen will, zahlt lediglich eine geringe Gebühr, die die Kosten des Versands (klimaneutral mit DHL GoGreen), der Carbon Credits und einen kleinen Beitrag zu den Plattformkosten umfasst. Der Geber erhält dann ein kostenloses Versandlabel von DHL Paket und kann den Artikel an jeder Poststelle abgeben. Natürlich kann man den Artikel vom Nehmer auch abholen lassen. So freuen sich alle drei - Geber, Nehmer und die Umwelt - wenn es Dinge zu verschenken gibt.
 

Lifecycler ist Non-Profit!

 
Wir haben Lifecycler aus idealistischen und gemeinnützigen Motiven gegründet. Alle Mitarbeiter arbeiten ehrenamtlich und erhalten weder Gehalt noch eine sonstige Vergütung. Noch ist Lifecycler jedoch zu wenig bekannt, um sich bereits selbst zu tragen. Wir brauchen daher einen Marketing-Etat, um für die Plattform zu werben. Dieses Budget wollen wir in Adword-Kampagnen, aber auch in Kooperationen mit Schulen, Fundbüros und Unternehmen investieren. Mit unserem Ziel von 10.000 EUR könnten wir richtig loslegen und eine Lifecycler-Community starten. 
 

Wir brauchen ein Marketing-Budget! 

 
Die Plattform ist fertig und alle Features funktionieren tadellos. Wir haben zusätzlich jeweils eine App für Android und iOS gebaut, die bereits live sind und alle wesentlichen Funktionen der Homepage abdecken. Mehr Informationen (auch zur Herkunft und dem Nachweis der CO2-Zertifikate) findet Ihr auf der Homepage lifecycler.de.
 
Wir hoffe, Euch gefällt dieses Konzept und Ihr unterstützt den Lifecycler! Dies ist ein echter Beitrag für eine "Circular Economy", einer nachhaltigen Art zu leben. Vielen Dank für Eure Unterstützung!
 

Die Perks!

 
Das Lifecycler-Notizbuch
 
Die Lifecycler-Standarte

story:
Who we are & What we’re doing

Eco- Lifestyles L3C is a hybrid green business located in New Orleans, La that provides eco-guidance and develops innovative eco-projects to help individuals, businesses, & communities’ transition into a healthier and more sustainable lifestyle. Presently, we're planning a multi-dimensional competition for October 23, 2011 along with a host of cultural, environmental, & sports related preliminary events starting on April 22, 2011. Our mission is to highlight the Natural Eco-Friendly Man with all of his Diverse Qualities!

THE PURPOSE is to popularize healthier and sustainable living among the black community starting with black males who are constantly subjected to negative profiling & stereotyping views. That hinders or prevents them from obtaining fair & equitable opportunities in the education, job, and housing sectors.

 

THE DOUBLE BENEFIT is that it not only provides contestants with pertinent environmental info, experiences, and exposure; but the competition also serves as a platform for on-going awareness & interest in the survivability of the "San Bushmen" People of Southern Africa, earth's oldest eco-friendly homo-sapiens; which is why we chose to title the competition after them. And plus, their imposed name is perfectly suited for our target market- which is intended for, but not limited to Black males (ages 21-35) who embrace their ethnic & natural  identity by wearing their hair in a Bush/Afro, Dreads/Locks, Braids, or Plaits. Additionally, we’ve come to find that they both share in cultural & identity struggles when attempting to live a natural lifestyle.

 F.Y.I- Monies raised will support the on-going production of this annual competition with 25% of event merchandise proceeds donated to the legal & cultural battles being waged on behalf of the Bushmen people's right to their ancestral lands. Let's all commit to the preservation of eco-sustainable Human Cultures & their ways - at home & abroad! To find out more about the importance of the Bushmen people, their land, and their culture go to our fb page: Save The Bushmen & Their Land. For their plight is also our plight!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

To successfully launch our eco-campaign & competition, we need to raise an estimated $22,000, or 2/3 of our total budget to cover major expenses. These expenses are the following: production staff & supplies, multi-media marketing, merchandising, venue(s), preliminary events, staging design. If our financial goal is not reached within the intended deadline, we will postpone the project until we reach our targeted goal. We will establish on-going communications with contributors until needed funds are obtained. Furthermore, we will also be seeking out socially responsible companies for sponsorship commitments & merchandising 'Save The Bushmen...' tee shirts to ensure that this project is actualized. 

We implore you to align yourself with an environmental imperative by helping us get the word out, and also by participating as a contributor or partner. On the side of this page you can discover perks that are being offered for your financial commitment. We welcome your comments & suggestions as we make dynamic steps together to make a difference in greening our world & preserving Eco-sustainable Cultures. If you have a desire to make a greater commitment as a contributor, partner, or to participate somehow, feel free to contact us at........... bushmencompetition@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

LEO Zoological Conservation Center is a non-profit refuge for rare, threatened, and endangered animals, with a focus on breeding species at risk. In addition, LEO ZCC supports conservation efforts through our Wild Partners. Around the world, species are struggling with threats like deforestation, habitat fragmentation and climate change. LEO Zoological Conservation Center has created a unique network which builds bridges between impactful “boots on the ground” conservation initiatives to our center worldwide. As an active participant, we are collaborating to preserve the imminent threat to our planet’s biodiversity and restore harmony between humankind and the richness of our natural world.

We are proud to have the Guatemala Project as one of our Wild Partners. Guatemala Project is a vital conservation effort where Daniel Kopulos and an assistant travel to a remote area of Guatemala to bring medical equipment and supplies, nutritional aids and expertise to help support the current work being done with endangered Scarlet Macaws, Mesoamerican River Turtles and Jaguar and the local communities.

Who is Daniel Kopulos?

Daniel has been breeding and hand rearing a variety of parrot species for over 23 years. He was a veterinary technician for more than 10 years of that time and also a zoo keeper. He has a vast knowledge of exotic animal medicine and nutrition.

 

 

What is the Guatemala Project?

Several years ago, the then director of the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) projects in Latin America asked Daniel for his help with the Scarlet Macaw Project. Since then, Daniel has visited the WCS station in the Mayan Biosphere twice to bring medical supplies and teach the WCS workers and veterinarians about macaw husbandry and chick rearing.

Central America in general is a hot zone for conservation. The isthmus supports seven percent of the planet’s species though it makes up just one-tenth of one percent of the Earth’s surface. The scarlet macaws of the Mayan Biosphere are one of those species that is critically endangered, with just 300 members living in the wild. The WCS project has had some amazing successes – since the project began the estimated macaw population has nearly doubled, and last year a major victory occurred when the station helped produce a large bumper crop of fledglings that have since taken flight. The Scarlet Macaw Project has also been selected by BBC’s “Saving Planet Earth” series as an example of excellence in conservation.

What We Need

LEO ZCC aims to raise funds to send supplies and skilled conservationists (Daniel and an assistant) to the Biosphere to provide up to date education for the WCS local station workers.

Work at the project station includes nest protection, artificial nest construction, chick rearing, veterinary monitoring, and education initiatives. All of this work requires skills training, supplies and funding, and the battle to save the macaws is far from over. While in the field last year, Daniel created a wish list of supplies that would greatly increase the overall success of the project.

If we do not reach our goal, LEO ZCC will forfeit a larger percentage to IndieGogo, and will provide the Guatemala Project with all the funds that are raised.

Your funds help us to provide the following categories: handfeeding formula, medication allowance, medical supply allowance, anatomy charts, handfeeding syringes, sterile microchips, airfare and room & board and food for 2 people.

The Impact

The Guatemalan Project, although working specifically with three species of animals helps to preserve all the life in that region. The animals selected to work with are all not only endangered, but are also known as landscape species. This means they have significant meaning or purpose for the region. Each of these species have been a part of the culture in the area since early civilization. They are still recognized as important and powerful species. By protecting them the land, forest and waters are also protected because you can not have one without the other. The Mayan Biosphere is one of the largest regions of forest and is a major contributor to air quality for the rest of us globally. Many resources have also come from this area over the decades including medicine, fuel, food and materials.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the Guatemala Project campaign with your friends and colleagues. Together we can make a difference!
 
 
 
 

PERKS

Kenyon Gibson's painting of macaws. (See Perks to find out how you can get a signed limited edition print and help fund the Guatemala Project at the same time!)

Guatemala Project is a vital conservation effort where Daniel Kopulos and an assistant travel to a remote area of Guatemala to bring medical equipment and supplies, nutritional aids and expertise to help support the current work being done with endangered Scarlet Macaws, Mesoamerican River Turtles and Jaguar and the local communities.
Who is Daniel Kopulos?

Daniel has been breeding and hand rearing a variety of parrot species for over 23 years. He was a veterinary technician for more than 10 years of that time and also a zoo keeper. He has a vast knowledge of exotic animal medicine and nutrition.
 
 
What is the Guatemala Project?
Several years ago, the then director of the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) projects in Latin America asked Daniel for his help with the Scarlet Macaw Project. Since then, Daniel has visited the WCS station in the Mayan Biosphere twice to bring medical supplies and teach the WCS workers and veterinarians about macaw husbandry and chick rearing.
Central America in general is a hot zone for conservation. The isthmus supports seven percent of the planet’s species though it makes up just one-tenth of one percent of the Earth’s surface. The scarlet macaws of the Mayan Biosphere are one of those species that is critically endangered, with just 300 members living in the wild. The WCS project has had some amazing successes – since the project began the estimated macaw population has nearly doubled, and last year a major victory occurred when the station helped produce a large bumper crop of fledglings that have since taken flight. The Scarlet Macaw Project has also been selected by BBC’s “Saving Planet Earth” series as an example of excellence in conservation.


What We Need
LEO ZCC aims to raise funds to send supplies and skilled conservationists (Daniel and an assistant) to the Biosphere to provide up to date education for the WCS local station workers.
Work at the project station includes nest protection, artificial nest construction, chick rearing, veterinary monitoring, and education initiatives. All of this work requires skills training, supplies and funding, and the battle to save the macaws is far from over. While in the field last year, Daniel created a wish list of supplies that would greatly increase the overall success of the project.
If we do not reach our goal, LEO ZCC will forfeit a larger percentage to IndieGogo, and will provide the Guatemala Project with all the funds that are raised.
Your funds help us to provide the following categories: handfeeding formula, medication allowance, medical supply allowance, anatomy charts, handfeeding syringes, sterile microchips, airfare and room & board and food for 2 people.


The Impact
The Guatemalan Project, although working specifically with three species of animals helps to preserve all the life in that region. The animals selected to work with are all not only endangered, but are also known as landscape species. This means they have significant meaning or purpose for the region. Each of these species have been a part of the culture in the area since early civilization. They are still recognized as important and powerful species. By protecting them the land, forest and waters are also protected because you can not have one without the other. The Mayan Biosphere is one of the largest regions of forest and is a major contributor to air quality for the rest of us globally. Many resources have also come from this area over the decades including medicine, fuel, food and materials.

Other Ways You Can Help


Please share the Guatemala Project campaign with your friends and colleagues. Together we can make a difference!
 
 
 
 

PERKS

Kenyon Gibson's painting of macaws. (See Perks to find out how you can get a signed limited edition print and help fund the Guatemala Project at the same time!)

story:
About GINEPRO ENERGIA...

Emanuele Giacomelli was born in 1963 in Tuscany Italy.

Since he was a child he dreamt of ways of obtaining energy from renewable sources. His earliest experiment was placing a metal strip on the top of a tree connected to a condenser. Luckily for him no lightning hit the metal strip so he is still here to continue with his passion.

He has never believed in perpetual motion, but has tried to separate the water in hydrogen and oxygen and to feed an internal combustion engine using the electricity produced by the engine itself. Giving the illusion that the engine runs for ever, the deception is the engine only turns whilst the battery has power.

He has also tried to obtain methylic alcohol and methane from fire wood to feed an internal combustion engine. He has studied how to maintain both warm and cold thermal energy, gathering material on the technique of ice boxes which maintained ice for a period of over one year.

He often uses an electric bike and would love to see more cars running on electric power as he considers electricity more efficient than hydrogen, biogas or vegetable fuels.

He is interested in wood housebuilding, convinced that the best performances in energetic saving are buildings in wood, but only from the first stage and over.

In the past 12 years he has delighted children with his shows, creating giant soap bubbles of over 140 cm. (You can see this at www.archimago.org).

Covering his subjects in the giant bubbles, however if the wind was too strong he soon discovered that the show would be ruined. From this observation he then designed a turbine structure based on a tree that moved with the minimum wind force. This structure is 7 meters high and has been carefully studied for optimum performance but still needs approved testing and patenting. It then needs to go into production and calculating the cost of material and work prior to marketing. 

What We Need & What You Get

At the moment Mr. Giacomelli is seeking financial assistance from anyone interested in this project. He is also keen to speak to anyone with engineering knowledge who can offer technical advise or materials for this project. 

We need funds for:

  • Registered design in Italy
  • Partial contribution for the European patent and maintenance plus taxes 
  • Graphics and video, publicity
  • Project and mechanical design
  • Test
  • Alternator technical research
  • Electromagnetic Certification
  • CE
  • Realization of the first 10 prototypes

You'll receive all the news about the works on Ginepro Energia Wind Turbine

Ginepro Energia Wind Turbine - Characteristics

  • Low ambient impact
  • 100% recyclable
  • Minimum maintenance
  • Low rotation speed
  • Perfect reading of the advertising message
  • No noise
  • Different sizes possible
  • You can put in the garden
  • You can connect to the grid, to a battery, directly to your home
  • Fully integrable in the ambient, LIKE A SCULPTURE.

Other Ways You Can Help

Emanuele also accepts supplies of material like iron, aluminum, special canvas fabric or laminated polycarbonate.

You can spread the word, tell about this campaign to your friends, share the link of this campaign on your pages...

Help the dreams to become real! Thank you!

 

...something about Cosmic Dreamers...

We are the COSMIC DREAMERS and we dream a better world,

we believe in this better world, and we wish this better world…

and so we need your help, to help someone else.

Whatever we make, wherever we live, WE ALL NEED ENERGY, and so we are supporting a project, GINEPRO ENERGIA, in parallel with our own projects in Electronic Music and 3D Graphic Art.

We have made a virtual model of this prototype and created a video to show the features of this wind turbine and the surrounding landscape. We have put a lot of effort into this video and hope you will appreciate the essence of our ideas.

To arrive at our goal as soon as possible we urgently need funding to assist in the substantial costs of this development.

 

Thanks to Indiegogo we can ask help to the WORLD, and so if you think that this project is useful, we say a BIG THANKS to all of you for supporting GINEPRO ENERGIA!

Peace and Love


Ely & Bruno
COSMIC DREAMERS
www.cosmicdreamers.com
www.reverbnation.com/cosmicdreamers

story:
Short Summary

Each flood bucket clean-up kit will include:

  •  scouring pads
  • 7 sponges, assorted sizes
  • 1 scrub brush
  • 18 cleaning towels (reusable, like Easy Wipes)
  • 1 dry laundry detergent, 50-78 oz.
  • 1 bottle liquid bleach
  • 1 bottle (12 oz.) liquid concentrated household cleaner (i.e. Lysol)
  • 1 bottle (25-oz.) liquid antibacterial dish soap (like Dawn)• Clothesline, two 50-foot or one 100-foot
  • 50 clothes pins
  • 5 dust masks
  • 1 pair latex gloves
  • 1 pair work gloves
  • 1 box heavy-duty trash bags, 22-27 count (33-35 gallon size bags)
  • 1 bottle insect repellent (drops or lotion, not aerosol), 6-14 oz.

The Impact

Although larger organizations such as the American Red Cross will most likely be assisting with shelter, food and health care, there is a need for supplies for property owners to use once the waters recede. These kits will allow homeowners and businesses to clean up their properties and allow for sanitary conditions.

Any monies collected above and beyond what is needed for the clean-up buckets will be given to the Corral Bar to pay for damages caused by the flooding.

story:
We are at a showdown.

We live in the Sixth Great Extinction of all life on Earth.  Insecticides threaten the global food supply.  GMOs choke out organic agriculture.  Our story is the Star Wars of the environmental struggle.

Monsanto is our villain, the instrument of death that breeds GMOs and soaks seeds in neonicotinoid insecticides.  Bayer, Syngenta and the United States government are Monsanto’s nefarious cohorts.

We will march from Ferguson to the global headquarters of Monsanto.

We will unleash that part of ourselves that we've held quietly in reserve, that collection of courage. Anybody hear me? 

Let's be too outlandish to be called mere "protesters."

Our nonviolent direct action will be so dramatic that people will shout out, “How will the bees get back to their hive?” and “How will we survive?”

What We Need

$6,000 for training, rehearsal and action gear

$4,000 for travel to Saint Louis in a veggie-powered bus

$2,500 for honoraria for ten activists ($250 per person)

$7,500 for our legal defense fund

Here are the stickers we will send you if you donate and share your address with us.


Who is Reverend Billy and the Stop Shopping Choir?

Reverend Billy Talen is the Earthalujah! preacher, an author, artist and father.  He has been jailed more than 50 times for his dramatic advocacy for the Earth, justice and democracy.    Savitri D leads the Stop Shopping Choir, a community of 40 singer-activists and musicians.  Nehemiah Luckett is the music director.  Their work has been featured in the New Yorker, Guardian, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, National Public Radio, Al Jazeera America, MSNBC, Fox, and many other international media outlets.

Stay connected

Let's create our own community.  Subscribe to our Earthalujahville! email list.

Spread the word on the Book of Face, Twitter and YouTube.

story:
We are a small group of scientists who developed the project Wave Power Only (WPO) and Solar Energy (SE). Many countries spend significant funds to desalinated seawater,for example Malta Mediterranean. Today have been around different desalination methods, but all of them require large electric power. It costs a lot of money. We offer a new desalination method without electricity consumption.

With your donation, we want to fully develop the project.

  The first step in this direction has already been taken as you see this little video.

The next step is to create the “WPO + SE” equipment for individual users. To make the next step we need new experiments and also special materials.We estimate that the total costs will be approximately 5,000. - U.S. $ to be ready for the first production samples.

If you help with the

      $10

  You'll get our label, which can be attached to a flat surface. Your name will be placed on our website:Donation

You can help make this commercialization a success.Meanwhile spread the news of this campaign on FaceBook, Twitter and other social networks to honor the scientists and engineers.Send this address to your friends and relatives.

  $ 20

  You'll get our label(5ps), which can be attached to a flat surface.

Your name will be placed on our website: Danation

  $28

  We will send you a glass cup with our label.

Your name will be placed on our website: Donation

  $50

  We will send you a T-shirt.

Your name will be placed on our website: Donation

  $100

 We will send you a T-shirt, bag with our logo.

 Your name will be placed on our website: Donation

  $150

  We will send you a T-shirt, bag with our logo and 4pc glass cup's with our label. Your name will be placed on our website: Donation

With your donation You will be placed in the queue to buy WPO + STE set for individual use. Package price will be 2,300. - U.S. $ and you'll save 1,000. - U.S. $ from the market price. Your name will be placed on one operating unit of floating platform "WPO+SE". There will be a total 36 operation unit's.

Our project will be necessary for the people who live in the desert next to the sea and the people living on the islands, such as the Mediterranean, Malta.For seawater desalination Malta spent 1/3 of an annual budget, about 180 000 000.-$ US.

Even an individual person can produce drinking water with our equipment in the desert and sell for surrounding population for drinking, and affusion plant.It will not harm the environment and solve the food problem.

Your donation will go towards making this happen and raising as much money as possible for this fantastic cause. So please donate what you can and from the bottom of our heart's we truly grateful,Thanks again!

In name of the our Scientific group

Rims Vaitkus

story:
Women's Wilderness Walk
In tribute to Dr Ian Player, 7 brave women embarked on a 5-day Wilderness Trail in iMfolozi Game Reserve from the 7th – 11th March 2015.

In doing so the 'Women in the Wilderness' are raising funds for Save Our iMfolozi Wilderness! The Save Our iMfolozi Wilderness (SOiW) campaign was launched on 1 May 2014. It is a project of the Global Environmental Trust (GET) opposed to Ibutho Coal’s application for an open cast mine that threatens the world famous iMfolozi wilderness area,  as well as the health of neighbouring rural communities.

The Wilderness area is also home to the largest concentration of rhino in the world!

So who are these Women of the Wilderness??

World Youth Rhino Summit Ambassadors for Wildlife & Conservation:

Gwendolyn Isaacs: Ashton College, Ballito
Jacomé Pretorius: Glenwood House, George
Kelly Dramos: American International School of Mozambique, Maputo

Who were joined by:

Sheelagh Antrobus: Project Rhino KZN Co-Ordinator
Bronwyn Laing: Rhino Art Co-Ordinator and World Youth Rhino Summit Team
Micah van Schalkwyk: Project Rhino KZN, Rhino Art and World Youth Rhino Summit Team  
Penny Parker: Works in the Cape Union Mart Marketing Dept. but is a conservationist at heart and is always willing to assist. Penny is joining the group to assist with photos, videos and writing our story to inspire others

Picture: Youth #RhinoWarriors Gwendolwyn Isaacs, Kelly Dramos, Jacomé Pretorius on Trail

Dr Player made mention during his World Rhino Day speech at the Summit that he's glad things have changed and that women are more involved in conservation. We agree: this was for you 'Madolo'.

story:
Manx BirdLife is a charity based in the Isle of Man working for the conservation of wild birds.

Having already contributed significantly to bird conservation on the Isle of Man by publishing the Manx Bird Atlas in 2007 and releasing a Manx wildlife documentary in 2014, Manx BirdLife is keen to grow in both achievements and ambition.

To help fund this ambition, Dora and Sophie (both working for the charity) are taking part in the ‘End to End Walk’ where they will have to walk 39 grueling miles (63km) in less than 10 hours. The race has several cut off points along the way, meaning that if they don’t walk fast enough they are taken out of the race and do not get the chance to finish it.

The race will take place on Sunday the 21st of September starting at the Point of Ayre at 8 am and ending at The Sound, both invaluable areas for wild birds in the Isle of Man.

Our ladies will embrace this physical challenge with a fighting spirit, something which the charity has a history of excelling at in its conservation targets. 

Follow their training and campaigning progress via:

  • Twitter: www.twitter.com/ManxBirdLife
  • Facebook: www.facebook.com/ManxBirdLife
  • Website: www.manxbirdlife.im   
Please spread the word amongst your friends and family too!
Contributions by cheque can be sent to our Office: 35 New Road, Laxey, Isle of Man, IM4 7BG


How Your Contribution Will Help

  • Upgrading a decayed IT system and computers: 2 new PCs, new Windows and Microsoft Office, new memory for a struggling old server.
  • Raising awareness of conservation issues affecting bird populations on the Isle of Man
  • Upgrading the database to a user friendly entry front-end 
  • Advocating for better bird conservation with local authorities 


Manx BirdLife Future

  • Providing an oasis for wildlife: Manx BirdLife is in the process of creating a nature reserve at the Point of Ayre in partnership with a gravel extraction company, the Island Aggregates.
  • Increase public engagement and brand awareness: reaching out to more people to show them how special the Isle of Man and its wildlife is. 

Our Current Work

  • Completing two more years worth of research on a Repeat Bird Atlas which is critical in finding out which species are in need of conservation action.
  • Gathering data through the public with a garden birdwatch scheme and bird sightings reports.
  • Maintaining the most comprehensive data set on bird populations in the Isle of Man, an invaluable resource for conservation

Our History

  • Founded in 1998 by Chris Sharpe in order to produce a ‘Bird Atlas’ for the Isle of Man, a comprehensive study of populations of all species, published in 2007. It greatly improved knowledge on and conservation strategy for the island’s birds.
  • Chris’s perseverance led to production of ‘The Isle of Man – A Natural World’ film. As you can see from the trailer at the top of the page, it showcases the spectacular wildlife of the island superbly.


We would be immensely grateful for you to give whatever you can to help build on our legacy and achieve more in conservation.

Maintaining the most comprehensive data set on bird populations in the Isle of Man, an invaluable resource for conservation




Our History


Founded in 1998 by Chris Sharpe in order to produce a ‘Bird Atlas’ for the Isle of Man, a comprehensive study of populations of all species, published in 2007. It greatly improved knowledge on and conservation strategy for the island’s birds.

Chris’s perseverance led to production of ‘The Isle of Man – A Natural World’ film. As you can see from the trailer at the top of the page, it showcases the spectacular wildlife of the island superbly.

We would be immensely grateful for you to give whatever you can to help build on our legacy and achieve more in conservation.

story:
"In recent years, research has demonstrated substantial declines in many species of bees within the UK. In particular, the number of managed honeybee colonies in the UK fell by 53% between 1985 and 2005 (Potts et al, 2010a) and wild honeybees are thought be nearly extinct throughout the British Isles (Carreck, 2008)."

 

BeeWatch Pesticide User

Here is how quick and easy it is to inform local beekeepers of a pesticide treatment:

 

You can fill in a treatment schedule to warn beekeepers of all upcoming treatments

You can set treatments in different regions and you will see all of the surrounding beekeepers on the map

The pesticide user app is simple yet very effective

 

Thank you! Using the tools above you have now warned all local beekeepers of any upcoming pesticide treatment

 

BeeWatch Beekeeper

You will get sent an instant notification when any pesticide treatment within 5km of your apiary is recorded. These will appear on your map, detailing when they are occurring. If they are happening in the next 24 hours they will be red.

 

 

You may have an apiary in different locations. You will receive notifications for pesticide treatments within 5km of all your listed apiaries. Your apiary symbol (Bee) will turn red when new treatments are recorded.

 

 

Any BeeWatch user can send swarm alerts

If you come across a swarm, as a pesticide user or beekeeper you can fill out a swarm alert which will instantly notify all local 'registered' swarm collectors. They can then arrange collection and save one more colony.

story:
Short Summary

The Sustainable Brothers is a student-based community-driven organization that consists of individuals from a diverse range of educational faculties such as sustainability, business science, law, the natural sciences and engineering. Despite their diverse range of expertise, they believe in collaborating with one another to achieve their common goal of promoting a sustainable ethos, acting on this way of life by implementing beneficial solutions to combatting the crises that have negative impacts on our planet and affect us all.

The Sustainable Brothers aim to raise awareness of the problems that persist in our current world, and provide innovative and practical solutions to combatting these problems, focusing on collaboration rather than competiveness in bringing about success in their projects.

Their biggest project to date is what they like to call their ‘Secret Garden’, a two-acre student house in the heart of Stellenbosch. They have turned this unproductive piece of land into a productive organic farm. Take a look at this video to see how they accomplished such a project: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lMddCU4Rn4M

Other projects they are involved in include recycling collection from various homes around Stellenbosch, and the donations of their organic produce to a particular crèche in the local informal settlement, Kyamandi.

If you would like to see more of what the Sustainable Brothers are doing, or help support them, visit their Facebook page: www.facebook.com/sustainablebrothers and website: www.sustainablebrothers.wix.com/sustainablebrothers. They can also be reached via email (www.sustainable.brothers@gmail.com) if you have any suggestions or would like to collaborate with them on any of their projects.


What We Need & What You Get

As mentioned earlier, we are currently running two major projects - one at our organic farm and the other involving recycling collection. In order for the Sustainable Brothers to be able to expand these projects to more communities around South Africa and potentially the world, and also implement further projects which we are trying put into practice, we unfortunately do require further funding. 

We are merely students with many exciting ideas, however, being students, we lack the capital to successfully implement many of the projects we are wishing to establish. One project we are very eager on implementing is empowering many of the local people in Kyamandi by providing them with the necessary resources to establish their own organic farms, which they can then utilize to provide for themselves and their families, as well as sell to their neighbors in the informal settlement.

If you would like to see an organization collaborate with like-minded individuals and attempt to combat inequality and the environmental crises that face mankind today, Sustainable Brothers has the passion and knowledge to do so with your financial assistance.

All projects are documented on Facebook and Youtube so you can conveniently track our projects and their success online. Our Facebook page (www.facebook.com/sustainablebrothers) has recently been updated with recent photographs of our recycling project in Stellenbosch.

The Impact

Sustainable Brothers eventually wish to possess enough momentum so that their projects can be expanded on to the global scene, making their impact more expansive and transforming the way in which the world operates today into a sustainable world where one's future children and future generations can enjoy the luxuries of life that mankind today can enjoy!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sustainable Brothers can also be helped by the mere promotion of their organization and the ethos they possess and promote. Advertising their impacts and the organization that unites all the sustainable brothers can assist them in acquiring funding from other sources. They also are very much open to collaboration with other organizations and individuals where they exist to establish a platform where like-minded individuals can help and be helped with bringing about appropriate interventions to the problems that the world faces today!

story:
Short Summary

We have a planet in crisis and a people in crisis.  The people of the world are scared, hostile, and angry.

  • After an out-of-body experience in December of 1994, I started on a long search for the ultimate spiritual truth.
  • Nature was meant to be our teacher, yet we have ignored the very thing that is built into all living things.
  • Our bodies are a temple and that physical nature, as well as the nature around us is constantly mirroring a profound truth.  This is what I call the separation from GOD phenomenon.
  • As I began searching through the religious texts of the world, I was able to relate the scientific and the religious to the human body.  Eventually coming up with a formula that would bring the power of the COSMOS down to our world for our use.
  • The formula is simple, the ingredients are simple, and WATER is the magic ingredient.  WATER is the KEY to our energy crisis and the global warming crisis.
  • One of my most profound moments was when I realized that Hydrogen was the only atom without a neutron, thus providing a direct route to GOD.
  • How have we let our world get to this point without understanding what WATER means to us spiritually and as our ultimate energy source.  This energy can provide AC - DC - and a powerful pulse-type energy. 
  • You, personally, have Hydrogen glue holding your DNA strand together.  You burn 1/2 pound of Hydrogen each day to supply energy to your cells.  My favorite MANTRA is:  No electron moves in a living system without the presence of Hydrogen. 
  • In Revelations in The Bible God says that he is Alpha and Omega - the beginning and the end.  Why are Greek words used in The Bible?  Because it is a clue - Alpha means obstructed to the truth of water.  Omega means there whirl sediments.  Some other truths in the Greek alphabet are Eta whose symbol is H (as in the symbol for Hydrogen) means with water, Theta means extend water, and Psi which comes right before Omega means come out vapor.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $150,000 to allow us to make a video showing the world how this energy is mixed and how it will power anything.  We will also convert a Chevy Volt to run via GEM Energy which will never need anything else.  The major reason for this video is to show the world that this GEM Energy is wireless and can be transmitted from a single source to power everything in your home.

  • We need additional tanks of Hydrogen and Oxygen.
  • We need to purchase some supplies, such as, needles and tubing for our $700.00 injector.  This injector allows us to precisely calibrate the titrations of water, Hydrogen, and Oxygen.
  • Any funding received will go to bringing this GEM Energy to the world.
  • My partner, Dennis Holmes, will be required to travel to those people who will be helping with the transreceivers.  We are unsure of how many trips this will require.
  • The purchase of the Chevy Volt is part of where the funding will go.  
  • I will need to travel as well to be part of the video and explain more about this energy.
  • We will need to pay for laboratory time.

Judy has 22 books up on Amazon and if you donate money, you can pick out the book or books you would like to have and she will send you a PDF version directly to your email.

The Impact

How good is your imagination?  Can you imagine a world where the waters are pure, where health is a given, where energy is safe and harmless to you and your family, a world where we can travel freely outside of our planetary system, and a world where the anger is gone and peace has descended at last.

  • Einstein said, "If the answer is simple God is answering."
  • Nikola Tesla said, "One day man will connect his apparatus to the very wheel works of the Universe.  The very forces that motivate the planet and their orbits and will cause them to rotate will rotate his own machinery.
  • David Bohm said, "In one cubic centimeter of empty space, the amount of energy is much greater than the total amount of energy of all the matter in the known universe.
  • Jules Verne said, "I believe that water will one day be employed as fuel, that Hydrogen and Oxygen which constitute it, used singly or together, will furnish an inexhaustible source of heat and light, of an intensity of which coal is not capable."

Other Ways You Can Help

Holding this GEM Energy in your heart is a major help.  Greatness is reached through the heart of the people in unison with a great cause.

  • Please post this funding request to your websites, facebook pages, twitter pages, as well as e-mail the link.  Let's unite the people behind this project and we will be able to finally bring a safe and powerful energy to the entire planet.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • You can always call or e-mail Judy Beebe directly ~ judybeebe@centurytel.net ~ phone:  406-844-0222.

story:
Short Summary

Who we are

Carly Hutchinson and Ilsa Jule are the co-founders of Anahata Nature Sanctuary & Learning Center located in North Central Massachusetts. Collectively, we have 11 years of homesteading and farming experience. We have spent the past five years overseeing four sustainable forestry and wildlife conservation projects at Anahata. Ilsa, in addition to her experience as a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) or direct farm-to-consumer distributor and market farmer, is certified in wildlife rescue. We also have received three competitive USDA conservation grants over the past five years.

Why our campaign is important

Our current project focuses on preserving 48 acres of pristine woodland that is slated for a 10-home subdivision. We want to purchase this land and make it open to the public as a wildlife sanctuary. We also want to start a learning center there and offer educational programming that provides people of all ages and backgrounds with rewarding connections to the natural world.

We need to raise $50,350 to save this land and start our nature sanctuary and learning center.

Why your investment in Anahata is important:

·Trees are really good for our air quality! Did you know that 10% of all Massachusetts carbon dioxide emissions are taken in by the existing trees there? 

·The bad news is that more than 50% of forests in New England States will be developed. Each year, several square miles of forestland are developed in Massachusetts, resulting in both the outright loss of habitat for plants and animals, and a lower quality remaining habitat as forestlands are fragmented into smaller patches.

·Deforestation is a national problem so every acre we save is a plus. The US Department of Agriculture projects that in 40 years we will have almost 400,000 fewer acres of forest in the US. Did you know that US forests are decreasing faster than those in Brazil? Check out this link to learn more:   http://news.mongabay.com/2010/0427-hance_forestloss.html

·And that's just the beginning of why it matters. A growing body of research shows that our mental, physical and spiritual health is directly linked to our association with nature. 

·In a world with less leisure time, the amount of time we all spend inside in front of a TV or computer screen has created something that author Richard Louv calls "Nature Deficit Disorder"—this means that children, families, even entire communities, have a diminished use of their senses, attention difficulties and higher rates of physical and emotional illnesses.

What We Need & What You Get

Our $50,350 goal will allow us to purchase the first section of the 48 acres of land that is slated for development; get Anahata off the ground with a legal organizational structure; and begin our Learning Center programming. Here's the breakdown:

Budget:

  • Two building lots of the 48-acre parcel (3.5 acres)*: $35,000
  • Land appraisal for full 48 acres: $2,700
  • Non-profit organizational status [501(c)(3)]: $5,850
  • Limited Liability Company (LLC) for profit-based arm to support non-profit activity: $1,800
  • Programming (forest and wildlife workshops, interactive presentations, and other knowledge-based nature experiences): $5,000 
  • Total: $50,350

*This initial purchase will buy us time to raise the money to purchase the rest of the 48-acre parcel.

What you'll get out of this investment in Anahata:

You'll be supporting the preservation of a gorgeous piece of land as seen in our video and photographs here. You'll also be investing in programming that focuses on workshops and interactive educational experiences that promote interactions with the natural world by focusing on:

·  Tracking,

·  Bird watching,

·  Wildlife rescue workshops;

·  Foraging

·  Botany

·  Native/invasive plant knowledge

·  Fort building

·  Orienteering

·  Camping

·  Enjoying the power and healing benefits of nature through what we call Nature Bonding Retreats.

What happens if we don't reach our goal?

We will use whatever money we get to buy as much land as we can, and/or get our non-profit status so that we will be eligible for grants from private foundations and governmental organizations.

Our track record

1.  We have already conserved 230 acres of pristine Massachusetts woodland (125 of those acres soon to be held in non-developable status for perpetuity through a state conservation program).

2.  Over the past five years the forests on these lands have been managed for sustainability and healthy forest growth as well as wildlife conservation and proliferation by working with certified foresters, land preservation and wildlife conservation experts.

3.  We have received three USDA conservation grants to protect the forests and wildlife we steward.

But…we don't want to stop there…

·  We want to preserve more forests and wildlife

·  We want to help to decrease nature deficit disorder through exciting and fun experiences for people of all ages and backgrounds that allow them to have positive interactions with the natural world

·  We want to provide public access to a 48-acre nature preserve.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support our campaign financially, please help us by:

  • Getting the word out and making some noise about our campaign.
  • This is easy to do using the Indiegogo share tools!

We really appreciate all your help and support. Together we can improve the planet.
